content:

YHM bags deal of over US$37m

Group to lease power generation equipment to South Asian utility board

Published

Mon, Sep 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

YHM Group has secured a contract worth more than US$37 million over a 20-year period to lease a set of hydroelectric power-generation equipment for power supply to a national utility board in South Asia.

The company expects the lease to commence after the commissioning of the power plant, which is expected before the end of this year.

The new deal will enable the company to diversify its earnings stream and establish a foothold in the energy-services business segment, YHM Group said in a statement yesterday.

The company is planning to place one billion new warrants to raise net proceeds of about $24.5 million, and has appointed Maybank Kim Eng Securities as its placement agent.

The warrants represent 12.26 per cent of the company's issued and paid-up share capital, and 10.92 per cent of its enlarged issued share capital.

Each warrant will be issued at a price of $0.025, and will entitle the holder to subscribe for one new ordinary share at the exercise price of $0.023.

The proposed exercise price of $0.025 for each warrant share represents a discount of 61 per cent to the volume-weighted average price of $0.0644 for trades done on the Singapore Exchange on Sept 24, the last full market day on which shares of the company were traded.

The company will receive an additional S$25 million, assuming all the warrants are exercised.

Some 80 to 100 per cent of the cash proceeds from the warrants issued and the exercise of the warrants will be allocated to the oil and gas business; up to 10 per cent will be used for the energy services project, and another 10 per cent, for the general working capital of the group.

The directors of the group said there was enough working capital available to the group to meet its present requirements after taking into consideration its present bank facilities.

YHM will be holding an extraordinary general meeting to approve the warrants issue.

YHM's shares closed 15 per cent lower at 6.1 cents yesterday.

site_title: S Koreans cash out stocks to cover jump in rental costs
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

S Koreans cash out stocks to cover jump in rental costs

Individuals sold a net 3.1t won of shares last month

Published

Mon, Sep 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SEOUL] When Choi Jong Hyun found his 50 million won (S$58,400) annual salary wasn't enough to cover the 8 per cent jump in rent for his Seoul apartment, he decided to cut back on stock investments rather than take on debt.

"I would rather cash out the stocks I now hold and not pay additional interest," Mr Choi, 32, who works in the financial industry and has about 50 million won of investments, said last Tuesday.

Investors such as Mr Choi are exiting South Korea's stock market as rental costs climb to the highest level since at least 1986 and household debt rises to a record. Individuals sold a net 3.1 trillion won of shares last month, the most in nine months, while trading of Kospi index stocks fell to a six-year low, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

The retreat by those investors, who accounted for about 45 per cent of the nation's equity trading last month, threatens to limit gains in the Kospi, which has rallied 8 per cent since the end of June, according to Barclays plc and Hanwha Investment & Securities Co. Consumer confidence sank to a five-month low last month, even after a rebound in exports fuelled the fastest economic growth in two years last quarter.

"Local participation is quite low," Chanik Park, the Seoul-based head of Korea equity research at Barclays, said last Tuesday. "Consumer sentiment and investor sentiment at this moment is not that positive."

The Kospi has climbed 4.4 per cent last month to 2,011.80, bringing its gain this year to 0.7 per cent. The won strengthened 3.4 per cent to 1,073.65 last month, while the cost of protecting the nation's sovereign debt against non-payment using credit default swaps fell 10 basis points to 76, according to CMA. The yield on the nation's five-year government bonds fell five basis points to 3.06 per cent last week.

Foreign investors have fuelled the Kospi's rally as data showed the economy expanded 1.1 per cent in the three months through June and exports jumped at a quicker-than-estimated 7.7 per cent rate in August.

International money managers ploughed a net US$7 billion into South Korean shares last month, the most on record, according to exchange data compiled by Bloomberg. The Kospi is valued at 1.06 times net assets, a 47 per cent discount to the MSCI All-Country World Index.

"Local retail investors are likely to return to the equity market by the end of this year when the economic uncertainties are cleared and this year's corporate profit figures are released," Cho Seong Joon, a Seoul-based strategist at NH Investment & Securities Co, said last Friday.

For now, sales by individual investors are accelerating. Outflows last month were more than twice as large as the 1.4 trillion won of withdrawals during the first eight months of the year, data compiled by Bloomberg show. The 100-day average value traded of Kospi shares declined to 4.03 trillion won last Friday, the lowest level since June 2007.

"Individual investors will be the group that could drive up trading volumes but this won't be easy," Kang Hyun Cheol, a strategist at Woori Investment & Securities Co, said in Seoul last Wednesday.

Individuals have low confidence and are also reluctant to buy as Kospi has struggled to pass a resistance level at 2,050, Mr Kang said. The benchmark gauge has approached that level at least six times during the past two years before resuming declines, data compiled by Bloomberg show.

Finance Minister Hyun Oh Seok said last Wednesday that household spending is weak due to high levels of debt. Consumer confidence fell to the lowest level since April this month, according to the Bank of Korea. Home loans and credit extended to households increased 1.8 per cent in the second quarter to a record 980 trillion won, the monetary authority said on Aug 22.

Lee Won Tae plans to start selling his 40 million won of equity investments to repay debt before interest rates rise. The 42-year-old senior manager at CJ Systems Co, an information technology service provider, took out a 200 million won mortgage four years ago to buy a three-room apartment in Mokdong, an eastern Seoul neighbourhood known for its cram schools.

South Korea's central bank, which kept its benchmark interest rate at 2.5 per cent for a fourth straight month on Sept 12, will probably increase it to 3 per cent by the end of 2014, according to Goldman Sachs Group Inc.

"I'm eyeing a good time to exit," said Mr Lee, who earns about 100 million won a year and has two elementary school children. "I can barely support my family as I want my wife to take care of kids at home. Our budget will become much tighter as the kids grow."

Younger professionals are also exiting the stock market as rental costs rise. Kookmin Bank's index of lump-sum deposits used to pay rent in in Seoul, known as Jeonse, climbed to a record 102.5 in August, the highest level since the lender began tracking the data in 1986.

The average Jeonse rent for Seoul apartments has increased for 12 straight months to 280 million won as at August, according to the Korea Appraisal Board. - Bloomberg

site_title: Asian, Gulf banks fill gap in aircraft finance
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Asian, Gulf banks fill gap in aircraft finance

European lenders cut their exposure to aviation sector after the debt crisis

Published

Mon, Sep 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[DUBAI] Cash-rich Asian and Middle Eastern lenders are taking a larger share of the US$100 billion global aircraft financing market as Western rivals step back due to the liquidity crunch and stricter regulations, a top Airbus executive said.

European commercial banks, previously the primary funding source for airlines, have substantially cut their exposure to the aviation sector after the continent's debt crisis, leaving a funding gap for fast-growing airlines in emerging markets, said Francois Collet, vice-president for structured finance at Airbus.

"Some European lenders have halved their lending availability for the aviation sector," Mr Collet said. "They have tried to fill the gap by bringing in other regional and local banks and working together in syndicated deals. Traditional banks are now playing the role of arrangers."

French banks BNP Paribas, Societe Generale, Natixis and other European lenders said last year they would cut exposure to risky and dollar-denominated assets such as shipping and aircraft financing to meet tougher capital rules and shore up reserves.

They have given way to Asian banks such as Development Bank of Japan (DBJ), Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group Inc and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group Inc, South Korean and Chinese banks, as well as Middle Eastern lenders such as National Bank of Abu Dhabi, among others.

"We see South-east Asian banks developing expertise and there's lot of interest from Japan and South Korea gaining an interest in the sector," said Mr Collet. "They clearly want to grow outside of their region."

Asian giants such as Singapore Airlines, AirAsia, All Nippon Airways and Lion Air are among companies that have ordered planes worth billion of dollars to support growing passenger numbers.

Airbus has recently raised its 20-year jet demand forecast, saying the world needed to double its fleet to meet demand. The planemaker says Middle East plane orders account for 8 per cent of its total backlog as at end-August.

Emirates, which has the world's largest fleet of the A380 superjumbos, used a mixed bag of funding including bonds, operating leases, US export credit facilities and financing leases to raise US$5.5 billion in the current financial year.

"The challenge for airlines would be to diversify funding sources as growth comes back to the aviation industry," said Mr Collet.

Capital markets will also have a bigger role to play in aircraft financing - it will account for about 14 per cent of total jet financing in 2013, up from 10 per cent last year, Boeing said in an annual forecast in December.

Pension funds and insurance companies, which have traditionally stayed clear of aircraft finance, are also looking at the sector, attracted by reasonable stability and the long-term nature of the financing, said Mr Collet. - Reuters

site_title: Big drop in strata factory sales to-date
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Big drop in strata factory sales to-date

Published

Mon, Sep 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The number of strata-titled factory sales to date this year is just over half the number seen over the same period last year, a DTZ report showed, as government regulations and a Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR) framework took effect.

In its quarterly report on industrial property released yesterday, DTZ said that 1,553 strata factory units changed hands this year as at Sept 27, down 46 per cent from the 2,890 in the previous year.

"The fall in transactions suggests that speculative buying in the industrial sector has dimmed over the course of the year," said Lee Lay Keng, head of Singapore research at DTZ.

Investment demand for industrial properties has also calmed following the TDSR's implementation, with the process of obtaining property loans now "more onerous and lengthy".

A series of government measures, from a Seller Stamp Duty on industrial property introduced in January, to others such as releasing smaller sites with shorter leases and mandating the minimum size of industrial units, also took their toll.

Based on caveats data from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA), DTZ said that 353 resale transactions for strata-titled factories were recorded in Q3, nearly 50 per cent lower than the previous quarter.

The subdued industrial property activity in Q3 corresponded with industrial rents and capital values both staying flat over the previous quarter. DTZ's research showed that average gross rents for first and upper-storey conventional industrial space stayed at $2.15 per square foot per month (psf pm) and $1.75 psf pm respectively.

For hi-tech and business park developments, rents remained at $3.10 psf pm and $4.70 psf pm.

As for capital values, average resale prices for first-storey and upper-storey freehold conventional industrial space in Q3 were unchanged from the previous quarter, at $627 psf and $470 psf respectively.

Ms Lee said that the various government measures mean industrial property prices should "stabilise going forward", which will benefit genuine end-users who want to buy their own property to avoid rental fluctuations.

Many industrialists tend to prefer larger, single-user facilities that are more flexible for production layout, DTZ said. URA data shows that the net supply of single-user factories in the first half of 2013, at 4.3 million sq ft, is already 23 per cent higher than the entire supply last year.

There is also a trend of tie-ups between specialised firms and property players for purpose-built industrial space, DTZ said.

But the bulk of private industrial space to be completed next year will be warehouses and multiple-user factories, with a large proportion being strata-titled developments.

Between the second half of this year and 2014, some 64 per cent of a huge pipeline of 46 million sq ft of private industrial space expected to be ready by 2016 will come on stream.

site_title: Boeing's 787 hits fresh turbulence
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Boeing's 787 hits fresh turbulence

Published

Mon, Sep 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[PARIS] The brochure for Boeing Co's aircraft repair service makes a simple assertion: "No one knows Boeing airplanes better than Boeing."

Now that claim is being put to a visible test as budget airline Norwegian Air Shuttle ASA grounded a brand new, US$212 million 787 Dreamliner over the weekend. The airline demanded Boeing fix the state-of-the-art jet, saying it needs repairs after less than 30 days in service.

Investment analysts say the glitch involving a hydraulic pump is minor and isolated, and it is unlikely to affect Boeing's stock price, which is towering at record levels. But Norwegian Air's vocal airing of its complaints is another black eye for the troubled Dreamliner. It follows a string of electrical and other safety problems that included battery meltdowns so severe they prompted regulators to ban the long-haul jetliner from flight for more than three months this year.

On Sunday, Polish airline LOT 787 flying from Toronto to Warsaw was forced to land at Iceland's Keflavik airport after problems with its air system.

Norwegian Air's formal request on Saturday for Boeing to take charge of fixing the plane throws a spotlight on an often overlooked facet of the 787's performance: reliability. And it shows how quickly a plane that cannot fly can hit a carrier's bottom line.

Like other airlines with small long-haul fleets, Norwegian Air does not have a spare plane it can use if a jet breaks down. The carrier said it had to rent planes and cancel tickets when it could not use its 787s, and the company's stock has fallen 6 per cent since a peak earlier this month, hit by a string of 787 problems and concerns about its broader business.

"Reliability is a big deal, especially for low-cost carriers such as Norwegian," said Russell Solomon, an analyst at Moody's Investors Service in New York.

But since the problem appeared to be a "one-off" and part of the normal growing pains for a new plane, he added, it probably would not unsettle Boeing investors.

When Norwegian Air began long-haul operations this year, it aimed to capitalise on the Dreamliner's lower operating cost and the jet's promised 20 per cent savings on fuel burn.

But the first two Dreamliners, delivered recently and part of a planned fleet of eight, broke down more than half a dozen times in September, forcing Norwegian Air to lease back-up planes on short notice or cancel flights.

Norwegian Air grounded its 787s several times, citing problems with brakes, hydraulic pumps and power. On Sept 23, the carrier said one Dreamliner was beset with problems in the oxygen supply to the cockpit. A problem with a valve on the airline's second 787 was repaired around the same time, but only after delaying a flight from Oslo to New York.

Boeing said the repairs of the latest problem, to be carried out in Stockholm where the aircraft is parked, would take a matter of days. That is much better than with the 787's volatile battery system, which grounded the worldwide fleet of Dreamliners from January to April.

"Boeing has identified a number of specific improvements to address component reliability," the planemaker said.

The grounded planes have prompted Norwegian Air to voice its dissatisfaction with the aircraft. "The aircraft's reliability is simply not acceptable," the airline said on Saturday. "Our passengers cannot live with this kind of performance."

Saturday's announcement capped a tough week for Boeing in which Commercial Airplanes CEO Ray Conner flew to Oslo to face Norwegian Air bosses over the earlier 787 mishaps.

Like Norwegian Air, state-owned LOT has had a list of problems with its Dreamliners, including last week delaying flights after check-ups showed two planes lacked gas filters.

LOT also said last week Boeing had until the end of the year to agree on compensation for the three-month grounding of the 787 because of the battery issues, or it would take the matter to court. - Reuters

site_title: New rules to deter corruption in finance, procurement officers
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

New rules to deter corruption in finance, procurement officers

Those 'at risk' will be made to rotate jobs or take forced block leave

Lee U-Wen

Published

Mon, Sep 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] From Jan 1 next year, some public service officers will be forced to take on different jobs or made to go on block leave for a number of days.

Those affected may include those whose core responsibilities are related to finance or procurement, or who are in regulatory roles with a high risk of being suborned and exploited if they remained in the same job for too long, said the Public Service Division (PSD) yesterday.

Depending on the nature of their work, these officers will be subject to either one or both of the measures, it added.

The new rules - with the aim of reducing fraud and corruption - state that they should not serve in their present posts for a period of more than five years.

Some officers whose work is more transactional in nature will also have to go on block leave for at least five consecutive working days in every calendar year, said PSD.

Certain government agencies already practise job rotation for its officers deemed to be in positions that carry "a high risk of corruption". The Land Transport Authority, which has many frontline enforcement officers in its ranks, is just one example.

Several other agencies have also imposed block leave as a fraud prevention and deterrence measure, said PSD.

PSD also announced that, from today onwards, all public officers will need to declare within seven days whenever they visit the two local casinos - at Marina Bay Sands (MBS) and Resorts World Sentosa - more than four times a month, or if they purchase the $2,000 annual entry levy.

For certain groups of officers, the PSD said that even tighter rules will apply to them.

Those who are in more vulnerable positions where they could be suborned or exploited, or whose misconduct will have "significant reputational risk" to the public service, will have to declare every visit within seven calendar days.

Officers who enforce operations in the two casinos, or regulate the activities of or negotiate business arrangements with the casino operators will also be banned from visiting the casinos, unless they are doing so as part of their official duties.

PSD said it is now working with the various agencies on which officers need to be designated for the stricter casino visit rules.

In July this year, Head of Civil Service Peter Ong announced in a letter to all public servants that PSD would review the rules regarding visits to casinos here.

The review followed a slew of high-profile cases of misconduct by several senior public servants, such as the one involving a Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau officer who was charged for misappropriating $1.7 million and gambling a large sum of that away at the MBS casino.

site_title: A US shutdown would cause global tremors
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A US shutdown would cause global tremors

Published

Mon, Sep 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

THE United States government is just hours away from its first partial shutdown in 17 years after the weekend passed with lawmakers failing to reach a compromise on a formula to extend federal spending authority.

The impasse is proving a difficult one to break. House Republicans want to delay US President Barack Obama's landmark healthcare restructuring laws for a year and make other changes to the health laws. The president and the Democrats, meanwhile, have promised not to let that happen.

The consequences for failing to agree will invariably hit Americans hard. As things stand, if lawmakers blow the Monday midnight deadline in Washington (Tuesday noon, Singapore time), as many as 800,000 federal workers will be forced off their jobs without pay. Crucially, though, essential services such as border patrols, meat inspectors and air traffic control will continue, as well as Social Security and Medicare benefits.

Mr Obama hit the nail right on the head when he warned that a shutdown of the US government would risk destabilising the world economy. His message to Congress was a simple one: "Do not shut down the government. Do not shut down the economy. Pass a budget on time. Pay our bills on time."

Some economists have predicted that a shutdown could reduce fourth-quarter economic growth by up to 1.4 percentage points depending on how long it lasts. The biggest effect would come from the output lost from furloughed workers. The mounting concern over the fiscal negotiations sent the dollar to a seven-and-a-half month low last week, while the cost of insuring against a US debt default has soared to its highest levels since May this year.

More worryingly, the gridlock over the budget could be just a prelude to an even more serious showdown expected later this month over the government debt ceiling. Republicans have said that they will refuse to lift the ceiling unless the healthcare law - known as Obamacare - is reigned back, which could mean the US Treasury would be forced to default on its mounting debt payments.

Yet, it's difficult to see which side - Republican or Democrat - will blink first at this point, with neither wanting to be the one to cast the final vote that would lead to a shutdown. Some recent surveys show that the American public is already deeply unhappy with its leaders in Congress, and rightly so. The man on the street is tired of such political one-upmanship and opposed to a prolonged shutdown that would impact their daily lives.

The truth is, even if lawmakers somehow wriggle their way out of a shutdown or a default, some damage has already been done. With so much uncertainty about the US economy, there's little hope that businesses, both local and foreign, will want to invest and hire there anytime soon.

site_title: Civil service urged to build public trust
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Civil service urged to build public trust

Lee U-Wen

Published

Mon, Sep 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] One major factor that will determine whether the government succeeds in rolling out its policies is whether it has the trust of the citizens, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong yesterday.

Without this "basic trust" in place, none of the government's plans can ever be realised.

In his address to some 250 public service leaders at their annual planning seminar, he said it is important that Singaporeans trust that their government is committed to them, understand their needs and will remain a steward of the public good.

The public service, which employs some 136,000 people, has to work together to strengthen this trust as a single unit, "with Singaporeans at the centre of what they do and to uphold the highest standards of integrity".

Also at the event at the Institute of Technical Education headquarters in Ang Mo Kio were Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean, Head of Civil Service Peter Ong, permanent secretaries of government ministries and chief executives of statutory boards.

In a 30-minute speech, Mr Lee called on all public service leaders to understand what is happening on the ground and to be responsive in solving the problems that people or businesses face.

At the same time, however, they must uphold Singapore's national interests and the wider common good, and not get "captured" by special interest groups or by those they regulate.

"If the policy is not working, fix it. If the policy is painful but necessary, such as the tightening of foreign worker inflows for businesses, find ways to mitigate the downsides, communicate our intent and hold our ground on the core of the policies," said Mr Lee.

The key to getting things right is to implement policies well and translate them into specific programmes. Public-service leaders have to monitor results and trends in order to know when a change to the government's approach is necessary, he added.

Also important is for the public service to put forth a "seamless and coherent organisation" to the people. Mr Lee acknowledged that some members of the public have found it frustrating to have to deal with multiple agencies and conflicting policies; instances such as these would erode their trust in the public service over time.

Another way to maintain public trust is to uphold a high standard of integrity, which he said has been been "painstakingly" built up over many years.

That Singapore has a public service of integrity means businesses compete fairly instead of relying on improper influence, and public officers have the discretion and authority to exercise their judgment and knowledge when managing multi-million-dollar projects.

Singaporeans also know that the doors are open for them in life if they work hard, regardless of their family background or personal connections, said the prime minister.

He noted that there has been a string of high-profile corruption cases involving public officers, including those at senior levels, in the past year, and that the public sector accounts for about a fifth of all corruption cases here.

The public sector must strengthen its systems to uphold its reputation for integrity and incorruptibility, and dispel any doubts that standards have dropped, he said.

He added that every officer, and the public service as a whole, should take pride in being clean and incorrupt. He called on all public-sector leaders to take the lead in putting in place the right systems, enforce rules fairly and firmly and deal with mistakes decisively - tasks they should not delegate or leave to their subordinates.

site_title: Economists worry about impact of US govt shutdown
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Economists worry about impact of US govt shutdown

Published

Mon, Sep 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[WASHINGTON] A prolonged government shutdown - followed by a potential default on the federal debt - would have economic ripple effects far beyond Washington, upending financial markets, sending the unemployment rate higher and slowing already tepid growth, according to a wide range of economists.

A shutdown of a few days might do little damage, but economists, lawmakers and analysts are increasingly bracing for a shutdown that could last for a week or more, given the distance between the two political parties. Such an outcome will suck money out of the economy and spread anxiety among consumers and businesses in a way that is likely to hold back economic activity.

And a default on the federal debt, which may occur within 30 days without congressional action, would be much worse, economists say. Failing to raise the debt ceiling would require the government to cut spending by about a third, potentially forcing delays in Social Security cheques, military pay and payments to doctors.

There are other risks, too. On Oct 17, the Treasury is scheduled to ask investors for US$120 billion in loans. But if investors grow nervous about whether the United States will be able to pay them back, they are likely to demand higher interest rates, which would cause rates to spike throughout the financial system, leading to more expensive mortgages, auto loans and credit card bills. Doubt could grow about the safety of parking money in US bonds.

"It's corrosive on the economy," said Mark Zandi at Moody's Analytics. A lengthy shutdown followed by a default would be "the nightmare of the recession all over again". Even if lawmakers find a way out of a shutdown or a default, this crisis is likely to have negative effects on the economy. With so much uncertainty in Washington, economists say that businesses, flush with cash, have been reluctant to invest and hire.

Business interest groups, usually aligned with the Republicans, have urged the party to abandon their demand for policy concessions, such as delaying President Barack Obama's healthcare law, in exchange for funding the government and raising the debt limit.

Much of the government will close today without action by Congress. If the shutdown lasts more than a few days, it would affect the economy in numerous ways.

For example, the closure of national parks and museums may hurt hotels, restaurants and the people who work for them. The process of getting approval for a home loan could take much more time, slowing the housing recovery.

Economists estimate that the cumulative effect of a prolonged shutdown could trim economic growth in the final three months of the year by up to 1.4 percentage points. Under that scenario, the economy would hardly expand at all.

But economists are far more concerned about a potential default on the federal debt. The Treasury has warned that it will have only about US$30 billion in cash on hand by the middle of this month, and estimates are that it will run out of money by the end of the month. - WP

site_title: Consumers can register with DNC from Dec 2
content:
Consumers can register with DNC from Dec 2

While earlier registration cheers some, businesses eye registry's Jan 2 kickoff warily

Published Mon, Sep 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] A new early registration date for the Do Not Call (DNC) registry now cheerily beckons to consumers on Dec 2, even as firms of all sizes grimly figure out the impact of such a registry on the cost-and-compliance front.

From that date, consumers eager to give telemarketers the boot will be able to register their phone numbers to opt out of getting marketing messages by SMS, voice call and fax; messages that reach them through apps linked to phone numbers, such as WhatsApp, are also covered, though not for apps linked to email addresses.

Consumers may register through the DNC website, over SMS or by calling the registry's toll-free numbers.

content:
MAS accepts pro-consumer plans on financial advisory sector

Published Mon, Sep 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has come out on the side of the retail customer after accepting most of the recommendations of a panel it appointed last year to shake up the financial advisory industry.

One pro-consumer change to come next year is the launch of a free website for them to compare life insurance and endowment products across providers; another will require insurers to make basic life insurance products available directly to customers instead of through agents.

Following a public consultation, the MAS accepted 19 out of 28 recommendations made in January by the Financial Advisory Industry Review (FAIR) panel. Eight were modified and one, dropped.

content:
Bank lending growth continues to slow

Published Mon, Sep 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Growth in bank lending here continued to slow, according to numbers just released by the central bank, pointing to a generally sluggish third quarter for loans compared to the second quarter.

Domestic banking unit (DBU) loans to non-bank customers totalled $540.8 billion in August, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). This represents a 15.4 per cent year-on-year increase, compared with the 17.6 per cent rise recorded in July.

On a month-on-month basis, total lending inched up 0.3 per cent in August, compared to a 1.2 per cent increase in July.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

China Sky to appoint Baker Tilly as auditor

Earliest trading can resume is Feb 2014; shareholders put new share issue on hold

Published Mon, Sep 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

china sky chemical fibre

Follow

SHAREHOLDERS of suspended China Sky Chemical Fibre Co received long-sought after guidance on the company's operations and listing status, but remained cautious about management by withholding authority to issue new shares at a general meeting yesterday.

China Sky stock has been suspended since November 2011, when the maker of nylon products was directed by Singapore Exchange (SGX) to appoint a special auditor amid questions about a botched land acquisition in Fujian province, other acquisitions and a number of accounting line items.

After initially resisting the SGX directive, China Sky has since completed a special audit - which found severe lapses in corporate governance - and is now taking additional steps towards resuming trading. Shareholders yesterday approved the appointment of Baker Tilly TFW as auditor after previous auditor Deloitte & Touche resigned, and the company will work on auditing and reporting its financial results for fiscal 2011 through 2013.

DBS eyes growth in China as it enters FTZ

[SINGAPORE] Clinching a front-row seat in China's drive to reform its economy will significantly boost DBS Bank's business in the world's second-largest economy, bankers said yesterday, as the Singapore bank enters the newly established China (Shanghai) Pilot Free Trade Zone (FTZ).

DBS and Citibank were two foreign banks, along with eight domestic ones, to get approval on Sunday from the China Banking Regulatory Commission Shanghai Bureau to set up in the new FTZ.

The zone, which covers 29 square kilometres, "started operating" on Sunday, Xinhua news agency said, adding that it was "a test bed for the leadership's drive for deepening market-oriented reforms and boosting economic vigour". Restrictions on foreign investment will be eased inside the area, which will also loosen controls on 18 service sectors ranging from finance and shipping to cultural services.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Ezion plans restructuring to buy 45% stake in Ocean Sky

It plans to inject marine supply base ops into Ocean Sky

Published

Mon, Sep 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

OFFSHORE marine group Ezion Holdings (Ezion) yesterday announced a restructuring and expansion plan as it tabled a bid to buy 45.15 per cent of the enlarged share capital of mainboard-listed Ocean Sky International (Ocean Sky).

As part of the move, Ezion will also inject its marine supply base business in Australia, Ezion Offshore Logistics Hub (Tiwi), into Ocean Sky, which is an investment holding company with interests in the civil engineering and construction business, as well as the property investment and property management business.

Ezion has proposed to subscribe for 440 million new ordinary shares in the capital of Ocean Sky at the issue price of S$0.108 per subscription share, to be satisfied by the allotment and issuance of 20.21 million new Ezion shares to Ocean Sky.

In addition, the company is proposing to acquire 165 million share options, with each option carrying the right to subscribe for one new ordinary share in the capital of Ocean Sky at the exercise price of S$0.108 each.

Along with proposing to inject its marine supply base business into Ocean Sky, Ezion is planning to re-designate its existing chief operating officer (COO), Larry Glenn Johnson, as the new chief executive officer (CEO) cum executive director of Ocean Sky upon the successful conclusion of the acquisition. He will remain an executive director of Ezion.

Mr Johnson's position as COO of Ezion will be succeeded by his current deputy, Lee Kon Meng, who will be promoted and be fully responsible for the group's fleet operations covering liftboats and service rigs, and tug and barge operations.

"This acquisition will allow Ocean Sky International to have a dedicated management team for the group to capture new business opportunities in providing vital marine infrastructure in resource rich Australia while allowing Ezion to continue to focus on meeting the strong demand from clients of its existing business," Chew Thiam Keng, Ezion's CEO, said.

Ezion shares slid 7.17 per cent, or $0.17, in trading yesterday, closing at S$2.20.

SIA to fly to Athens for four months in 2014

Move is to capitalise on the peak summer travel season

[SINGAPORE] A year after suspending flights to the Greek capital, Singapore Airlines (SIA) yesterday said that it will temporarily offer flights to Athens between June and October next year to capitalise on the peak summer travel season.

"Singapore Airlines took the difficult decision to suspend year-round services to Athens in October 2012 after a prolonged period of challenging operating conditions," the airline said in a media statement released yesterday. At the time, it had also axed services to Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates due to sustained weakness on both routes. SIA had first launched flights to Athens back in 1972 before suspending the route last year, which it said at the time was in line with its policy to match capacity with market demand.

Flights from Singapore to Athens will be operated twice a week - on Mondays and Thursdays - using Boeing 777-200ER aircraft starting June 9, 2014 until Oct 9, 2014. SQ382 will depart from Singapore at 2.05am and arrive in Athens at 8.30am while SQ 381 will depart from Athens at 1pm and arrive at 4.55am the next morning in Singapore. Greece isn't the only country that SIA has renewed plans for.

site_title: Regulating 'get rich quick' seminars
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Regulating 'get rich quick' seminars

Published Mon, Sep 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

BT readers are not prolific letter writers but when they do send in their views for publication, they usually raise valid and important issues. Such was the case with the last missive that appeared in print "Scrutinise financial investment seminars too" on Sept 24 where reader Vincent Khoo makes a strong case for some form of regulation to be introduced to govern the dozens of "free" and paid investment seminars that are regularly advertised in the print and Internet media, particularly those that claim massive (sometimes guaranteed) profits in a short space of time.

The reasoning is that if financial advisers have to be licensed under the Securities and Futures Act (SFA) and are strictly limited in what they can say or sell to their clients, then so should those who conduct these "get rich quick" courses and seminars on trading commodities, property, stocks, currencies etc.

Granted, speakers at these events do not have a lasting relationship with the audience, at least not of the form that could be construed as being fiduciary, but as Mr Khoo correctly pointed out, a gullible public which pays thousands to attend and then stand to lose thousands after attendance because they think that can surely get rich should still be protected.

Mon, Sep 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Prices of small completed private apartments (up to 506 sq ft) climbed for the second month in a row to hit a new peak in August, according to the latest flash estimate from the National University of Singapore (NUS).

Market watchers agree that the data - the Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI) for small units rose one per cent in August, following a 2.1 per cent climb in July - suggests that buyers are gravitating towards smaller homes.

Given that the absolute quantum of these smaller format units are relatively affordable even after factoring in the effect of the Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR), it is not surprising that they are favoured by buyers and entry-point investors, said Donald Han, managing director of Chesterton Singapore.

The brisk sales witnessed at CapitaLand's Sky Vue attests to this. The development, which was launched the previous weekend, saw 410 of the 505 units released for sale snapped up on the first day. The most popular units were the one-bedroom and two-bedroom units; the average price of a one-bedroom unit was $750,000, while a two-bedroom unit averaged $933,000.

The TDSR framework, along with the other property cooling measures, has also shifted interest to the non-central region, given the lower price quantum, said Nicholas Mak, executive director, research and consultancy at SLP International.

The SPRI for Non-Central Region (excluding small units) rose one per cent, following a 0.4 per cent gain in July.

Conversely, the SPRI for Central Region (excluding small units) slipped 1.1 per cent, reversing a 0.4 per cent gain in July. Central Region is defined as districts 1-4 (including the financial district and Sentosa Cove) and the traditional prime districts 9,10 and 11.

The Overall SRPI was up 0.1 per cent in August, after gaining 0.4 per cent in July.

It is worth noting that overall prices have stayed relatively flat despite a sharp reduction in transaction volumes, said Lee Lay Keng, head of Singapore Research at DTZ.

Based on URA caveats, resale transactions of non-landed private homes fell 27 per cent month-on-month to 388 units in August from 529 units in July. This was the second-lowest monthly resale transaction volume since the beginning of the year; the lowest was in February, after the higher Additional Buyer's Stamp Duties (ABSD) and tighter financing restrictions were introduced.

"Despite the lower transaction volume, resale prices have generally held up as individual sellers in the secondary market have limited incentive to sell their properties unless they receive a premium as their replacement cost is now higher in lieu of the higher ABSD, especially if they are multiple property owners," said Ms Lee.

Moving forward, Chesterton Singapore's Mr Han said he expects prices in the Central area to ease further, although this will likely be compensated by a slight increase in prices in the suburban areas.

site_title: Solar-powered family car coming soon?
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Solar-powered family car coming soon?

The Dutch creation produces more power than it needs

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Fancy a sustainable, non-polluting family car that produces more energy than it uses which can be sold back to the power grid?

Such an energy-positive vehicle could come on the market if the students at Eindhoven University of Technology can find a manufacturer to produce their solar-powered four-seater car, which won a gold medal at the World Solar Challenge in Australia.

One-and-a-half years ago, the Solar Team Eindhoven from the Netherlands wondered if there was an alternative to the electric car which was just as silent and emission-free but with a much longer range than the usual 180 to 200 km. They came up with the solar-powered family car.

Until then, solar-powered vehicles were mostly built for speed rather than comfort, with a solar panelled wing atop a small and cramped cabin. So the Solar Team Eindhoven came up with Stella. It has a carbon fibre body and a long sloping roof of solar panels. In the low cabin, there are four individual seats and a tunnel running through the centre filled with 65 kg of lithium-ion battery cells.

"The Netherlands is not famous for sunshine but rain and wind," said the Dutch ambassador to Singapore, Jacques Werner, at an event at the Nanyang Polytechnic yesterday to introduce Stella.

Yet Stella was able to soak up enough sunlight to travel 70 km, or nearly twice as much as the Dutch person's average daily commute of 38 km.

That is because it works in cloudy conditions too. The solar panels do not need to catch direct sunlight; all it requires is enough diffused light.

Stella can also be fully recharged by plugging it into a household socket for six to eight hours.

On a full charge, it has a range of 450 km. If it is travelling in bright sunshine, it can go almost twice as far. Two in-wheel motors power the front wheels and the 380 kg car can carry four people weighing 80 kg each.

During the six-day, 3,000 km race across the Australian outback last month, Stella clocked an average speed of 67 kilometres an hour with three people on board.

Stella was built by 22 students over one year with the help of various sponsors, one of which is NXP Semiconductors. NXP also provided car-to-car communications to transfer data from Stella to the mission control car in order to optimise car performance and ensure smooth running under all road conditions.

"Stella's performance during the World Solar Challenge 2013 demonstrated the feasibility and appeal of solar-powered cars, and can help the automotive industry define a new category of cars for the near future," said Karsten Penno, NXP's regional sales and marketing director.

site_title: Blue chips shield market amid penny storm
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Blue chips shield market amid penny storm

Total market cap of Singapore companies falls just 0.4% in October

Published

Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

THE value of Singapore-listed shares stayed mostly flat in October, but a closer look reveals a tale of two markets with battered penny stocks on the one hand and resilient large caps on the other.

"I guess generally the blue chips saved the day," DMG & Partners head of research Terence Wong said.

The total market capitalisation of Singapore-listed companies dipped 0.4 per cent month on month to $913.2 billion in October, data compiled by The Business Times showed. Compared with a year earlier, however, total market cap was up 7 per cent.

Smaller companies bore the brunt of any decline. The FTSE ST Small Cap Index fell 5.9 per cent during the month to 537.84 yesterday. In contrast, the large cap-dominated Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1.4 per cent to close at 3,210.67 over the same period.

The source of October's penny pounding can be traced to just three companies which saw sudden price collapses on Oct 4, triggering a series of rare market intervention measures by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and setting off widespread selling among other penny counters.

Blumont Group, Asiasons Capital and LionGold Corp, in which regulators are reviewing the trading of their shares, saw $10.4 billion, or about 94 per cent, of their combined market value wiped out during the month. That was more than the $3.9 billion month-on-month decline in total market value.

Those three stocks are penny counters now, but one month ago they were members of the billion-dollar club, which now has three fewer members at 112.

Mr Wong reckoned that the penny sell-down may actually present an opportunity for bargain hunting.

"There's a bit of indiscriminate selling," he said. "So investors should really hunker down and look for good-quality companies, and you shouldn't have to wait too long for quick gains in some of them."

Overall, Mr Wong thought that macroeconomic conditions also appear to be supportive of stronger equity markets.

"If you look at China, Europe, things are really, really not as bad as what they thought," he said.

DMG prefers the offshore marine, discretionary consumer and construction sectors, and is neutral on property, technology manufacturers and consumer staples.

Voyage Research analyst Ng Kian Teck, however, was not as certain that Singapore's penny stocks will recover that quickly, citing a significant amount of uncertainty and wariness still in the market about how SGX determines when to intervene.

"Investors are still waiting," Mr Ng said. "They want to hear more from SGX ... They want to know what SGX considers fair, orderly and transparent, and that question mark will keep people from the market."

Nevertheless, Voyage expects the blue chips to sail along smoothly, with the STI inching higher to test 3,260. For the rest of the year, it also expects a quieter market with the holidays approaching.

site_title: Debunking myths and exposing lies
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Debunking myths and exposing lies

Published

Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

IT took grit and gumption to spend 12 years of their lives researching the lesser-known facts about Communist revolutionary Mao Zedong. But the struggles of Chinese author Jung Chang and her British husband Jon Halliday did not end when they published Mao: The Unknown Story (2005).

The book attracted heavy criticism from the Chinese because it did not recount the "official" version of Mao's life story. It showed Mao in less than favourable light - in fact, as a tyrannical leader concerned only with gaining power for himself.

"After the Mao book was published, there was a book titled Was Mao Really A Monster? published in response to ours. It collected various book reviews attacking us for showing Mao to be a monster, even though we didn't actually use the word. But what can I do? I'm not going to reply to these ill-informed people who are just making assertions," Chang says.

Just as her family's biography, Wild Swans (1991) was banned in mainland China, so was Mao: The Unknown Story. However, both books have been translated into over 40 languages and sold more than 15 million copies around the world.

Notably, none of her critics have been able to point out a single factual error in her books, which is why Chang continues to dismiss what they say.

She explains that her process of ensuring accuracy involves tediously checking and cross-checking facts in original documents in historical archives without relying on secondary sources.

"Still, I don't like attacks," she says over the phone from her home in London. "I actually don't relish controversy; I'm merely interested in what I'm interested in, and that's to say something new that other people haven't said."

Chang reveals that she is in the middle of translating her most recently released book from English to Chinese - another controversial biography that shows the positive side of the Empress Dowager Cixi, who has always been portrayed as a villain in Chinese history.

Next Monday at the Singapore Writers Festival, Chang will discuss her works during her lecture, Utopia, Mao and The Empress Dowager Cixi.

"Mao and the Empress Dowager are both riveting subjects. I think the process of decision-making and policy-making is very interesting. I like to understand how they made decisions that concerned a quarter of the world's population," says Chang.

Her interest in the Empress Dowager was piqued when she was carrying out the research for Wild Swans. She learnt that her grandmother was once a victim of China's foot-binding practices, which were abolished by the Empress Dowager at the beginning of the 20th century, and not by the Communist Party.

She says, with a hint of pride: "I get tremendous satisfaction debunking myths and exposing lies. I want to do historical detective work . . . so it's great fun writing about controversial people. I don't want to write about someone whom everybody has been saying the same thing about. I think that's just boring. I want to open new paths, and when you break new ground, inevitably you're going to be controversial."

Chang will deliver a lecture titled "Utopia, Mao and the Empress Dowager Cixi" on Nov 4 from 7.30pm to 8.30pm at The Salon at the National Museum of Singapore. This event is not included in the festival pass, and tickets cost $15.

site_title: Food and spices become her art
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Food and spices become her art

Published

Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

WHEN a chef visits a spice market, he gets ideas about what he'd like to cook. When Korean artist Haegue Yang visited Little India for the first time and saw the rich variety of ingredients, she decided to turn them into art.

Ganthoda powder, dry mango powder, da huang powder and even Nigella powder - no relation to Nigella Lawson - were among the unusual looking and sounding spices that provided Yang with the starting point for her artist residency at the Singapore Tyler Print Institute (STPI).

The STPI exhibition features frames of "spice moons" - circles of spices whose rough textures and earthy hues evoke your sense of sight, smell, taste and touch, even though the circles are encased in their glass frames.

Yang, who represented South Korea at the Venice Biennale in 2009, says that she's interested in "humble, everyday objects, like food and spices".

"They are so much a part of our lives that we forget what they reveal about our country's history, culture and tradition. As an artist, I want to turn the commonplace into something sublime."

Her interest in Singapore's food and spices reflects a larger concern with issues of migration, diaspora, assimilation and displacement.

Yang migrated to Germany in 1994 to further her studies after graduating from Seoul National University with a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree. She has been based there ever since and creates some of her most captivating large-scale installations in her second home.

For her residency in Singapore, she departed from making threedimensional installations to create two-dimensional art using paper. Even so, the rough textures of the moon spices and the beautifully textured paper works that were created by pressing food items onto paper pulp betray her predilections.

Other works such as a series of squares bearing the names of spices written using the very spice and in the font type found on the spice packaging illustrate Yang's sense of humour.

There is even, mischievously enough, a series of sheets featuring the various brands of instant noodles found here.

Yang says, with a twinkle in her eye: "I've titled the exhibition Honesty Printed on Modesty because there is a sense of modesty and intimacy in working with paper . . . But that said, I do think I'm communicating intimately with the audience even when I'm making a large-scale installation.

"After all, what is art but an attempt to make yourself vulnerable and reach out to someone in an intimate way?"

Haegue Yang's exhibition is on at the Singapore Tyler Print Institute, 41 Robertson Quay, until Nov 23, from 10am to 6pm (Tuesdays to Saturdays). Open on Mondays by appointment only and closed on Sundays. Admission is free.

site_title: Brad Little stands tall in musical theatre scene
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Brad Little stands tall in musical theatre scene

Playing a popular stage role - the Phantom - nearly 2,400 times is remarkable, says GEOFFREY EU

Published

Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

IT'S not his main mission in life or anything, but Brad Little stands tall in the annals of musical theatre as one among a select group of performers who have played a popular stage role close to 2,400 times - that's more than six-and-a-half years - and counting. The fact that the part in question - The Phantom of the Opera - is arguably the most famous character in Broadway history makes Little's achievement all the more remarkable.

"I cherish it," says Little, 49, about the defining role of his career. "I'm no longer a spring chicken and I'll eventually come to the end of doing leading man-type characters."

The Phantom is special to Little for many reasons, but especially because it helps people - himself included - to address their insecurities.

"We all have insecurities - mine is dyslexia - and the character of the Phantom gives hope," says Little in a recent telephone interview. "The Phantom has made them not feel alone, and unlike any other show, it is therapy for so many people."

He adds: "I cried when, at age 24, I saw Michael Crawford (the original Phantom) perform. I thought of my dyslexia - here's a musical character that is letting me go to a place I've never gone to before."

It eventually led to a starring role - one that he has performed numerous times before on Broadway and also as a member of productions that have toured the world, including Singapore and other parts of Asia. This weekend, Little will be the headline performer in The Phantom Unmasked, a musical programme at Marina Bay Sands that will include songs from many Broadway shows.

"It's a musical theatre concert but it won't just be Phantom, it will be Brad Little - I hope the audience will embrace that side of me and see the man behind the mask," he says.

Although he is pretty nifty on his feet, he has never showcased his dancing skills. "I stopped dancing because they were giving the lead to the guy that didn't dance so well."

"Phantom is a show that has everything, but it's also just a visual spectacle that transports you to a fantasyland," says Little, who was born in Redlands, California and grew up with the theatre as his playground - his father was a theatre professor and his mother taught the piano.

"I caught the theatre bug when I was very young and I did go through some rebellious teenage years when I wanted to become a basketball player - but my jump shot is not as good as my high note."

Little describes his singing voice as a high baritone. "I have the warmth of a baritone along with the low tenor notes. "When I was young I wanted to be Robert Goulet, until my voice teacher told me, 'You are no Robert Goulet - you can do more.'"

Among many other roles, Little went on to play the leads in the Phantom, Jesus Christ Superstar and Oklahoma!

Little left California for New York when he was 19 and for most of the past 30 years, has been gainfully employed, doing what he loves. "I was very fortunate to be an actor, and not waiting tables," he says. He tried out for some television and movie roles, but they never panned out.

He will continue to tour with the Phantom over the next 18 months but he is also spending a lot of time in South Korea, where he is planning to start a musical theatre school and a production team to put on Western musicals. "Next to Japan, Korea is the most advanced in Asia in putting together their own musicals," says Little.

Right now, the theatre scene there is stagnant and there is a lot to be desired in terms of quality, he says. He says that some of the productions he's seen in Asia are "criminal and embarrassing - promising something to the audience that is not brought to the stage". "Audiences are being fooled by sloppiness in theatre and there's so much that's missing to take it to the next level. Don't just do choreography for movement's sake, there has to be a story as well - let's get back to the storytelling."

The Phantom Unmasked, featuring Brad Little with Shoshana Bean, is on at the Mastercard Theatres, Marina Bay Sands, tonight and tomorrow night. Tickets at $95-175. For more information, call 6688-8826 or go to

www.MarinaBaySands.com

site_title: A new generation, but the same traditions
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A new generation, but the same traditions

At Domaine Faiveley, the new head is also aiming higher, says NK YONG

Published

Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

WINE is about people. Perhaps nowhere is this better illustrated than in the Domaines of Burgundy where personal commitment by succeeding generations to the honour, reputation and integrity of the House ensures its continued success and fame. And who else better to entrust this critical responsibility to than the next generation.

You can certainly hire someone suitably qualified and with the required competence and ability to take over, but it will not be the same as having your children take over. The personal commitment of an employee, however dedicated, would not be the same. Thus, in recent years I have been increasingly received at the Domaines by the next generation, sons or daughters or both, whose fathers had received me when I first visited in 1986.

At Domaine Drouhin, it is now Veronique or Frederic, Robert Drouhin's children, at Domaine Louis Jadot by Andre Gagey's son Pierre-Henry, and at Domaine Faiveley by Francois Faiveley's son Erwan, who took over in 2007. (Francois himself is the sixth in line from the Francois Faiveley who founded the company in 1825.)

Faiveley, like Jadot and Drouhin, is both Domaine and negoce, and like them it is the Domaine part that dominates and sets the reputation of the house.

Their vineyard holdings are extensive, 37.21 hectares of vineyards in the Cote d'Or and a further 82 ha in the Cote Chalonnaise. These vineyard holdings supply 80 per cent of their requirements, allowing them to personally oversee and guarantee the quality of every bottle they produce.

The harvest was more or less over when Erwan received us last month in the old home of the Domaine in Nuits-Saint-Georges. The Domaine's office in the small building on the rue de Tribourg belies its importance and gives no indication of the presence below ground of its extensive cellars. He led us further down the road to the new chais and cellars, where they were busy dealing with the just-completed harvest.

Erwan has great plans for Domaine Faiveley. This was obvious from his excitement as he outlined his plans for the expansion and enhancement of the building planned for completion within the next few years.

The next generation not only secures the Domaine's reputation but clearly aims higher! Which is as it should be. (I would also want that my children do better than I have!) I am already looking forward to visiting the extended and improved new home of Faiveley a few years down the road.

Tasting notes 2012 vintage

Gevrey-Chambertin 1er cru Cazetiers 2.05 ha

Great vibrant colour, very good ripeness, with great freshness and appeal. Good length. Excellent.

Nuits-Saint-Georges 1er cru Les Porets St-Georges 1.69 ha

Even riper, very very ripe, packed with fruit. Good balance, acidity and length. Quite lush for a Nuits.

Clos Vougeot Grand Cru 1.29 ha

Very dark red, with very attractive ripe pinot fruit bouquet; quite soft rounded body, very ripe fruit with good density, making it very approachable. At this stage seems to lack some finesse and balance, finishing a little short, but quite one of the best Clos Vougeot I have ever tasted, almost seductive. A must-buy!

Charmes Chambertin Grand Cru

Good ripe fruit and concentration, medium length.

Latricieres-Chambertin 1.21 ha

This is very good. Has very good freshness and density of fruit, has power and concentration. Very impressive.

Mazis-Chambertin 1.3 ha

Very different from the Latricieres. Very good, good complexity and length. Has more charm at this stage than the Latricieres.

Chambertin Clos de Beze 1.29 ha

Not tasting well at this point. Good but has overlay of vanillin and coconut flavours. Not well integrated. Would be good to see this much later.

Chambertin Clos de Beze, Oeuvres Rodin

This is from a different plot which contains old (60 to 70-year old) vines. This is very, very special. Has good weight, great richness, well-balanced and very good complexity. Since 2010 vintage this wine has been bottled separately as Chambertin Clos de Beze "Oeuvres Rodin". Look out for this!

Corton Clos des Corton Faiveley Grand Cru 3.02 ha (Monopole)

This is a very special plot in the Corton appellation.

This is very lovely and has everything - great ripeness, freshness, complexity, and very long finish. A great wine and a very, very lovely drink. Another wine to look out for.

A very enjoyable tasting of a very successful vintage for Domaine Faiveley with some great wines. A vintage to look forward to, a must-buy vintage and to cellar!

Observations

I have been tasting (and drinking) Faiveley's wines from barrel to finished wine over the past 25 years, and have noted that they need at least 10 years to reach anywhere near maturity. Before that they tend to be so reserved that they appear even austere. They remain closed for a long time.

A recent example well exemplified that. A 1989 Clos des Corton drank in March last year was still not quite ready - backward and reserved.

A few years ago, in 2007, I was tasting in the cellars with Bernard Hervet, who had just joined the firm as managing director while Erwan was still away completing his studies. It struck me from the first few samples that there was a change in the style of the wines.

They were certainly not as austere and reserved as I remembered of past barrel tastings, and actually appeared to be more user-friendly. Subsequent tastings both in the Domaine's cellars and in the tasting of a new vintage held locally last year reinforced this impression.

It is a well-known observation that fine wines reflect the personality of the wine-maker.

My early tastings of Faiveley's wines took place while Francois Faiveley, Erwan's father, was in charge. Francois is by nature reserved. He relaxes and warms up when he gets to know you better. Erwan is the opposite - he is more sunny and more outgoing. He almost bubbles over in his enthusiasm and eagerness to "get up and go".

It is clear that he loves what he is doing, that he is 200 per cent at his job making wine, the best wine in his world! I look forward to further tastings with him.

What emerges then is that Faiveley's wines from vintage 2008 onwards will be ready for drinking much earlier than earlier vintages. Great! Thank you, Erwan.

site_title: Jobless rate at lowest since last Dec
content:
Jobless rate at lowest since last Dec

Fewer layoffs in Q3; strong showing by services and construction sectors despite slowdown from Q2

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The jobless rate surprisingly fell to 1.8 per cent in September - the lowest level since last December - as layoffs subsided in the third quarter, preliminary official figures released yesterday showed.

Employment growth remained strong, driven mainly by the services and construction sectors, despite slowing from the previous quarter.

Private sector economists had expected the unemployment rate to stay unchanged in September from June's 2.1 per cent, a tight labour market notwithstanding.

Citigroup's Kit Wei Zheng said the dip in the jobless rate in September reflected the latest round of tightening of the foreign worker policy that kicked in on July 1, as well as a "correction" of the unexpected rise in the jobless rate in June despite a strong sequential expansion in gross domestic product (GDP) in Q2.

"We note that the unemployment rate has corrected to 1.8 per cent - below even the Q1 rate," he said.

Mr Kit suspected there was "lagged hiring after the Q2 surge in activity", which was intensified by the shedding of foreign workers that forced employers "to draw down the resident labour force to meet their labour needs".

Added OCBC Bank's Selena Ling: "Basically, the labour force participation rate is improving, but overall domestic labour market tightness is still prevalent under the current environment of foreign manpower curbs."

Noting that the low unemployment reflected strong manpower demand, the Ministry of Manpower (MOM), which released the tentative labour figures in its Employment Situation Third Quarter 2013 report, said the seasonally adjusted jobless rate for residents (citizens and permanent residents) dipped to 2.6 per cent in September from 2.9 per cent in June.

The unemployment rate for Singapore citizens slipped from 3.1 per cent to 2.8 per cent between June and September.

"An estimated 48,300 residents, including 43,400 Singapore citizens, were unemployed in September 2013," the report revealed. "The seasonally adjusted figures were 56,000 for residents and 50,300 for citizens, down from 63,200 and 55,700 respectively a quarter ago."

While jobs growth slowed to 28,100 jobs in Q3 from 33,700 jobs in Q2, Ms Ling said this could stem from "a combination of both shortage in manpower (that is, constrained labour supply) rather than (being) solely due to a moderation in economic or business activities".

Total employment rose to 3,448,300 in September, up 4.1 per cent from a year ago.

The construction and services sectors were the main engines of job growth in Q3, adding 10,600 and 14,000 jobs, respectively. There were more new construction jobs than Q2's 8,500, but fewer new services positions compared with the previous quarter's 22,700.

Manufacturing created 3,000 jobs in Q3, up from 2,300 jobs in Q2, marking the second quarter of improvement since the drop in Q1 (minus 1,200 jobs).

Redundancies fell to 2,600 workers in Q3, down from 3,080 in Q2. This offset a doubling in the early release of contract workers to 500 - the highest level since Q3 2011. The fewer layoffs were due to manufacturing redundancies falling to 1,000 in Q3 from 1,630 in Q2.

The number of construction workers axed jumped from 250 to 300 over the two quarters, while workers laid off in the services sector rose from 1,200 to 1,300.

site_title: Litigator and author Adrian Tan joins Stamford Law
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Litigator and author Adrian Tan joins Stamford Law

He's leaving Drew & Napier after spending 21 years there

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Well-known litigation lawyer, author and humorist Adrian Tan, 47, has left Drew & Napier - the Big Four firm he has called home since he was a pupil - to join Stamford Law, a boutique legal practice set up by one of Singapore's most prominent corporate lawyers, Lee Suet Fern.

It's a move that has taken those who know Mr Tan by surprise, and it's no doubt news that would surprise the rest of the legal fraternity.

Mr Tan is known for being on such high-profile cases as that of Singapore Press Holdings, which he represented, versus the National Kidney Foundation in 2005. More recently, he argued for a teenager and his father when they sued Credit Suisse over trading losses, and he also represented the owner of Sijori Resort Club in a class-action suit filed by over 200 former members.

Those who grew up in the 1980s will also remember him as the author of the wildly popular and best-selling The Teenage Textbook (which was later made into a movie and also a stage play) and its sequel, The Teenage Workbook.

When asked why he would leave the reliable familiarity of one of the country's best law firms, Mr Tan admitted to The Business Times that it was not an easy decision: "I spent 21 years in Drew & Napier. I joined as a pupil and I'm leaving as a partner. I learnt from the very best of senior counsel, Davinder Singh. It is a wrench to leave. I feel like a blushing bride leaving her home to join her new family."

But, he adds: "I'm very attracted to Stamford. It's a Singapore law firm that hires international lawyers. It's boldly going toe to toe with foreign firms. It's showing other Singapore firms how to thrive in the new environment - where young Singapore lawyers now have the choice of working for Singapore law firms or international ones, and consumers have more choice in the market."

The attraction runs both ways. Stamford Law's senior director Mrs Lee says: "Adrian will, in the first instance, strongly enhance our litigation capabilities.

"He is an able, unusual and outstanding lawyer. He represents a broad swathe of clients in their key corporate challenges and concerns. He has the ability to be powerful and persuasive for them, to be their strong advocate.

"But he is much more than a very good lawyer. He has numerous skills, talents and interests outside - as a writer, a humorist, a speaker. He also has a strong sense of service to the community which I admire (Mr Tan also serves on the Law Society of Singapore and is the pro-bono legal adviser to the Singapore Association for the Visually Handicapped)," she adds.

The admiration is shared by others in the profession. Senior Counsel Thio Shen Yi, joint managing partner of TSMP Law Corporation, said: "Stamford is one of the leading corporate practices in town. The addition of Adrian to the disputes practice should significantly increase their bench strength in this area. He's a capable guy and well respected by the fraternity."

Influential American lawyer Richard L Cassin, a best-selling author on international law, who now runs the FCPA (Foreign Corrupt Practices Act) Blog, said: "Adrian is smart, creative and humble - a great combination in a lawyer and a friend.

"The best lawyers are those who really want to help their clients. It's not a trait you can learn in school or measure in someone. But you know it when you see it. And Adrian has it," Mr Cassin added.

No encounter with Mr Tan is ever complete without his trademark wit. When asked what he believes he will bring to Stamford Law, starting from his first day on the job today, he quipped: "Stamford is a force in corporate law. I am a litigator. The synergy is obvious."

And the first task he'll tackle? "For two decades, I've been standing up in court as a Drew & Napier litigator. My first order of business is to practice introducing myself as 'Adrian Tan from Stamford Law'."

site_title: Grand Banks sets profit course to exit SGX watch-list
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Grand Banks sets profit course to exit SGX watch-list

Yacht maker has applied for deadline extension to meet requirements

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

GRAND Banks Yachts, in choppy waters with the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for almost two years, is now on course to calmer seas.

The Singapore-based manufacturer of luxury motor yachts, which has been placed by SGX on its watch-list, has made significant progress in meeting the criteria set by the regulator to be taken off this list.

On the list since Dec 5, 2011, Grand Banks was told that it had to meet the criteria of $40 million in market capitalisation and achieve pre-tax profits within a two-year deadline or face delistment.

On market capitalisation, the group recently completed a rights issue of one rights share for every two shares held, which raised $12.3 million in net proceeds from the issue of 57.7 million new shares at $0.22 each. This enlarged Grand Banks' share capital base to 173 million shares and increased its market capitalisation to $38 million.

Peter Poli, acting CEO of Grand Banks, told reporters at a press briefing yesterday that with the rights issue, the group was less worried about being able to meet the market capitalisation requirement of $40 million. "We are almost there, (as) we have 173 million shares now. To get to $40 million, we need a price of about $0.23 a share. If we continue to improve performance, the market will recognise that and we will be fine." Grand Banks' share price closed at $0.225 at the end of trading yesterday, reflecting a gain of $0.005 or 2.27 per cent.

The greater challenge will be in achieving profitability, acknowledged Mr Poli, as he noted that, that in itself, will already have a positive impact on share price and thus, market capitalisation. In its first quarter results released earlier this week, the group reported a net loss of $579,000, 60 per cent down from a year ago. Loss from operations was 68 per cent lower at $405,000. Revenue climbed 46.3 per cent to $9.5 million. It also achieved operating cash flow of $0.6 million, against a negative $1.7 million last year.

The improvement in its first-quarter performance was due to the recovery in the US luxury boat market and response to its new models, as it noted that its business in Europe had been on the decline as the eurozone crisis had led to more prudent consumption there as well as governments there showing more uncertainty on tax regulations. Business in the Asia-Pacific was also on the rise with the region now accounting for about 20 per cent of the group's sales.

The group's order book stands at $14.2 million and this includes six new orders that it recently clinched, which are mostly due in the third quarter and will bring in about $7.5 million of cash flow. It is also due to deliver two more boats to dealers in Japan and Australia in the next 30 days, which will bring in about $2.5 million of cash flow.

Grand Banks is hoping to increase sales by participating in the largest boat show globally at Fort Lauderdale over this weekend and the group admitted that it will also look into making acquisitions in the future to create a critical mass. While the utilisation rate of its sole yard in Johor Bahru has improved, leading to higher gross margins, it noted that it may sub-lease its excess capacity there should the opportunity arise.

The group has applied to the exchange for an extension of time beyond Dec 5 this year for it to meet the criteria for removal from the watch-list and is awaiting SGX's response.

Soilbuild posts 13% rise in Q3 earnings

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

SOILBUILD Construction Group's third-quarter net profit rose 13 per cent year on year to $6.32 million, on the back of healthy progress in its construction projects.

Executive director Ho Toon Bah said: "While industry-wide challenges such as rising labour costs and constraints are inevitable, we are pleased to say that our ability to execute our projects efficiently and effectively has led to another quarter of commendable results. This marks nine months of continuous growth for the group."

New construction projects helped its July-September turnover rise 44 per cent to $84.54 million in the reporting quarter. The projects include a mixed-used development at Lavender, an HDB project in Tampines, a research and development building at Changi Business Park, and a ramp-up industrial development at Mandai Link.

However, gross profit margin slipped 1.7 percentage points to 11.2 per cent as it had completed projects that contributed higher margins. Earnings per share (EPS) for Q3 was 0.95 cent, down from 1.13 cents a year ago.

Nine-month profit came in at $15.93 million, a 42 per cent rise from a year ago, on the back of an 81 per cent leap in turnover to $220.53 million, while gross profit margin fell three percentage points to 10 per cent. Nine-month EPS were 2.76 cents, up from 2.25 cents.

Looking ahead, Soilbuild said it is well-positioned to pursue new tender opportunities in the local market, which it expects will remain positive for the near future.

As at Sept 30, the group's order book stood at $442 million, with projects expected to be completed substantially in the next 12 to 24 months.

Soilbuild's shares ended trading unchanged at 26 cents yesterday.
