site_title: Muddy Waters: Game over for Olam if Temasek pulls out
content:
Muddy Waters: Game over for Olam if Temasek pulls out

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Almost a year after it first released its report on Olam International, shortselling research firm Muddy Waters is not letting up on the agri-commodities trader yet.

"My view is that if Temasek decides tomorrow that it wanted out of this investment, it would be game over within months for them, without Temasek's backstop," its research director Carson Block told The Business Times in his first visit to Singapore since launching its report against Olam last November.

"For us, the be-all and end-all when we're looking at Olam is free cashflow. It's a company that seems to be in general wholly-incapable of generating free cash flow. It takes on more and more debt, and eventually, this debt has to be repaid."

The shortseller had late last year accused Olam of relying on accounting tricks to boost its bottomline, spending too much on poor quality assets, and said it valued Olam on a "liquidation basis".

The attack, the first of its kind in Singapore, caused Olam's shares to fall 20 per cent to a low of $1.395 at the height of the saga, and subsequently led to an overhaul of Olam's plans after a strategic review.

The firm said that it now aims to be free cashflow positive from the 2014 financial year onwards, a year earlier than its original target of FY2015, and has laid out plans to cut planned capital expenditure, monetise its balance sheet and divest certain assets.

Mr Block said of these: "The company's saying the right things. The question is whether it actually does those things. It might have become slightly more selective, but you still see substantial cash burn in the company."

"Maybe they can finance their way out of it, however many more times, but there will come a day - it might be sooner, it might be later - when the market will not be open to this company."

In August, Olam reported a negative free cashflow of $316 million for the 2013 financial year, compared with negative $661 million a year before.

Olam's net gearing now stands at 1.93 times, as compared to 2.20 times the previous quarter, and 1.81 times at the end of FY2012.

When asked if Muddy Waters still retains a short position on the firm, Mr Block said it does not usually comment on its positions aside from the release of its reports.

But in a hint that Muddy Waters is still short on Olam, he added: "Obviously we're usually used to winning within a shorter period of time. Fortunately for many of the names we've shorted in the past, we haven't really had to think to answer that question. Olam is different."

Shares for Olam, and Muddy Waters' target after that, US cellphone antenna operator American Towers, had not dropped as much as the shortseller's earlier targets, leading to talk that its influence has faded.

In a sign that its streak of lacklustre results is ending, however, Muddy Waters' latest report launched last Thursday against Chinese mobile services provider NQ Mobile led to its shares falling more than 60 per cent within an hour.

Temasek moving into the ring to support Olam was a move that the shortseller had not foreseen, Mr Block admitted.

"We looked at it from a purely economic standpoint, which is that it is not an investible company, and maybe we ignored the political elements of this, the psychological element, the issues that were more systemic in Singapore that could interest a sovereign in a bailout," he said.

Two weeks after Muddy Waters spoke out against Olam, Temasek, then the firm's second-largest shareholder, threw its weight behind Olam by agreeing not just to take up its pro-rata entitlement of Olam's US$1.25 billion bonds-cum-warrants rights issue, but also sub-underwrite it. The issue was eventually 1.1 times subscribed.

Temasek has also since then progressively increased its ownership of Olam, from an initial 16.3 per cent before the Muddy Waters attack to 24.07 per cent now.

In Mr Block's view, Temasek had stepped in because of the wider implications that an Olam collapse would have posed to the commodity-trading industry in Singapore.

"If Olam had failed, what would the banks have done with the other commodity houses that are borrowing in Singapore?" he said. "It's reasonable to assume that if the banks had to write off losses to Olam, you could have a real funding freeze for the commodity trading industry in Singapore. "

Temasek's spokesman Stephen Forshaw said the Singapore investment company's reason for investing in Olam remained the same: "We have been, and remain, supportive of its publicly known strategy to take the opportunity, in recent years, to add on more upstream and midstream capabilities and capacities.

"We also acknowledged that no business is without risks. But that said, at the time of the investment, we were comfortable with Olam's credit position and longer term prospects, and were very pleased to have another opportunity to invest in the company, alongside others."

Good Class Bungalow market starts to thaw

Options said to have been granted for sale of at least 2 properties recently

Kalpana Rashiwala

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

THE Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market appears to be thawing after a quiet period following the introduction of the Total Debt Servicing Ratio framework in late-June.

Options are said to have been granted for the sale of at least two properties recently in Gallop Park and Dalvey Road.

A Singaporean in the banking and finance industry is understood to be selling his Gallop Park bungalow for $25.2 million, translating to $1,574 per square foot (psf) on its land area of about 16,010 sq ft. On site is a two-storey freehold property with approximately 7,000 sq ft built-up area; it has six bedrooms and a swimming pool. The property is believed to have been renovated a few years ago. Newsman Realty brokered the sale.

The latest transaction would mark the fifth time the property is changing hands in the past seven years; the earlier transactions were at about $7.5 million in March 2006, $12.3 million in July 2007, $13.1 million in September 2008 and the December 2010 sale at $21 million to the current owner.

BT understands that the Dalvey Road transaction is at $33 million, or close to $2,190 psf on land area of 15,081 sq ft.

The freehold bungalow, with a built-up area of about 8,600 sq ft, is part of The Glencaird Residences collection developed by a unit of Wharf Holdings. In the latest transaction, the seller is believed to be a company linked to Singaporeans currently residing in Hong Kong. It is thought to have bought the property in April 1997 from Wharf for nearly $13.9 million.

The bungalow was completed in 1999.

Separately, at Mount Echo Park (in the Chatsworth Park GCB Area), an old bungalow with a freehold land area of 15,116 sq ft has been put up for sale at an indicative price of around $26.8 million or $1,773 psf.

On site is a two-storey property believed to have been built around 26 years ago. Its owner is a retired Singaporean who has emigrated overseas.

The five-bedroom bungalow has a built-up area of about 6,000 sq ft. It has a swimming pool and landscaped garden at the rear. "The new owner will have a few options. One, he could do an ID (interior design) job costing maybe $300,000-400,000. Two, he could do major A&A (additions and alterations) works to increase the built-up area to around 8,000-9,000 sq ft; this could possibly cost $1-2 million. Or three, he could completely tear down the existing bungalow and redevelop the site," said KH Tan, managing director of Newsman Realty, which is handling the tender for the property closing on Nov 15. "The property sits on a flat, rectangular site in a quiet area."

Commenting on the state of the market, Mr Tan revealed that he has in hand about a dozen potential buyers looking for a GCB for their own residence.

Most are hoping to sell their existing homes - which could be a smaller bungalow or even apartment - and looking to enter into an agreement to buy a GCB with a longer-than-usual option exercise period.

Market watchers say this is to give them enough time to sell their existing home to avoid being slapped with a high additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) rate on their GCB purchase as well as to settle the loan on their existing property so that they may qualify for the loan amount they will need to buy their new bungalow.

Under the Total Debt Servicing Ratio framework, banks granting property loans to individuals have to ensure that a borrower's monthly total debt repayments do not exceed 60 per cent of his gross monthly income.

And, under the January 2013 property cooling package, Singaporeans have to pay 7 per cent ABSD on their second residential property purchase here, with the rate increasing to 10 per cent ABSD on the third and subsequent purchase.

"The GCB market has been soft for the past few months but I think prices will start to rise again in Q3 next year," Mr Tan predicted.

content:

OSIM's Q3 net profit rises 16% to $22.7m

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

OSIM International's third-quarter profit rose 16 per cent as sales of its massage chairs, massagers and nutritional supplements improved.

Net profit was $22.7 million for the three months ended Sept 30, up from $19.6 million a year ago, Asia's biggest maker of massage chairs said in a statement yesterday. That was lower than the $23.5 million forecast by analysts in a Bloomberg poll.

Revenue rose 7 per cent to $153 million from a year earlier. Contributions from its North Asian operations grew 9 per cent to $81 million, while that of its South Asian business grew 5 per cent to $59 million.

"It's been another very good quarter for us in China. We've continued to invest in building up awareness of the brand and the products we're selling," said OSIM's CFO Peter Lee. "In terms of products, the new key driver of revenue is the uInfinity," he said, referring to the $7,000 uInfinity chair OSIM launched last quarter.

The company's products range from massage chairs and neck pillows to health supplements and teas. It aims to boost sales in its key markets of China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Singapore and Malaysia.

During the quarter, OSIM invested $2.3 million into opening 17 new outlets and upgrading existing outlets. Cash flow from investing activities increased mainly as a result of the repayment of a loan from TWG Tea, the company said.

As at end-September, the group's cash and cash equivalents stood at $250 million, up from $184.9 million a year ago.

Founder and CEO Ron Sim said the company plans to add between six and 10 outlets in North Asia next year, as well as enhance the features of its uAngel and uInfinity chairs.

Earnings per share for the quarter were 3.1 cents, up from 2.7 cents a year ago.

For the first nine months of the year, net profit was $74 million, up 15 per cent year on year. Revenue grew 5 per cent to a record $469 million.

The group declared an interim dividend of one cent a share, unchanged from a year ago.

OSIM shares closed unchanged at $2.11 yesterday.

site_title: Mostly disappointing superhero sequel
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Mostly disappointing superhero sequel

Thor - after just two outings - is looking a little uninspired, says GEOFFREY EU

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

HE MAY be a thoughtless lunkhead at romance - keeping the interplanetary peace is a full-time distraction, after all - but when an invading force wreaks mayhem and threatens to wipe out the kingdom, this god of thunder is all business.

Two years on from an impressive solo debut, and taking a leave of absence from his duties with The Avengers, the big, bearded, hammer-wielding warrior returns to cinemas in Thor: The Dark World - a more sobering, less amusing and mostly disappointing follow-up to the first film, an origins tale in which inter-species love blossoms between a feisty earthling and the heir to the nine realms.

Epic fantasy, Norse mythology and comic-book sensibility are once again the major elements in this early-autumn sequel, which will likely make a substantial contribution to the Marvel Studios coffers. Not that it matters much, but the movie itself is a formulaic and slightly muddled effort, directed by Alan Taylor and weighed down by the need to provide extended narrative and a back story to the villain du jour.

As a result, plot and character development are kept to a minimum while loud, fiery explosions are at a maximum.

Audiences weaned on the likes of Star Wars and Lord of the Rings have seen it all before - better executed too - and while there are some nice individual moments, this Thor lacks the confidence and levity of its predecessor. Plus it's hard not to be blasé about yet another effects-led superhero blockbuster.

This time around, much of the action takes place in the celestial realms of Asgard and surrounding planets, where Thor (Chris Hemsworth), as king-in-waiting to his father, Odin (Anthony Hopkins), has spent the last two years fighting wars and kicking some alien butt.

His treacherous adoptive brother, Loki (Tom Hiddleston), is festering in an Asgardian prison, while back on Earth, main squeeze Jane Foster (Natalie Portman) waits in vain for Thor to call or email.

Just when peace breaks out, Jane discovers a mysterious portal to an alternate universe and inadvertently unleashes an evil force known as the Aether.

Meanwhile, a rare impending planetary convergence gives Malekith (Christopher Eccleston), the brutal leader of the Dark Elves, a chance to exact revenge and destroy Asgard.

Jane may be a brilliant astrophysicist, but there's precious little chemistry between her and her guy. Instead, it's left to Loki to serve as a royal pain in the Asgard and generate some much-needed dramatic heat.

When Malekith attacks and kills someone near and dear to Thor, he reluctantly teams up with Loki in an effort to save the day - a smart move by the filmmakers, as it turns out.

Still, it's hard to be taken seriously when you wear a red cape and lug a giant hammer to work every day.

Thor lacks the intensity and psychological complexity of his caped counterpart the Dark Knight, but even as he tries his best to be a good demigod and a great king, this movie will take him only so far.

The Dark World is no catastrophe but it fails to shed much light on a character who, after only two outings, is looking a little uninspired.

Thor's immediate future is assured in the form of the next Avengers movie and he remains a Marvel-ous team player but for now, his star is just a little out of alignment.

Rating: C+

SUBSCRIBERS

JAL's net profit in H1 slips 17.8% to US$833m

Strong yen, rising fuel costs bite into bottom line but it is bullish for full year

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[TOKYO] Japan Airlines (JAL) said yesterday net profit for the six months to September dropped 17.8 per cent to US$833 million, as the strong yen and rising fuel costs bit into its bottom line.

But it boosted its outlook for the full year, striking an optimistic note on prospects for customer numbers on both domestic and international routes.

In a half that saw the grounding of its fleet of Boeing 787 Dreamliners after a series of safety glitches, the company said it had made 81.94 billion yen (S$1.03 billion), with an operating profit that was down 14.6 per cent at 95.84 billion.

Sales, however, edged up 4.0 per cent to 659.30 billion.

The numbers were healthier than main rival All Nippon Airways (ANA), which issued a grim earnings report, citing high fuel costs and the worldwide grounding of Boeing's next generation aircraft as contributing factors.

JAL, which returned to the market last year after a spectacular bankruptcy, did not give a specific reason for its weaker earnings.

But depreciation of the yen, which has slid to around 100 to the US dollar compared with 80 a year ago, was seen amplifying the cost of fuel as well as user fees for international airports.

Japan's thorny ties with neighbours also depressed demand for flights to South Korea and China. Tokyo is embroiled in separate territorial spats with both countries.

But JAL said revenues from its international services increased "despite the suspension of Boeing 787 flights and stagnant demand on Korea and China routes".

"On June 1, 2013, JAL resumed operation of the Boeing 787 on completing of all necessary safety measures, after battery problems grounded the fleet in January 2013 and caused substantial concerns and inconvenience", the company said.

JAL and ANA were sideswiped by the grounding of Boeing's new aircraft that began in January. After a long-running probe the planes were allowed to fly again in June.

JAL said it increased the use of the fuel-efficient Dreamliner on international services to increase overall efficiency, while reducing Narita-Beijing flights because of shrinking demand.

Domestic services also fared well, with expanded routes and improved services such as better airport lounges.

Unlike ANA, which cut its full-year profit forecasts by two-thirds, one-time flag carrier JAL upgraded its annual forecasts, citing strong demand for flights to South-east Asia and cost-cutting efforts.

The figures were also expected to benefit from an adjustment in foreign exchange movement and falling fuel prices. - AFP

THE Securities Investors Association (Singapore), or SIAS, is holding the fourth Singapore Corporate Governance (CG) Week 2013 from Nov 8 to 15. site_title: Singapore firm turns to High Court for protection against PNG govt
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Singapore firm turns to High Court for protection against PNG govt

It seeks to nullify board sacking, safeguard US$1.4b

Published

Wed, Oct 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] A Singapore non-profit has invoked Singapore laws to nullify the purported sacking of its entire board including a prominent corporate figure by the government of Papua New Guinea and to prevent US$1.4 billion in assets from being "wrongfully appropriated" in a high-profile tussle over a controversial gold and copper mine in the country, according to court documents obtained by BT. Among those purportedly terminated from the board of PNG Sustainable Development Program Ltd (PNG SDP) is Lim How Teck, who has been a director since 2003.

A shipping veteran who retired as chief operating officer of Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) after 26 years there, Mr Lim sits on 14 other boards in Singapore. He is currently chairman of Certis Cisco, ARA-CWT Trust Management (Cache) and Temasek Holdings unit Heliconia Capital Management, as well as the Singapore-based director for major German heavy lift and projects cargo liner company Rickmers.

Typically, directors from Singapore-incorporated companies can only be removed under Singapore law in accordance with the provisions of the Companies Act and the Memorandum and Articles of Association. But in this case, the PNG government has apparently passed legislation, which it says gives it "all necessary powers" to restructure PNG SDP and its operations, and to expropriate its assets including a 63.4 per cent stake in the Ok Tedi mine, among other things.

Former PNG prime minister Mekere Morauta, who was removed from his position as chairman of PNG SDP last week, has criticised the legislation as "unlawful" and which "violated the rules of international law".

"It is apparent that the government passed the legislation to purport to restructure PNG SDP," court papers said, "despite the fact that the structure and governance of PNG SDP was carefully decided and agreed upon after lengthy negotiations between BHP Billiton (the mine's former operator) and the state, and after extensive consultations with key stakeholders."

The company was established when Australian mining company BHP Billiton, in a deal with the government in 2001, divested its majority share in the mine to PNG SDP following concerns about its long-term environmental impact, and in return was granted legal immunity.

It is responsible for ensuring that dividends from the Ok Tedi mine, which accounts for more than a quarter of the country's total exports and nearly 10 per cent of its GDP, are used and managed transparently and accountably for the sustainable development of PNG's western province region and in communities affected by the mine's pollution.

In an effort to nullify the board changes and protect its assets, PNG SDP, represented by Senior Counsel Harpreet Singh Nehal of Cavenagh Law LLP, has sued the PNG government and three members of a transitional management team in the High Court this week.

According to court papers, PNG Prime Minister Peter O'Neill wrote to Mr Morauta last week to advise him of the termination, referring to a section in the Expropriation Act passed last month that he said gave the government powers to remove the directors.

But PNG SDP disagreed. According to court papers, it said that the parties expressly provided that the security deed over the dividends received from the Ok Tedi mine is governed by Singapore law.

The company is seeking declarations that the existing board has full authority to manage its business; that the PNG government may not restructure the company unless in accordance with the provisions of its Memorandum and Articles of Association. It is also seeking a declaration that its assets can only be applied to promote sustainable development within PNG and to advance the general welfare of its people.

PNG SDP is also seeking an order to stop the transitional management team from "taking any action or giving any instructions in relation to its property, rights and assets in Singapore or elsewhere".

Represented by Nish Shetty of Clifford Chance, PNG SDP has also commenced arbitration proceedings through the International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) in Washington DC in what is believed to be the first multi-billion dollar claim by a Singapore company against a foreign government for recovery of the expropriated stake, or alternatively, for compensation to be paid. It is also seeking damages for violations of international law, the company said.

Mr Morauta said that the company, which has operated the mine since 2002, is entitled to an annual dividend, currently capped at US$350 million a year, on its shares in the mine. To date, the government has not paid, or proposed to pay, any compensation to PNG SDP for taking its property, he said.

content:

China Minzhong Q1 profit tumbles 60%

Net margin dives to 7.6% from 19.8%; higher operating costs cited

Published

Wed, Oct 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

CHINA Minzhong, the vegetable processor which came under fire by shortseller Glaucus Research late in August, yesterday posted a 60 per cent plunge in net profit to 48.4 million yuan (S$9.8 million) for the first quarter ended Sept 30, 2013.

Earnings per share slumped to 0.074 yuan for the quarter, from 0.218 yuan in the previous year.

Its net profit margin tumbled to 7.6 per cent from 19.8 per cent a year ago.

China Minzhong said higher operating costs, mostly labour, and average selling prices not rising fast enough to offset higher costs, pressured its margins in both its cultivation and processed business segments.

"The group will seek to mitigate this pressure through the continued shift towards higher value products, better economy of scale on new farmland, as well as more efficient use of resources and increased mechanisation to reduce labour needs," it said.

Other costs that ate into its margins include a 181 per cent rise in selling and distribution expenses to 70.1 million yuan - spent mostly on promoting its brand name domestically. Administrative expenses rose 64.7 per cent to 35.4 million yuan, mainly due to a rise in professional expenses relating to legal and advisory services.

Majority shareholder Indofood Sukses Makmur had made a general offer for the company following the latter's share price plunge after Glaucus had accused it of fraud and financial irregularities, including abnormal profit margins and sales that were artificially boosted. China Minzhong said yesterday that it had on Sept 30 started supplying processed vegetables to Indofood.

For the fiscal first quarter, China Minzhong's revenue edged up 4 per cent to 637.8 million yuan on higher sales from its cultivation business segments.

"The marginal sales increase was on the back of a high revenue base in Q1FY13 which recorded a one-off sales rollover from the previous financial year due to a shift in the operating peak season caused by a late winter," it said.

Analysts BT spoke to said there was no correlation between the Glaucus incident and China Minzhong's poor showing this quarter. Neither did they see any of Glaucus' claims ringing true in the company's financial statement.

Maybank Kim Eng Research analyst Wei Bin said he had not expected some of the costs incurred, especially the 44 million yuan spent on marketing and advertising, but "if you excuse these one-off costs and expenses items which add up to about 60 million yuan, and you add it back to the bottom line, the net profit is quite comparable to year-ago levels," he said.

China Minzhong said that while demand for vegetables remains healthy and agriculture remains a key industry favoured and strongly supported by the local government, it will continue to face rising labour costs in China.

To counter rising wages and future labour shortages on farmland, the group is in the midst of setting up two more industrialised farming bases in Jiangsu province and Sichuan province, in addition to its two existing ones in Tianjin and Shanghai.

China Minzhong shares were last traded at S$1.105 on Oct 18.

Korean Air counter falls over affiliate funding

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Korean Air Lines dropped the most in two years in Seoul trading on concerns that the company may provide further funding to its affiliate Hanjin Shipping.

South Korea's biggest carrier fell as much as 9.9 per cent, the most since September 2011, to 34,600 won and traded at 34,750 won as at 12.13 pm in Seoul. The stock was the worst performer on the MSCI Asia Pacific Index yesterday.

Hanjin Shipping gained 1.9 per cent to 7,960 won, after earlier surging as much as 4 per cent. The benchmark Kospi Index fell 0.7 per cent.

Korean Air said on Wednesday that it would provide 150 billion won (S$175.1 million) to Hanjin Shipping to help ease the company's "temporary" liquidity shortage. The announcement came after Korean Air last week posted a loss for the first nine months due to weak travel demand on its Japan services.

"While it's not a lot of money, the airline industry isn't doing all that well," Um Kyung A, an analyst at Shinyoung Securities in Seoul, said by phone. "Korean Air also has a lot of debt coming due next year."

Korean Air is the biggest shareholder of Hanjin Shipping Holdings, the holding company that owns the largest stake in Hanjin Shipping. Both are members of Hanjin Group. Hanjin Shipping is considering raising 300 billion won through share sale and loans, The Korea Economic Daily reported. - Bloomberg

site_title: Go with an open mind to the works of these two choreographers
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Go with an open mind to the works of these two choreographers

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

WHEN it comes to dance, the written word can only say so much about it.

Choreographers Christina Chan and Kinsun Chan would, in fact, prefer that their audiences show up to watch their works with no assumptions, with a clean slate, as it were.

Christina's work at the upcoming annual Passages Contemporary Season by the Singapore Dance Theatre is a 15-minute male duet titled Shift or Go, which uses a table as a prop, like she did in a workshop in 2011 and in an extended piece at last year's event.

But this piece will not be anything like those two works, said the full-time choreographer with dance company Frontier Danceland.

"I don't think I have a typical style of choreographing. It depends on the dancers I'm working with, because every dancer's body is different. So every piece is different."

She described Shift or Go in terms of space and time, and recommends that the audience take it in by just sitting back and focusing on the changes in space as a whole, rather than on the dancers' individual steps.

"I don't know exactly how to describe it. It's like I'm carving into the space or cutting into the space. It's quite a lot more (like) landscape in a sense, but then again, nobody should have to think about that as a member of the audience. They should just experience it."

Kinsun, a Swiss-Canadian mounting a piece called Slide for Passages, also prefers to let his audiences make up their own minds about his work.

"Slide is, for the most part, an abstract work, and what I appreciate most about abstract art is that it gives room for viewers' interpretation."

The choreographer for ballet companies such as the Basel Ballet and Zurich Ballet cautions the audience not to expect a clear narrative like that in Cinderella or Romeo and Juliet; they will not see a relationship develop or emotions portrayed by the six men and six women on stage.

He said the inspiration for the work is rooted in exploring sliding movements. He added: "I found the phrase 'Let it slide' a central starting point, in reference to giving in to something or letting it pass. And as with every piece, this one too has a unique character, which feels more liquid and fluid."

Passages Contemporary Season runs at the Gallery Theatre of the National Museum of Singapore tonight at 7.30pm; the shows tomorrow are at 3pm and 7.30pm, and on Sunday, at 3pm.

Standard tickets cost $25, and concession tickets for students, senior citizens and full-time National Servicemen cost $20.

site_title: Warm reception expected for Westwood EC site
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Warm reception expected for Westwood EC site

But other released site at Lorong Lew Lian unlikely to be triggered soon

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

PROPERTY consultants agree that the executive condominium (EC) site in Westwood Avenue will be warmly received, but getting them to agree on their pricing expectations is another matter.

That site was one of two released for tender yesterday by the government, the other being a 99-year leasehold residential site in Lorong Lew Lian.

With the Westwood site, the cost per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) cited as likely by consultants ranged from $285 to $380.

On the lower end of the range was SLP International's executive director Nicholas Mak, who said he expects a top bid of between $285 and $313 psf ppr.

Taking the middle ground is Alice Tan, an associate director for consultancy and research at Knight Frank, who expects the winning bid to come in at between $330 and $360 psf ppr; DTZ's head of research Lee Lay Keng gave a range in the same ballpark - between $325 and $365 psf ppr.

Ms Tan said that she expected "moderately healthy interest" in the site, although there were four other confirmed EC sites on the Government Land Sales Programme in the second half of this year, and one potential site on the reserve list. "The upcoming sites could see stronger interest, given their proximity to train stations."

The Westwood site spans 186,052 sq ft and has a maximum permissible gross floor area of 520,945 sq ft, based on a gross plot ratio of 2.8.

That the area has not seen the launch of many EC sites for more than a decade - other than a recent sale of a site in Yuan Ching Road - supports some consultants' thesis of pent-up demand. The last two ECs in the area, Summerdale and The Floravale, were launched in 1997.

Pent-up demand underpins the bullish expectations of consultants who cited psf ppr prices on the higher end: Orange Tee's head of research Christine Li and Ong Kah Seng, the director at R'ST Research, gave a range of $360 to $380 psf ppr.

Ms Li also said that the tightening of the mortgage-servicing ratio, the lowering of loan tenure and the implementation of the Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR) framework were measures working in favour of the EC market.

Mr Ong noted that 11,329 EC units were sold between Q4 2010 - when ECs were introduced as a housing class - and Q3 this year. This translates to a yearly average of 3,770 EC units sold each year.

Assuming that previously sold EC sites in Yuan Ching Road, Punggol Drive, and Punggol Central are launched by the end of next year, a maximum of 3,110 EC units will become available next year.

"The supply in 2014 may be insufficient to cater to EC buyers, based on an average yearly demand of 3,770 units," said Mr Ong, who noted that this figure does not take into account buyers who applied but failed to land a unit. "Given that the TDSR will encourage prudent buying, and more EC-eligible buyers will opt for ECs over private condominium units, the recent historical annual demand for ECs should be sustained or grow even stronger going into 2014," he said.

The tender for the Westwood site closes at noon on Jan 7.

The site in Lorong Lew Lian, measuring 150,762 sq ft and with a maximum permissible gross floor area of 452,288 sq ft, was released on the reserve list.

But DTZ's Ms Lee said that the site is unlikely to be triggered in the near term.

Mr Ong, agreeing, said that developers might not trigger the site for sale till the second quarter of next year, given the existing cautious sentiment.

Assuming the site is triggered next year, Mr Ong said that he expects about five bids for the site, with an expected top land bid of between $430 and $490 psf ppr.

SLP International's Mr Mak said that he expects the site to achieve a land price of $620-720 psf ppr, assuming the site was launched for sale today.

The two residential sites are expected to yield 980 housing units.

SUBSCRIBERS

Singapore fund investors still cautious: Eastspring Investments

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

SINGAPORE unit trust investors prefer income over growth for the next six months, and are most confident in equities, according to a survey by Eastspring Investments.

"Our study revealed that mutual fund investors in Singapore are continuously searching for yield in the current low-interest environment," said Alvin Chiu, head of marketing at Eastspring Investments.

"Some of our other key findings about mutual fund investors in Singapore are that they are generally risk-averse and understand the benefits of long-term investing. They are also keen to use asset classes beyond traditional bonds to acquire yield and total return."

Fund investors here currently allocate about 37 per cent of capital into growth funds, 31 per cent into income funds, and 36 per cent into growth and income funds, according to the survey of 300 unit trust investors in July 2013.

But these weightings are expected to shift in the next six months, with growth funds' allocation falling to 28 per cent, while income funds' allocation is expected to rise to 38 per cent.

This trend is in line with but slightly more income-focused than the region. On a scale of zero to 100, with a reading below 50 indicating a future preference for income, Singapore scored 43. The region's average was 45.

The report also showed increasing confidence in equities among Singapore investors, with 50 per cent expressing confidence over the next six months compared with 47 per cent in July.

Confidence in real estate slipped to 37 per cent for the next six months from 42 per cent, while bonds and cash also saw lower forward confidence.

Mr Chiu said that the data suggests investors remain cautious and are therefore looking to income products for protection. But within the realm of income funds, the preference is for higher-yielding equity funds.

site_title: China writer in exile tackles problems that affect most people
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

China writer in exile tackles problems that affect most people

RACHEL LOI highlights three Asian writers whose works reflect the political milieu of their time and background. She also suggests six events with notable writers in attendance

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

NOBEL Prize winner for Literature Gao Xingjian is often quick to distance himself from anything involving politics. He even describes himself as the sort of writer who covers all genres except political papers and advertorials. "I write what I want to while staying away from issues of politics and economics," he says.

But his body of work tells a different story. Chinese politics often form the backdrop in his writings, ever since he became a pioneer of experimental theatre in China in the early 1980s. His work attracted the attention of the Communist Party, which harassed him and forced him to flee his homeland.

After he had made a new life for himself in France, the 1989 Tiananmen Square incident took place. He released a work titled Fugitives, which was set against the backdrop of the incident. In retaliation, the Communist Party banned all his works in China.

The author now lives in exile as a citizen of France, after giving up his Chinese passport in 1998. In 2000, he became the first writer in Chinese to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature, and his works have been translated into 40 languages.

"I count myself very lucky to be having this kind of recognition. However, it was never my intention to seek fame. I only wanted to do my best for my work because I believe that if I can create something that makes me happy, surely it can work its way into other people's hearts," says Gao.

"My plays and novels depict the survival of man, and the complexity and humour of humanity. They are problems that affect most people - and don't just pertain to China."

Over the course of his career, the 73-year-old author has published more than 20 works including plays, essays and short stories. He is best known for his two semi-autobiographical novels. The first, Soul Mountain (1990), tells the story of a man's journey along the Yangtze river, while the second, One Man's Bible (1999), touches on the Cultural Revolution he went through in his youth.

"I wrote my first novel at the age of 10, and it started from there. During the Cultural Revolution, I was scared so I burnt all my drafts and diaries. But after the revolution, I continued writing, until today, and at the age of 73, I am still not done. This is my life," he says.

Gao's interests include filmmaking, and he has two films to his name - Silhouette/Shadow (2003), a poetic portrait of an artist attempting to understand life, and After The Flood (2008), where actors dance in front of a screen on which his black-and- white paintings are projected.

Next Friday at the Singapore Writers Festival, Gao will premiere his third film, Requiem for Beauty, after delivering a lecture titled Literature and Aesthetics. He describes the film as a piece of "cinematic poetry" that is inspired by his care-free life in France.

While he has yet to reveal the subject matter of the film, Gao promises that it will be "the sort of independent movie that cannot be found in the commercial market".

racloi@sph.com.sg

Gao's lecture, Literature and Aesthetics, is on Nov 8 from 6.30pm to 8.30pm at the National Museum of Singapore Gallery Theatre. This event is not included in the festival pass, and tickets cost $15.

A Meet-the-Author session with Gao on Nov 9 is from 11.30am to 12.30pm at The Salon, National Museum of Singapore. Gao will also take part in a panel discussion, Tongue Ties, Tongue Tied, on Nov 10, from 5.30pm to 6.30pm at the Singapore Management University Binary Pavilion on the Campus Green.

Both these events are included in the festival pass.

site_title: Much of 777X design work to be outside Seattle
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Much of 777X design work to be outside Seattle

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] Boeing Co has decided to place a significant amount of design work for its coming 777X jetliner in cities outside the Seattle area, where the current 777 was designed and is being built, according to an internal memo reviewed by Reuters and confirmed by Boeing on Wednesday.

"It has been decided that much of the detailed design will be carried out by Boeing engineering teams in Charleston (South Carolina), Huntsville (Alabama), Long Beach (California), Philadelphia and St. Louis," the memo said. The Boeing Design Center in Moscow will also support the design activity.

"However, at this time, no decisions have been made about 777X design or build in Puget Sound," the memo said. The news was seen as a blow to engineering workers in Washington state and a sign that the jobs building the more efficient version of Boeing's best-selling wide-body plane could migrate to lower-cost, non-union states, especially Boeing's production facility in South Carolina.

"This is another step in Boeing's war against SPEEA (Society of Professional Engineering Employees in Aerospace), the engineers' union in Seattle," said Scott Hamilton at aviation consultancy Leeham Co in Seattle. "Boeing has been systematically moving engineering jobs out of Washington all year."

The move also comes as Washington state Governor Jay Inslee is considering proposing a package of tax incentives to persuade Boeing to put 777X design and assembly work at its giant factory in Everett, Washington, where the current 777 is made, and keep work in the Puget Sound region, which encompasses Everett, Seattle and Renton, where Boeing has facilities.

Union officials said that they expected some 777X work will be sourced from the Puget Sound region.

Shifting entirely away from the Everett factory, they said, likely would bring problems similar to those experienced with Boeing's 787 Dreamliner, which has suffered a series of glitches, including unstable, overheating batteries and repeated mechanical failures. Design and parts for the 787 were sourced from suppliers around the globe.

Boeing has been considering whether to build the 777X at its factory in North Charleston, South Carolina, and is acquiring land adjacent to that factory. But the company reiterated on Wednesday that it has not yet decided where to build the jet.

The memo released on Wednesday said that Boeing's goal is to bring engineering skill from across the company to tackle a project as large as the 777X. The company also said that it would apply "lessons learned" from the 787 and 747-8 programmes. The new structure of design, "will allow for an efficient use of resources and enable Boeing to resolve design issues effectively the first time". - Reuters

site_title: Brighter power sector with solar energy
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Brighter power sector with solar energy

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

TO further diversify the energy mix here, Singapore is preparing the ground for renewable energy options, with solar power seemingly the most viable at this point. This comes as the power industry here is in a stable, steady state. With natural gas supplies already helping to fuel most of the electricity produced here, renewables (like solar, as it becomes commercially viable) are targeted, in the first instance, to meet up to 10 per cent of current peak electricity demand here.

The power industry here has indeed gone from famine to feast: total generating capacity is outpacing electricity demand growth. It has also gone "green". Supply of environment-friendly natural gas (the favoured fuel accounting for 85 per cent of the electricity generated here) is more than ample, with recently started global shipments of liquefied natural gas (LNG) supplementing what is expected to be diminishing piped gas supplies from neighbouring Indonesia and Malaysia.

Any earlier apprehensions about supply security following Temasek Holdings' sale of the three biggest gencos (Senoko Energy, YTL PowerSeraya and Tuas Power) to foreign owners have also all but evaporated. The trio hold over a three-quarters share of the electricity market here, and in coming months, yet another foreign-owned genco (PacificLight Power) will join them. The experience over the last four years (after the genco divestment) is that the increased intra-industry competition, plus efficiency gains from the power market's liberalisation, has helped moderate wholesale electricity price increases here.

Still, from an end-user's (or household's) perspective, there may be some nagging feeling that this hasn't quite trickled down yet to lower electricity tariffs. But this is largely because feedstock prices for both current piped gas and LNG supplies are still pegged to oil prices. Future LNG supplies (which could be sourced on a shorter-term basis and priced off international gas prices like the US Henry Hub) will hopefully help address this. Longer-term, there are also plans to introduce smart meters, allowing households to choose both the price and which electricity retailer they want to buy power from.

Supply security (but not necessarily cheaper utilities) has meanwhile been beefed up for big consumers like the oil and chemical companies here. On this front, Singapore gencos have ventured into alternatives. Tuas Power is using coal and biomass fuel to supply steam and other utilities. Sembcorp has also started using woodchips and recently announced a waste-to-energy plant capitalising on the waste materials it collects. Big Oil like Shell and ExxonMobil have themselves built new in-house cogeneration plants to supply utilities using LNG feedstock from the SLNG terminal.

In the public sector, the use of solar power panels to generate electricity (including for HDB housing) has started. The latest to do so is the Singapore Sports Hub. Consumers who currently enjoy guaranteed power supplies at the mere flick of a switch have to realise that all this cannot come free.

site_title: Clarifying SGX's clarification
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Clarifying SGX's clarification

Listen to this article

Published Tue, Oct 29, 2013 · 10:00 PM

IN RESPONSE to the tumultuous events of the past three weeks involving the speculative trio of stocks Asiasons, Blumont and LionGold, the Singapore Exchange (SGX) last Friday issued a detailed clarification to correct what it believes are misconceptions about its role as frontline market regulator.

Clearly intended to be the final word on the subject, SGX's explanations are useful as they address gaps in the public's understanding of the way regulatory matters are handled and how the exchange views its role. Last Friday's release should be compulsory reading for all parties interested in regulatory matters, how discipline is maintained in daily trading, and overall governance.

From a close reading of SGX's release, the first point to note is that the exchange's powers are limited almost wholly to issuing warning signals to the market if trading takes an unusual turn. These warnings range in strength, starting with a query - the first signal that something may be amiss. Then it progresses to designation (which occurs if there may be possible manipulation and/or excessive speculation); and ends with an exchange-driven suspension (when the exchange thinks the market is not orderly, informed or fair).

content:

Learning with the best

The latest round of Rolex's Master and Protege Initiative - a biennial programme that matchmakes veterans in the international arts world with upcoming talents - in Venice saw sparks fly. JAIME EE reports

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

ZOMBIES tried to eat Margaret Atwood's head. Gilberto Gil brought the house down with a heady mix of Brazilian samba and Arab social commentary. Lin Hwai-min forced his Brazilian protege to climb a mountain in Taiwan and he came back a "Crooked Man"; meanwhile, William Kentridge's Colombian charge realised he could teach people philosophy and give them a good workout if he trapped them in a garden maze.

Welcome to the sixth cycle of Rolex's Master and Protege Initiative - where the arts are ever in their favour.

Over the brief weekend of Oct 19-20 in magical Venice, the gods smiled and put off the inevitable push into early winter, sending a brief spurt of crisp, (mostly) sunny weather over this city so richly steeped in history, arts and culture. A fitting backdrop indeed to the latest instalment of Rolex's longstanding support of the arts - a biennial programme that matchmakes veterans in the international arts world with upcoming young talents to keep the fire of creativity going.

Gondoliers and tourists stood by as a flurry of water taxis skimmed from the hotels Westin and Danieli to the Fondazione Giorgio Cini - a monastery-turned-cultural foundation on the island of San Giorgio Maggiore. Over two days, its sculpted, expansive grounds took on an inexplicable energy as the latest round of masters and proteges gathered with international media and the arts cognoscenti to present the fruits of their year-long collaboration.

In the building's library, or biblioteca, British literary protege Naomi Alderman - feminist author and inventor of a running app which creates an audio illusion of zombies chasing the jogger to make exercise less boring - presented her project with the illustrious Canadian writer Margaret Atwood.

It was a novel they co-wrote on the unlikely topic of zombies - partly because Alderman had an affinity with them and partly because Atwood didn't believe that serious writers had to only write about serious topics. The Happy Zombie Sunrise Home was her idea, and became a digital novella that can be found on the literary e-platform wattpad.

The rollicking tale saw Atwood and Alderman each writing a chapter and e-mailing it to the other to continue. They obviously had fun doing so, considering that Alderman's presentation included a live re-enactment of her app Zombies, Run!, complete with "real" zombies pursuing a hapless jogger around the room right up to the front where Alderman and Atwood were seated - both of whom were promptly set upon by the zombies and, well, eaten.

With the zombies satiated and quiet, action of a different kind filled the long, timber-floored space of the Cenacolo Palladiano, tailor-made for the work of Brazilian dancer Eduardo Fukushima. Half Italian, half Japanese but completely original in his approach to dance, the intense, small-built Fukushima parlayed the influence of Taiwanese choreographer Lin Hwai-min into a series of mind-bending movements you should not try at home. Part robotic, part spastic and so tightly controlled that every muscle seemed to work like a carefully calibrated spring, his "Crooked Man" defied any attempts at categorisation - the sheer physicality of the work speaking for itself.

After the intensity of the Speed Talks where proteges engaged in quick 12 minute chats with any master he or she chose, witnessing the rehearsal of Polish stage director Michal Borczuch working out the kinks of his production which had been overseen by his late mentor Patrice Chereau (he died of cancer two weeks before the event), and surveying the clean lines of the structure that Chinese architect Yang Zhao created with his mentor Kazuyo Sejima, anybody who was pooped could take a relaxing walk in the garden. So they thought.

It wasn't just any garden but the complicated green labyrinth in the Cini Foundation that protege Colombian artist Mateo Lopez turned into a site-specific installation with the help of visual artist William Kentridge.

With an iPod playing a simultaneous commentary, it was designed to emulate walking through Venice's maze-like alleys while the narrator gives you advice about life, makes observations and asks you to do silly things like write on a ping pong ball or look for hidden messages in the hedges. It was a walk you needed to complete to get out of the maze, after which you've had some light exercise and a new perspective of life.

But the best was yet to be when Egyptian musician Dina El Wedidi took to the stage with her earnest, rousing revolutionary songs that had people tapping to her rhythm and melodies even if they didn't understand the politics behind them. But when her mentor Gilberto Gil came on stage to join her, all hell broke loose as he went straight into performance mode and had everyone on their feet in a scene more suited to a foot-stomping outdoor concert than a supposedly restrained high-brow arts event.

If there was something that everyone agreed upon, it was just how spontaneous, lively and enjoyable the 2012-2013 Rolex mentors programme turned out to be, compared with the previous cycles since the programme began in 2002.

Even Rebecca Irvin, Rolex's head of philanthropy, marvelled at the sheer camaraderie among the proteges and mentors. "This group has become very close," she said, explaining how the initiative requires mentors to spend a total of one month in the year of the collaboration but this group spent much longer than that.

"We're asking artists to collaborate - they don't have to be friends, they don't have to like each other. But they all really, really liked each other. Naomi (Alderman) loves Margaret (Atwood). I guess it's about putting people together and they either get on or they don't. Why the relationships happened to be very close this year, and uniformly so, I'd like to know so we can see how to reproduce it. The other relationships have been valuable but this year seems kind of special."

It was clear, too, from the way they spoke of each other at a press conference, how fond the proteges and mentors were of each other.

Gilberto Gil and Dina El Wedidi shared warm looks as he explained how his idea of mentoring was to let her follow him on the road, even doing a guest performance at one of his shows in London, while she invited him to Cairo to watch her perform.

Lin Hwai-Min of Taiwan's Cloud Gate Dance Theatre spoke candidly of how his idea of mentoring was not to teach Eduardo Fukushima how to dance, so he simply had him travel from Sao Paulo to spend time in Taiwan where he was immersed with Lin's dance company. "I set up strange things for him, made him climb mountains and hike for four days; I think he must have hated me,"quipped Lin. "But he came out intact and with more confidence. I am very proud of him." From the way they embraced easily and were spotted on the streets shopping together, a bond had definitely formed.

It was the same with Atwood, the otherwise serious author whose "strategy was to do a joint project to get to know each other and give my protege a subject where she was superior to me and would not feel intimidated". That topic was zombies, "because Naomi is an expert", but "let me point out to you that monsters have a long history that goes back to Greek and Roman times, so don't think zombies are a low and un-literary interest".

William Kentridge, too, spoke of how he helped the usually precise and "unmessy" Lopez to see the virtues of "messiness", and film editor Walter Murch - whose work includes the seminal movie Apocalypse Now - spoke of the long hours he shared with protege Sara Fgaier in the editing room as he worked on his first documentary feature, where he also learned from her experience in non-fiction film.

Kazuyo Sejima, in turn, spoke of how she and her Chinese protege Yang Zhou bonded over their humanitarian project to construct a "gathering place" in Tohoku, Japan, for survivors of the 2011 tsunami.

Film editing and architecture were two new disciplines added last year, and Rolex's Ms Irvin said that they would look at possibly adding more disciplines as the initiative evolves.

Meanwhile, at a glittering finale dinner which in previous years announced names like Martin Scorsese, Brian Eno, Zhang Yimou, David Hockney, Jessye Norman and Anish Kapoor as mentors, the next line-up was announced.

Artist Olafur Eliasson, choreographer Alexei Ratmansky, writer Michael Ondaatje, film director Alejandro González Iñárritu, composer Kaija Saariaho, lighting designer Jennifer Tipton and architect Peter Zumthor will go on to pick their proteges from a curated list of nominees determined by Rolex's board of artistic advisors.

Until then, the Palazzo Pisani Moretta glittered with the twinkling lights of Venice and stars like Sophia Loren who lent Italian glamour to a night that marked the end of one artistic journey, but the start of a fresh new one.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Taking time-outs keep Matchbox Twenty on top

Dylan Tan

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

FRONTING a successful rock band is no guarantee that you'll enjoy the same fortunes as a solo artist. Just look at the number of albums that Mick Jagger sells when he's not recording with his bandmates from The Rolling Stones.

But it's not always the same story. The likes of Justin Timberlake and Robbie Williams have become bigger artists in their own right than when they were part of a band. Likewise, Matchbox Twenty's frontman Rob Thomas has enjoyed plenty of success on his own.

After putting the band on hiatus in 2004 - while they were at the top of their game - the 41-year-old went on to enjoy an equally illustrious solo career that includes two platinum-selling Top Five albums, . . . Something To Be (2005) and Cradlesong (2009).

He also lent his songwriting talents to artists such as rock legend Tom Petty and country stars Willie Nelson and Travis Tritt.

But nothing beats getting back together with the boys and it's something that Thomas slips back into quite easily as he truly enjoys jamming with the rest of the Matchbox Twenty guys.

"It's a whole different gig," he explains in an e-mail interview. "I love my solo band but there is something about playing with the same guys for almost 20 years . . . Matchbox Twenty is always home to us; it's something we've built over many years."

The band was formed in Florida in 1995 and comprises Thomas on vocals and keyboards, Kyle Cook on lead guitar, Brian Yale on bass and Paul Doucette on drums. Former rhythm guitarist and founding member Adam Gaynor left in 2005, with drummer Doucette standing in during recording.

They made their debut in 1996 with Yourself or Someone Like You. The album was a big hit, spawning singles such as Push, 3 am, Real World, Long Day and Back 2 Good. 2000's follow-up Mad Season and 2002's More Than You Think You Are both went multi-platinum and featured hits such as Bent, Unwell, If You're Gone, Bright Lights and Disease.

After going on hiatus in 2004, Matchbox Twenty regrouped briefly in 2007 to record a handful of tracks for their retrospective compilation album Exile on Mainstream and toured for about a year before taking another break in 2008.

But they got back together again three years later and started work on their fourth studio album, North, which features the top 10 single She's So Mean. It was released late last year and shot straight to the top of the album charts in America and Australia.

Thomas attributes the success of North to the time out that the band members took from each other. "Every time we step away from Matchbox, we aren't just sitting around; we are always working with other people in other situations," he stresses. "And every one of those is an opportunity for us to learn something new and bring it back to Matchbox when we're together again."

North has also set Matchbox Twenty back out on the road with back-to-back sold-out tours through North America and Down Under. The quartet are set to play their first-ever show in Singapore next weekend.

"The only part of our career that we don't fully control is touring," says Thomas, when asked why it took the band so long to finally make it here. "There are so many factors that involve the label, booking agents, promoters, etc that all we can do is to keep saying we want to go somewhere until they send us there!"

Matchbox Twenty plays at the Singapore Indoor Stadium on Nov 10 at 8pm. Tickets at $68-108 available at Sistic outlets and online

Around Town

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

>Family

A Christmas Carol, Grimm's Fairy Tales and Red Riding Hood:

Take the youngsters for a night out at the theatre with three shows lined up in the next couple of weeks. Celebrate Yuletide early with the familiar Dickens tale about a stingy man and the lessons he learns from the ghosts of Christmas Past, Present and Future in A Christmas Carol performed by Canada's Dufflebag Theatre Company and staged by ACT 3 International. Over at the Drama Centre, musical versions of popular Grimm's fairy tales like Hansel and Gretel, Rapunzel, The Valiant Little Tailor and more will be staged. Last but not least, the Singapore Repertory Theatre performs Little Red Riding Hood with a twist, by London's award-winning writing duo Jake Brunger and Pippa Cleary.

A Christmas Carol runs from Nov 2 to Nov 17, at 10am and 2.30pm on weekdays and at 11am and 4pm on weekends, at Act 3 Theatre on 126 Cairnhill Road. Tickets cost $25 for weekdays and $28 for weekends.

Grimm's Fairy Tales runs from tonight until Nov 17, at 10.30am and 2.30pm from Tues to Fri, 2.30pm and 7.30pm on Sat, and 11am and 5pm on Sun, at the Drama Centre Theatre. Tickets cost $30 and $32.

Red Riding Hood will run from tonight until Dec 15, at various timings, at the DBS Arts Centre - Home of SRT. Tickets cost $25 to $28 on weekdays and $35 to $38 on weekends.

Log on to

www.sistic.com.sg

for more information and to purchase tickets.

>Theatre

The Merchants of Bollywood:

After a sold-out run in Singapore in 2010 and a successful world tour, this musical returns to the Marina Bay Sands Grand Theatre from next week. The show is loosely based on two real life people - Hiralal Merchant, who did the choreography for classic Hindi films, and his granddaughter, Vaibhavi Merchant, who is the Bollywood choreographer behind the dances for this show. Written and directed by Australian Toby Gough, the musical tells the history of the Bollywood film industry.

The Merchants of Bollywood will run at the Grand Theatre at Marina Bay Sands from Nov 5 to Nov 10, at 7.30pm from Tues to Fri, and 2pm and 7.30pm on Sat and Sun. Standard tickets are from $45 to $165, while VIP Boxes (four seats) cost $660. Log on to

www.sistic.com.sg

for more information and for tickets.

>Exhibition

Journey to the Soul Mountain:

Find out more about Nobel Prize for Literature winner Gao Xingjian's works before he makes an appearance at the upcoming Singapore Writers Festival. Journey to the Soul Mountain showcases 50 black-and- white photos taken in late 1987, when Gao was writing a novel based on his time in rural China. He began writing the book in 1982 and continued until 1989 after he had moved to Paris. The novel, Soul Mountain, has been translated into 39 languages.

Journey to the Soul Mountain is on at the Societe Generale Gallery at the Alliance Francaise de Singapour until Nov 12. Opening hours are 11am to 7pm from Mon to Fri, and 11am to 5pm on Sat. Closed on Sundays and public holidays. Admission is free. Log on to

www.alliancefrancaise.org.sg

for more information.

Humans Among Aliens:

Check out the works of three contemporary Italian artists at this group exhibition. Valerio Berruti will showcase 11 frescoes on jute and over 30 drawings on cardboard in Innocent Awakenings; José D'Apice's works combine drawing and collage in An Exploration of the Imagination and Subconscious; and Troilo uses his fingers to create large paintings in Expressive Black and White Works.

Humans Among Aliens will run until Nov 17 at Artspace@Helutrans, Gallery 3, located at Level 2 of the Tanjong Pagar Distripark on 39 Keppel Road. Opening hours are 11am to 7pm on Tues to Sat. Admission is free. Call 6462 0030 for more information.

Natural Cool CEO fined $150K for trading breaches

Ang Choon Cheng quits post and directorship

Published Thu, Oct 31, 2013 · 10:00 PM

NATURAL Cool Holdings CEO Ang Choon Cheng has been hit with a civil penalty by the authorities and has resigned from his position over false trading and manipulation of shares in the company.

Mr Ang, who also relinquished his post as a director of the air-conditioning services firm yesterday, was dealt a $150,000 civil penalty without court action by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) for breaching the Securities and Futures Act (SFA).

His violations of the Act started after he pledged Natural Cool shares for financing purposes. On 35 days between Jan 9, 2008 and June 16, 2009, he bought Natural Cool shares in order to maintain or raise the share price to prevent margin calls, MAS said.

"As a result of the purchases, Natural Cool shares closed as much as 12 bids, or 30 per cent, above the preceding traded price," an MAS statement said yesterday.

"Through his actions, Mr Ang intended to create, and created a false or misleading appearance with respect to the price of Natural Cool shares."

Mr Ang had carried out the purchases and two sale transactions using the securities trading accounts maintained by two other people with the same brokerage house, which created the impression that the various transactions were for these two people, when he had been the actual beneficiary of those trades.

In its statement yesterday, the authority noted that Mr Ang had "cooperated fully with MAS in the course of the investigation".

On top of the civil penalty, which was levied for violations of two separate parts of the SFA, Mr Ang also voluntarily undertook not to be a company director for a one-year period with effect from yesterday.

In the wake of Mr Ang's resignation from Natural Cool, the company appointed Tsng Joo Peng, an executive director of the company, as the new CEO with effect from yesterday.

"Mr Tsng has been an executive director of the company since August 2005 and is well versed with the operations of the group," the firm said in a filing to the Singapore Exchange yesterday.

The counter's last closing price was 16 cents on Oct 24.

site_title: No guaranteed access for Pavilion to SLNG terminal
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

No guaranteed access for Pavilion to SLNG terminal

It'll have to vie with other firms for use of facility: Iswaran

Published

Wed, Oct 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Temasek-owned Pavilion Energy will not have guaranteed access to the Singapore LNG (SLNG) terminal and will have to vie with other industry players, including international ones, for its use, said S Iswaran, Minister in the Prime Minister's Office.

"It will be a level playing field," said Mr Iswaran, who is also Second Minister for Home Affairs and Trade & Industry.

He was responding to a BT query on the role of Pavilion and SLNG, and whether Pavilion will have a stake in SLNG or the two will be independent of each other.

"Pavilion is a private company . . . it's a commercial operation, so we have to treat them as such," he stressed.

On the other hand, "Singapore LNG is fully owned by the Energy Market Authority (EMA) and is responsible for developing and operating the LNG terminal," he said, referring to the $1.7 billion Jurong Island facility that started up in May. SLNG is also the first open-access, multi-user LNG terminal in Asia.

"So Pavilion will be treated like any other commercial operator in the Singapore system," he added.

The issue is timely as Pavilion, which was set up by Temasek Holdings in April to invest and participate in both upstream and downstream aspects of the LNG chain, yesterday announced that it had struck its first long-term LNG purchase for delivery into Singapore and the region.

It is pertinent as EMA is now developing a Terminal Access Code (TAC) to provide clarity to industry players on how the facility's capacity can be allocated to spot import and other ancillary services without affecting its main throughput services, that is, bringing in LNG to fuel Singapore's power stations and big industries, such as the petrochemical complexes.

The SLNG terminal, which started with an initial capacity of 3.5 million tonnes per annum (tpa), will see its regasification capacity boosted to six million tpa by year-end when a third tank is completed. It is also planning a fourth tank to ramp this up to nine million tpa, with the final investment decision, including construction award, for this expected in Q2 2014.

There has been a flood of big global LNG producers and traders, including majors such as Gazprom, Shell and BP, which have set up outposts here to capitalise on Singapore's plan to develop into an Asian LNG hub. But there will be limits to the number of players which SLNG can accommodate at this time.

EMA had earlier assessed that the terminal will be able to support only up to four long-term importers, including initial aggregator BG Group, but said it was considering allowing players to also apply for licences to import spot cargoes.

Singapore consumers less pessimistic in Q3: Nielsen survey

They are also getting more upbeat about their job prospects and personal finances

Listen to this article

Published Wed, Oct 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] While Singaporeans may be getting more upbeat about their job prospects and personal finances, consumer confidence levels here still fall on the side of pessimism, a survey has found.

According to Nielsen's Global Survey of Consumer Confidence and Spending Intentions released yesterday, confidence levels in Singapore slipped in Q4 last year and remained flat for three consecutive quarters. But confidence bounced back in Q3 this year to the same level a year earlier.

"The higher-than-expected GDP growth that Singapore experienced in Q2 has had a positive impact on consumers' confidence, which has increased this quarter for the first time in 12 months," said Luca Griseri, head of financial services, Nielsen Singapore and Malaysia.

Company Briefs

Published

Wed, Oct 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Creative's Q1 loss deepens to US$5.54m

CREATIVE Technology posted a net loss of US$5.54 million for its fiscal first quarter, 24 per cent more than the US$4.46 million loss a year earlier. Turnover fell 15 per cent to US$30.4 million. Loss per share was 8 US cents, up from 6 US cents.

Pure Beauty's offer for SMG unconditional

PURE Beauty Investments' voluntary offer for Singapore Medical Group has been declared unconditional. This comes after acceptances hit 42.14 per cent, which together with shares owned, controlled or agreed to be acquired by Pure Beauty and any person acting in concert with it, makes it 62.57 per cent of the total number of shares and 53.25 per cent of the maximum potential issued share capital of the company.

Loyz Energy draws first oil in US well

SINGAPORE-BASED upstream energy group Loyz Energy announced yesterday that it has drawn first oil in North Dakota and Colorado in the US, where it is currently far progressed into the first leg of its well-drilling campaign. The announcement comes just over a year after concluding its largest exploration and production (E&P) deal, which provides the group with a 20 per cent share of net revenue interest for each producing well.

Yongnam issues Q3 results warning

YONGNAM Holdings issued a warning yesterday that it is expected to record an operating loss for its third quarter, notwithstanding a healthy increase in revenue. This is mainly due to cost overruns from three on-going projects which pared operating margin to new lows and a significant non-recurring one-off loss on disposal of some fixed assets that eroded the already thin bottom-line profit for the quarter. Nevertheless, the group said it is expected to report a net profit for the financial year, though it is expected to be significantly lower than that of 2012.

Cosco delivers bulk carrier to Asian buyer

COSCO Corporation announced yesterday that its Guangdong shipyard had completed and delivered a bulk carrier of 57,000dwt, named Greener, to its Asian buyer. The bulk carrier measures 189.99 metres in length, 32.26 metres in breadth and 18 metres in depth.

Tianjin Zhong Xin's Q3 net dips 6%

TIANJIN Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group posted a 6 per cent drop in net profit for its third quarter to 48 million renminbi (S$9.7 million) due to the disposal of a subsidiary and decrease in share of profits from an associated company. Revenue for the quarter increased by 10 per cent to 1.4 billion renminbi.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

IndoAgri earnings continue to slide

Published

Wed, Oct 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

INDOFOOD Agri Resources' earnings dived 52 per cent in the third quarter due to the twin pressures of lower selling prices and higher production cost, making it four quarters in a row of lower earnings.

Net profit for the July-September quarter slid to 122.9 billion rupiah (S$13.7 million), representing earnings per share of 86 rupiah, compared with 179 rupiah last year.

The firm's top line fell 13 per cent to 3.08 trillion rupiah.

Sales performance had been "adversely affected" by both weaker selling prices of palm products and rubber and poorer sales numbers in its edible oils and fats division, due to lower sales volume and a 10 per cent price reduction for consumer cooking oil and margarine since April, IndoAgri said.

Crude palm oil prices averaged US$845 per tonne in the nine months so far, significantly lower than the average of US$1,006 in 2012, as slower biodiesel demand in Europe and expectations of stronger palm oil supplies in the second half of the year brought prices down.

Rubber prices have also eased to an average of US$2,884 per tonne for the nine months, from US$3,384 last year, on slower demand from major consumers such as China, US and Europe.

Higher production cost, no thanks to rising wages and newly matured plantations, meant that gross profit declined by a greater 22 per cent to 836.3 billion rupiah.

The bottom line was further eroded by a foreign exchange loss of 88.7 billion rupiah, against gains of 16 billion rupiah last year, after the rupiah weakened sharply against the US dollar in the third quarter.

IndoAgri also shared in a greater loss of 16.1 billion rupiah because of its investment in Heliae, a US development-stage firm which develops algae technology solutions for the commercial production of products such as fertiliser, chemicals and pharmaceuticals.

These were partially offset by a maiden profit contribution of 50.2 billion rupiah from its investment in sugar mill Companhia Mineira de Acucar e Alcool Participacoes (CMAA).

IndoAgri had announced its acquisition of the 50 per cent stake in CMAA for 143.4 million Brazilian real (S$87.1 million) in January.

"We were surprised by its Brazilian sugar's contributions despite low international raw sugar prices," said CIMB analyst Ivy Ng, who is maintaining an "underperform" rating on the stock for now. "We expect Q4 earnings to be better, led by seasonally stronger plantation production and sugar contributions."

For the first nine months, net profit was down 66.7 per cent at 295.6 billion rupiah while revenue dipped 9.4 per cent to 9.53 trillion rupiah.

IndoAgri's shares ended trading half a cent higher at 89 cents yesterday.

site_title: Asiasons eyes $25m convertible loan facility from directors
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Asiasons eyes $25m convertible loan facility from directors

Published

Wed, Oct 30, 2013 · 10:00 PM

BATTERED investment firm Asiasons Capital plans to take a $25 million convertible loan facility from two of its key directors as a source of standby capital, it was announced yesterday.

Draw-downs on the four-year facility will incur annual interest of 6 per cent.

The lenders - co-founders and co-managing directors Ng Teck Wah and Jared Lim Chih Li - may choose to be repaid upon maturity in shares at 25 cents apiece, or a 58 per cent premium to Asiasons' Tuesday close of 15.8 cents. The stock ended at 15.5 cents yesterday.

If fully drawn down and converted, the facility will be converted into 100 million shares, or about 9 per cent of enlarged share capital, based on reported share numbers as at Sept 17. Mr Ng's and Mr Lim's last reported deemed stake was 49.3 per cent.

Given that it is an interested-party transaction, the facility has to be approved by the firm's independent shareholders.

Asiasons will use the facility as standby capital, with $20 million set aside for investments and the remaining $5 million for working capital.

As at June 30, Asiasons had cash and cash equivalents of $13.6 million, with $7.6 million of debt repayable by June 2014. It also has an $18.5 million term loan due in 2015, which is secured by quoted securities.

Mr Lim told The Business Times that the deal should "give a note of confidence that the founding shareholders continue to believe in the company and are injecting fresh funds at a significant premium to the market".

Asiasons had been trying to raise $254 million through a placement of shares to a group of institutional investors, but that deal fell through as a result of events over the past few weeks.

"This is the same direction being adopted, just a smaller amount," Mr Lim said.

Asiasons stock has fallen more than 90 per cent from its Oct 3 close. The share's unusually sharp drop on the morning of Oct 4 led to a suspension by Singapore Exchange (SGX), followed by exchange-imposed trading curbs that were lifted only on Oct 21.

SGX and the Monetary Authority of Singapore have said they are reviewing trading in the stock.
