site_title: Blue Lotus beckons
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Blue Lotus beckons

Nestled in uptown Sentosa, the casual noodle bar proves quite a draw, writes JAIME EE

Published

Sun, Oct 27, 2013 · 10:00 PM

NEW RESTAURANT

Blue Lotus

31 Ocean Way #01-03 Quayside Isle

Tel: 6339 0880

Open for lunch Fri to Mon 11.30am to 3pm

Open for dinner Wed to Mon 6pm to 11pm

(Closed on Tues)

FOR his maiden venture, Ricky Ng could do worse than name his restaurant after a chapter in a French comic series or locate it outside the comfort zone of lazy Singaporean diners.

The reference to Herge's Tintin, the shower of colourful lanterns and the manufactured lifestyle destination that is Sentosa's Quayside Isle give Blue Lotus an air of exotica catered to Occidental palates. That is, until you take a bite of its chilli crab and pomelo, which will not only clear your sinuses but any bias you had at the start.

Underneath its casual noodle bar exterior, there's a serious Chinese restaurant trying to bust out. But not in the Imperial Treasure/Crystal Jade or even Tung Lok (where Ng was COO for years before going solo) way with its structured Cantonese banquet cuisine and "What, no braised whole comb of shark's fin or two-head abalone for you today?" attitude. Rather, it's about applying high-end restaurant standards to folksy, homespun favourites.

It helps that, as an independent operator, Ng - who's traded in his cool-dude wardrobe for T-shirt and jeans - can work on the fly, tweaking dishes in real time in response to feedback while adding new items or dropping unpopular ones any time. He's at the restaurant all the time, so a minimum standard of quality is assured - and if it isn't, he takes complaints on the chin.

Even though he lost his original chef due to employment pass issues, the second in command has stepped up to the plate. The cooking is assured, the menu streamlined and less of a hotchpotch attempt to appeal to all tastes.

At lunch, quick meal options include upgraded hawker classics such as bak kut teh, char kway teow and prawn noodle. The pork rib soup ($18) is cooked with black garlic - which adds a rather cloying, unnatural sweetness to the broth although it's supposed to have health benefits.

It's a trifle alienating, but we can appreciate that the ribs are steamed beforehand to keep the meat from losing all its suppleness when left to cook in the broth. In turn, the prawn noodle ($18) is actually ramen in an intense, truffle-scented superior stock with a plump, cushiony prawn dumpling. Meanwhile, the char kway teow ($16) operates on the premise that there's more to be done with prata than to dunk it in curry or wrap it over banana and chocolate.

Here, it's shredded and fried in black sauce with fat crunchy prawns and bean sprouts. The jury is out on whether the chewy dough shreds work better than conventional rice noodles, but we'll vote for the fragrant wok hei and the plump seafood.

The real appeal of Blue Lotus, though, is in its generosity with ingredients and the quality. No fillers or substitutes are used to stretch the supply of fresh seafood used in everything from dumplings to chilli crab.

That's what makes the lemongrass prawn sticks ($18 for four) such a winner - lightly packed minced shrimp shaped around the fragrant stalks instead of sugarcane. Dip into a creamy citrus emulsion for a fusion Vietnamese staple that works.

The same with deep-fried salt and pepper squid ($18) - a guilty pleasure of fat, octopus-like tentacles with a light crisp coat that leaves a lingering tingle on your tongue from the Szechuan pepper.

Of course, there's the must-order chilli crab that can't decide if it's sweet, sour, tangy, fiery or punchy so it settles for all in a peppy orange-red gravy that cloaks Sri Lankan specimens so solidly packed, they might have still been bench-pressing weights when the fishermen's nets came in.

To alleviate the chilli sting, meticulously peeled pomelo segments are showered over the crab in a surprisingly successful antidote. How well it works if the heat is dialled up on request is not something we want to try.

Blue Lotus's ever-evolving menu has also thrown up a couple of new hits. Available only on weekends, the roast pork belly ($18) is excellent, the wobbly, melt-in-the-mouth layers of fat and fork-tender meat topped with a lacquered layer of crackling belying its nondescript appearance.

And while we didn't try it, the home-made lor mai kai ($38) - which needs two days' advance order and eight people to eat it - sounds promising from its description as a whole chicken encased in glutinous rice, wrapped in lotus leaf and slow-cooked.

For a fuss-free weeknight meal of serviceable sweet-sour pork and mapo tofu with rice, to a more elaborate feast of crab and wok-fried wagyu cubes and everything in between, Blue Lotus appeals with its neighbourhood charm and polished uptown core.

Sentosa Cove neighbourhood, that is. We have something like that in our neck of the woods, too, but it's called a zi char. So until we can afford to move, we could do a lot worse than drive to Sentosa for a meal we actually like.

jaime@sph.com.sg

7.5

9-9.5: Sublime

8-8.5: Excellent

7-7.5: Good to very good

6-6.5: Promising

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Forever young

For the ambitious CEO of Versace, upholding the house's corseted, cupped and cinched aesthetics for the next generation is the secret to restoring a luxury empire. By May Yip

Listen to this article

Published Fri, Oct 25, 2013 · 10:00 PM

SPEAKING highly of one's boss may be customary practice for any employee, but Versace chief executive Gian Giacomo Ferraris's admiration for Donatella Versace borders on the effusive. "Working with Donatella Versace is a most rewarding experience," declares Mr Ferraris in his suite at the St Regis Hotel, when he was in town to grace the opening of the brand's 2,013 square feet boutique at Paragon. "She possesses not just incredible creative talent - imagine the amount of concentration required for creating our range of products - but has great managerial skills as well."

It would have been easy for Mr Ferraris, who was the former head of the Jil Sander Group and Gucci Group, to take personal credit for the brand's successes. After all, within a year of his appointment at Versace in 2009, he managed to increase revenue of the Versace group by 9 per cent. Saddled with debt after the death of founder Gianni Versace in 1997, followed by the global financial crisis in 2009, the group posted operating profits only in 2011.

And the secret to the group's success, besides much drier restructuring measures, lies in creative consistency. Picking up a printed throw cushion from the settee, Mr Ferraris explains: "Every line, every product had to be placed under the direction of Mrs Donatella to deliver the same emotion and DNA throughout the brand. From men's ready-to-wear to a cup, to a cushion, to a woman's accessory - everything has to be approved by Mrs Donatella."

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Making the right decisions

Some tests and procedures to save our lives may have the potential to increase risks of stroke, cancer and dementia

Listen to this article

Published Fri, Oct 25, 2013 · 10:00 PM

WITH people's increasing longevity, the main challenges will be to reduce the risks of diseases of the elderly, namely, heart disease, stroke, cancer and dementia. In addition to controlling the main risk factors, such as high blood pressure, diabetes mellitus, high cholesterol levels and smoking, we can further maintain our health by not exposing ourselves to the risks that will be detrimental to our health. Interestingly, the very diagnostic tests and procedures that can save our lives may have the potential to increase our risks of stroke, cancer and dementia.

Invasive diagnostic angiograms

The first group of tests called angiograms are diagnostic procedures that involve the insertion of a plastic tube and the injection of contrast agents into the arteries of the heart or brain under X-ray guidance; these tests carry both an increase in the risk of stroke and increased exposure to X-ray radiation. Safer non-invasive alternative tests have replaced most of these tests. Currently, imaging the arteries using a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan or a computed tomography (CT) of the arteries can be performed non-invasively with no risk of stroke, heart attack, or bleeding. While brain angiograms have been largely replaced by non-invasive scans, invasive angiogram of the heart arteries (coronary angiogram or CAG) is still a commonly performed diagnostic procedure.

site_title: Lowdown on tie-ups
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Lowdown on tie-ups

International chain stores aren't the only ones to bank on collaborations with posh brands. A handful of Asian brands are now working with higher-end designers to entice savvy shoppers. By May Yip

Published

Fri, Oct 25, 2013 · 10:00 PM

THE most talked-about high-low fashion tie-up this season may be Isabel Marant's insouciant-chic designs for H&M (which will be released on Nov 14). But one doesn't need to camp out at a chain store to get a piece of collab action. Closer to home, home-grown labels are also joining forces with international fashion wunderkinds to whet the appetites of style trendites.

Malaysian fashion retailer Dude & the Duchess, which specialises in well-tailored shirts and dresses, for one, has snagged rising fashion star Jonathan Liang, a fellow countryman who is based in Paris, for its first-ever collaboration - DD x JL.

"There is an ongoing movement of brands at all levels, from luxury to mass, and the trend of launching collaborations has helped many levels of businesses, giving them a different edge and helping them appeal to different demographics," says founder of Dude & the Duchess Kristy Yong, who has already started work on yet another collection with Mr Liang after enjoying the experience of teaming up on the capsule line. "It has been a very intense six to seven months of Skyping across Kuala Lumpur and Paris time zones, and we're incredibly excited about the outcome."

To be launched next Friday in its retail and online stores, the capsule collection checks all the boxes of a buzz-worthy line: precisely-cut separates, of-the-moment trends, a hot name and, above all, great value for money.

Most notably, the high-tech fabrication employed, like embossed snake and crocodile skin, and grated foil-glazed viscose, are more luxurious than what one would usually expect from a high street label. And with prices ranging from RM329 ($129) for a Lurex jacquard swing skirt to RM459 for a metallic blue dress with a pebbled sheen finish, the pieces are practically steals when considering the four-digit price-tagged looks from Mr Liang's main line.

"We've infused details such as hidden pockets, kangaroo pouches on a shirt and slits on sleeves and shirts, which play a role in the tuck-and-fold of the garments," elaborates the 25-year-old designer, who briefly interned at Givenchy before launching his own label in the fashion capital. "These details may be uncommon for a high street collection, but the aim was to create personal pieces the wearer could relate to."

And the high-low divide between collaborators is even wider for yet another capsule line: online fashion retailer Love, Bonito's collection by haute couture designer Julien Fournie. Launched during the Fide Fashion Week earlier this month, the range of 15 looks was designed in just three days during a trip to Paris by the brand's founders and took two months to materialise.

"We attended Julien's show last year, and casually mentioned to Frank Cintamani, chairman of Fide Fashion Weeks, about the idea of Love, Bonito possibly working with Julien Fournie," says Viola Tan, a co-founder of the affordable fashion label. "Julien's team was initially very reserved; they hardly ever collaborated with other designers, much less an online shop so this is more than an honour for us. We have been dreaming of this since last year and it was only this year that we were graced with an answer."

For lesser-known Asian brands, attracting big-name talents may be a challenge when it comes to creating a tie-up that's on the lips of shoppers. In the case of home-grown house Raoul, working with an up-and-coming talent - rather than a superstar designer - is a long-term strategy to elevate the brand's credibility and style cachet.

"Accessories are an integral part of a fashion house, and we knew that it was an area that needed to be addressed and put in the right hands," says Raoul's creative director Odile Benjamin, who appointed Raphael Young, a Paris-based accessories designer whose creations have been worn by Lady Gaga and Beyonce, to design its Pre-Fall 2014 shoes and bags.

"We didn't actively go out looking for a designer; the introduction happened, Raphael and ourselves got talking immediately and Doug (Douglas Benjamin, Odile's husband and co-creative director of Raoul) and I felt that he really understood what we wanted. So everything fell into place naturally."

In fact, Mr Young, who was born in Korea and adopted and raised in France, has no qualms about working for a smaller Asian label, despite having headed the shoes and accessories design team at Calvin Klein Collection.

"My Asian blood causes me to like Asia, and working with Mr and Mrs Benjamin is as exciting for me as working for the oldest European maison - we even speak French sometimes with Odile," says the designer, who now has an eponymous shoe label. "Raoul is growing fast and its base in Singapore is a great 'trampoline' to connect with the whole world."

Likewise, although he had moved to Paris to propel his career to an international level, Mr Liang also does not regard a collaboration with a less premium Malaysian brand like Dude & the Duchess as a step backwards.

He says: "It doesn't matter where a label comes from or what level it is at, what matters most is the values and visions of its founder."

Rather than worrying that a lower-priced collection would dilute the luxe positioning of his own fashion house, Mr Liang focused on creating pieces that ranked high on versatility and value, and introduced some classics from his label such as uniquely placed hems and slits, hidden details and elongated button stands, all while retaining Dude & the Duchess's classic shirt styles and relaxed fits.

Besides, when asked if his designs for the tie-up could be paired with looks from his own collection, the designer jokes: "If I spot anyone in a piece from this collaboration mixed with our main line, I would stalk them, stop them and take lots of pictures so I could show them to my mum."

site_title: Bali getaways
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Bali getaways

Tay Suan Chiang checks out 3 resorts which will appeal to those seeking the sun, sand and sea, with some shopping thrown in

Published

Fri, Oct 25, 2013 · 10:00 PM

MENTION Kuta and images of backpackers' hostels and the stretch of great surfing beach in Bali come to mind. All that is still there for the budget conscious travellers who want to rough it out. But the area is now getting a more upmarket feel with the opening of the Sheraton Bali Kuta Resort.

The great thing is that the Sheraton is located in the heart of Kuta beach with the golden sandy stretch and the Indian Ocean just across the road, and the bars, restaurants and pubs all within walking distance.

Already, the resort is popular with families and the slightly older crowd, who may have given Kuta a miss before.

Instead of sticking with the slanted, thatched roofs typical of Balinese architecture, the hotel has opted for a modern look, but retaining some Balinese touch. The hotel rooms and main social areas are elevated and this has advantages.

For one thing, you don't quite see or hear the traffic that goes past the resort. Perched on the rooftop of Bene Italian restaurant, you get clear views of the sunset, which beats having to squeeze with the masses on the beach for an Instagram worthy shot.

The resort makes no bones about cashing in on its prime sunset viewing spot. From 5pm to 7pm nightly, it hosts Sunset Gatherings for hotel guests and the public. For 149,000 rupiah (S$16.50) and you get to sample wine, with canapes, artisanal cheeses and breads or handmade wood-fired pizzas while watching the sun set.

The resort's 203 rooms and suites are spacious with balconies either facing the ocean or its two courtyards. To put it simply, the rooms are nothing short of what you would expect from the Sheraton brand.

What stands out more at this resort are the dining options, and the activities that raise the guest experience.

The Indonesian island getaway is known for its local fare, such as babi guling and bebek betutu, but giving that a miss, and opting for Italian is not a bad idea.

At Bene, executive chef Rossano Renzelli does a mean hand-made pasta, alongside his signature dishes including Spezzatino di maiale, manzo, and e salsiccia con piselli - stewed diced pork, beef and pork sausage with green peas and onion and a classic Risotto ai porcini - Italian rice with porcini mushroom.

If you have a group of 10, opt to dine in the private dining room, where you and your pals can sit around a solid single tree trunk dining table which overlooks the beach.

The resort's other dining option is Feast, its 160-seater restaurant that has live stations, offering buffets three times a day.

The food quality and variety are decent, but the best time to come is on Sundays, from noon to 3pm, when the restaurant holds its weekly Market Brunch, believed to be the first of its kind on the island. The theme is Sip, Savour and Shop. The food menu changes weekly, but you can expect artisanal cheeses and sliced meats, sushi, and seafood barbecue. And if you like the cheese or seafood on the buffet spread, they are also for sale, alongside other fresh produce and pre-made items. It is also at the market brunch that you can get chocolates from the island's only chocolate manufacturer, Pod Chocolate, started by Australian Toby Garritt.

If you are lucky enough, you may get invited to dine at the chef's table. Chef Renzelli will invite 12 guests to dine with him in the pastry room, inside the resort's kitchen. "It will be for open-minded diners," he says. The menu is extensive, but forget dining on fancy tableware. Instead, your jumbo river prawn bouillabaisse is served in a pot, and the veal leg in a shallow metal bowl. Not quite the fine dining experience you would expect, but nevertheless a fun story to share with the other not-so-lucky guests.

If you are the sort who must shop, the resort is next door to the famed Poppies Lane, a row of shops selling local beachwear and apparel and other souvenirs.

Alternatively, head to Beachwalk next door, an open air shopping mall, that looks suspiciously like The Star Vista.

Most of the brands here are what you can find in Singapore, so if you are looking for something that is more local, head to Satu. The multi-label fashion boutique houses some of Bali's best designers, such as lace brand Uluwatu, Niluh Djelantik, a Balinese brand that has gone international, and Erika Peña, a jewellery brand with celebrity fans such as Beyonce and Kim Kardashian.

The resort also ties up with Satu to host a monthly fashion show during afternoon tea sessions.

Dario Orsini, Sheraton Kuta's general manager, describes the resort as "a sanctuary on Kuta, but with a mute button. You still have the beach, shopping and nightlife nearby".

No small change

JUST like how a haircut or a new wardrobe can instantly make a person look more refreshed, a change of interiors in a hotel can also give it an updated look.

The 15-year-old Four Seasons Resort Bali at Sayan is a prime example of that. "Our one and two-bedroom villas have always been considered unique in the world," says its general manager, Uday Rao. "The 42 villas have been impeccably maintained since the resort was built, but we wanted to evolve the design to ensure their place among the finest villas in Bali."

Japanese designer Koichi Yasuhiro from Design Studio Spin in Tokyo is behind the villas' new interiors, which are now chic and modern, but with a strong reflection of Balinese architectural style, tradition and culture.

Like before, you see only lily ponds on the ground level, which indicates where the villas are. To get to the villa, you have to go down a flight of steps, which ups the anticipation level.

Whereas the rooms previously looked bland and generic, the feel is now much warmer. In place of a bare wall behind the bed, there is now an intricate carved wooden screen featuring a delicate pattern of leaves and birds with an inlay of traditional ikat fabric. The bed now comes with a sheer white canopy that was previously missing. It doesn't sound like much, but with the ambient lights turned on, the bedroom now takes on a much more romantic feel than before. It is no wonder the resort continues to be popular for weddings and honeymoons.

The recent renovation also meant that little touches which were not considered necessary five years ago, are now in place. For example, opening a drawer on the bedside table reveals several types of chargers built into it, so you can have your smartphones and other devices charging away beside you even when you sleep.

The resort prides itself on its larger than large bathrooms, which now have a more tropical feel. Marble has replaced boring beige tiles, giving the bathrooms a luxurious look. Each villa comes with a private plunge pool, but should you wish for a bubble bath, you can do so in the new marble free-standing tub. For a fee, the resort can draw different types of baths.

Jimbaran Bay beauty

Also cashing in on a new look is The Four Seasons Resort Bali at Jimbaran Bay. Standing in place of PJ's, the resort's former casual restaurant is now the swanky Sundara.

The beachfront restaurant is also designed by Design Studio Spin, and certainly lives up to its name, meaning "beautiful" in the Sanskrit word. If your idea of a perfect holiday is spending the entire day by the beach, this is the place to be.

Set in two Balinese-style pavilions, the two-storey restaurant offers both indoor and outdoor seating. Regardless of whether you choose to sit downstairs or upstairs, you get panoramic views of Jimbaran Bay and the amazing sunset.

The restaurant is headed by Australian Greg Bunt, who owns three restaurants in Brisbane, and has worked in Hong Kong and Macau. The lunch menu comprises lighter choices such as sushi, salads and wood-fired pizzas.

For dinner, pick from the wide selection of grills, such as lobster, mahi mahi and lamb rack, of which Sundara is known for. The 1kg grain fed 200 days boneless rib eye, which is big enough to share among two to three diners, is worth going off the diet for.

You can start the day with breakfast at the resort's other restaurant Taman Wantilan, or choose to dine in their villas.

Then head to Sundara and spend the morning working a tan on the many day beds, with a cocktail or two in hand. The menu boasts 42 cocktails, such as Smoked Berries, made from Bombay Sapphire, Lagavulin 16-year-old single malt scotch and wild berries; and the innocent-sounding Tea Time, made of Ketel One vodka, peach and tea.

After lunch at Sundara, a dip in the 55m-long infinity lap pool sounds just about right. Or chill on the day bed with a book in hand, before dinner.

"Sundara will become a must-see landmark for all of Bali," says Michael Branham, general manager of Four Seasons Resort Bali at Jimbaran Bay. Judging from the many sunseekers spotted at Sundara on a recent visit, Mr Branham is spot on.

site_title: Roof with a view
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Roof with a view

The view of the neighbourhood and its surrounding greenery was what enticed the Lohs to buy the slightly elevated land on which their two-storey house was built. By Tay Suan Chiang

Published

Fri, Oct 25, 2013 · 10:00 PM

YOU would think the best views in the house are from the master bedroom, right? But not in this home.

Andrew Loh and his wife Sharon Seetho allocated prime space in the home for ... an attic and roof terrace. As the two-storey semi-detached home stands on slightly elevated land, the roof terrace offers unblocked views of the neighbourhood off Holland Road and its surrounding greenery. "I knew I had to buy this land when I saw the view," says Mr Loh, a director at a bank.

Ms Seetho adds: "We could have put our bedroom at the back and wake up to this view, but we rather put our entertainment area here, so that everyone can enjoy the space." In contrast, the couple's bedroom on the second floor faces their neighbour across the street.

In the attic is a cosy living area and a small, partially equipped kitchen for doing some light cooking. There is more seating on the roof terrace alongside a dining table that can seat eight. Even when the family is not entertaining friends and relatives, the roof terrace is still frequently used. "Every weekend, we come up here for dinner, sometimes for a BBQ," says Ms Seetho.

While the roof terrace has the best views, the rest of the house isn't too shabby either. On the first floor, the living and dining areas have an almost "doorless" feel. In place of walls, the design team at Wallflower Architecture + Design placed large sliding doors all around. "We usually have these doors open, and with direct access to the driveway, it feels as if there are no doors," says Mr Loh. "The house is very open."

A row of trees have been planted to give the family some privacy. "The trees do double work - not only as a privacy screen, but they help absorb dust that the wind brings in," says Mr Loh.

The couple put much thought into the design of their home. For example, instead of a lap pool, they decided to make do with a smaller one near the entrance, which also doubles as a water feature at night. "This way, we have more deck space for outdoor activities," says Mr Loh. Even though there is enough room for two kitchens, a dry and a wet one, the Lohs decided to just make do with one. A breeze constantly wafts through the kitchen so cooking fumes don't linger.

Even how the space under the stairs should be utilised was thought through. "Typically, you could build storage space there, but that would make the area look too heavy. We wanted something that is more open, so we chose a water feature instead," says Ms Seetho.

The couple and their two children, Shaun and Clare, have their bedrooms on the second floor. Apart from the usual features such as a walk-in wardrobe, and a spacious bathroom, the couple's bedroom has its own loft area, which is used as a study. The study also connects to the attic and roof terrace. There is also a family room on the second floor, where apart from the roof terrace, the Lohs spend most of their time.

On the outside, the house has a multi-layered facade: a combination of glass doors and windows, a veil of operable vertical timber louvres, horizontal aluminium sunscreen and vertically drawn blinds. "These are all different expressions of material and composition but primarily enabling the family to control the amount of sun screening, breeze, and view," says architect Robin Tan. "Sometimes it is not just what the family want to see, but what the neighbours can see of them."

To let in more light into the home, skylights have been strategically placed. The extensive use of large windows and sliding doors also help brighten up the home, while encouraging plenty of natural ventilation all around. "We used to have all the doors open, but now we only open the necessary ones," says Ms Seetho. "Can you imagine when it rains, we will all be running everywhere to close the doors?"

To give the home some warmth, the couple added their personal touch through their choice of artworks and posters that dot the walls. Most, such as the large Vietnamese, lacquered painting in the living room, were purchased during their travels overseas. "We often go into galleries, and should a piece catch our eye and the price is right, we will get it," says Mr Loh.

He also collects smaller items, such as a wooden spice box from Jaipur, and a cow bell from Chiangmai. On display in another part of the home are his father's binoculars, and an old dictograph. "Before my school moved out of its old premises, some of us went around the grounds picking items. I found this dictograph in the science lab," says the former St Joseph Institution student. "It is having these little things around that make a home feel more cosy, and gives it more soul."

site_title: Larger-than-life funnyman
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Larger-than-life funnyman

Rob Schneider, who plays an exaggerated version of himself in his act, says he's a better stand-up comic now than in the past. GEOFFREY EU reports

Published

Thu, Oct 24, 2013 · 10:00 PM

HE'S inhabited a succession of wacky characters and outrageous personas over a 25-year movie and television career but lately, funnyman Rob Schneider - you may know him as Deuce Bigalow, The Hot Chick, the Sensitive Naked Man or maybe even Orgasm Guy - has been tickling live audiences and tackling the comedy world with perhaps his most shocking creation ever: himself.

Or an approximation of the real Rob Schneider anyway - one that has a stash of typically irreverent, sometimes offensive but always humorous observations on topical issues and life in general up his long sleeves.

Schneider has devoted the past four years to relentlessly honing his stand-up skills and will bring his act to Singapore tomorrow when he performs at The Star Theatre.

He was here in 2011 but declares that he's simply a better stand-up comic now - thanks to all the effort he's put into fine-tuning the act.

Developing a style

"Humour is a wonderful way to subvert people to your point of view," says Schneider over the phone from his hotel room in Adelaide, where he was at the tail-end of an Australia tour. "I play an exaggerated version of myself and I just developed a style after awhile. The topical stuff ebbs and flows and then during the part with some basic universal truths, you kind of explain what it is and then exploit it for comedic purposes."

It takes a lot of work to examine the lighter side of life and extract all the humour from a situation, says Schneider. "Mark Twain said explaining humour is a bit like dissecting a frog: all the parts are there but in the end it doesn't jump anymore," he says. "I've been doing nothing but stand-up for four years, that's the only way to get good at it - people need to see you up there."

Schneider's brand of humour may not appeal to everyone but he has no qualms about taking on what he calls "hot-button issues" in order to find bring attention to issues that matter.

His act takes aim at current events as well as American pop culture (such as Mylie Cyrus' sartorial sense, or lack thereof), but it also includes a bit on the Taliban practice of stoning women to death for adultery - the punchline involves using a single pebble instead of many rocks.

"I also have an Oscar Pretorius joke - not a lot of people can pull that off," he says, adding that the audience will let you know if you go over the line. "If you want to be a world comic that's what you have to do, but if you're afraid to offend, you can't be a comedian."

Taking a topic that is somewhat familiar and then going a little further by presenting a what-if scenario and shocking the audience by design - that's the comedian's job, explains Schneider. "It's about digging in and going a bit deeper - but never forget you're there to entertain."

Schneider, who turns 50 next week, is not averse to poking some fun at himself either. "I'm going to get my own special parking space in five years," he says.

On reflection though, he says the half-century mark is a positive milestone. "I'm excited about where I'm at, both in my life and my stand-up act," he notes. "I'm doing this because I love it, and because I want to be the best. It's taken 25 years to get to this - I don't know how much longer I'm going to be doing this but I'm giving it everything I've got."

Schneider credits Chris Rock - a buddy and fellow comedian - with persuading him to go the stand-up route. "Chris Rock talked me into doing this and now I want to give him a run for his money," he laughs, adding that the US comedy scene is in the pink of health at the moment.

"Stand-up comedy is a great art form and there are a lot of great comedians at their peak - they're a little angrier, more bitter, and it makes comedy better."

There's also enough going on in the world to provide stand-up material, he adds. "US democracy is a mess, but it was also invented by people that owned slaves."

Mulling various ideas

Schneider says he admires comedians like Rock, Louis CK, Daniel Tosh and Bill Burr and will continue to focus on his stage act, but his wish list includes a few more chances on the movie go-round as well.

Among the ideas he is mulling over are a story about a taxi driver who connects with a child that is born in his cab and another that reunites a bunch of ageing comedians on the big screen - an Expendables-like comedy.

He acknowledges that some of his films have bombed at the box office and been savaged mercilessly by critics. "If all my movies had worked out, I wouldn't be doing stand-up - but now there's no other place I want to be," says Schneider. "I've had some disappointments, not all my movies have worked and I've had my fights with people but I've mellowed now, like a 25-year-old Bordeaux that's ready to drink - better drink me soon though."

site_title: A cinematic dance production on stage
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A cinematic dance production on stage

Praying Mantis features dancers and video art on flash drive, says CHEAH UI-HOON

Published

Thu, Oct 24, 2013 · 10:00 PM

HAVE memory stick, will travel. A collaboration between a dance choreographer and a film producer resulted in an almost cinematic spectacle of movement on stage with just a few dancers and video art on a flash drive.

Film producer Eva Baro and dance choreographer Matias Martinez's production, Praying Mantis, is a story told with video art, visual effects and light.

"We defend clean technologies and we liked the concept of storing scenery in a memory stick, so that the only physical presence on stage is the dancers and movement, their soul," says Baro.

And their dance production promises to be cinematic, with the cinema music of Armand Amar, cinema photography direction of Reinier Van Brummelen and cinema special effects of David Marti and Montse Ribe.

Praying Mantis is a dance production about a girl in the middle of the Bolivian Salt desert who's saved by a group of praying mantis. Martinez mashes several dance and movement techniques in a style which he personally developed, which emphasises the centre of the body and adapts to the plot of the story that is going on.

"But rather than showing a dance technique or style, we try to bring original stories representing them with dance, video art, music and light all together," says Martinez.

Working on feelings

The two collaborators' starting point was how they wanted the audience to feel, they share.

"Rather than action that was clear from the plot, we worked on the feelings we wanted to show with images, movements, dance, music and special effects. It's been a creative collaboration from the dance point of view and the video point of view," says Baro.

How movement is linked to emotions is a question that has intrigued the film producer. Since technology has made such major changes in society and the way people communicate with one another, she began to see the need for movement even more than ever.

"The real physical experience is becoming a question of survival for humans. We need to move in real life more than ever . . . we need dance," she muses, recalling the creative period she went through thinking about the importance of movement.

Invited by Martinez to help him in a production, she was impressed enough to look for ways to help him express his art form. Dance, for him, he shares, is a corporeal expression of something.

"It's not about movement or style, but choreography is about pulling together everything to take people to another dimension," he shares.

When their project got underway, Baro was inspired by a Zana Brinski picture of a bug which dances in front of its prey before attacking it. "It's like bug's dance of the death. So I started to compare the instinctive dance of insects versus the instinctive/artistic dance of the humans and keep asking why dance and movement makes us so happy," she elaborates.

Sharing beauty with art

"At the end what was clear was that we wanted people to stop for a little moment in their lives and feel, to be aware about the beauty that is still there outside. We all wanted the same thing that is making people happy for a moment in their life provoking ticklish, magical, and positive feelings through art," she says.

Adds Martinez: "We wanted to share beauty with art. There was a script and then from there every creative side contributed with an expression. The production is like a painting with video images and the feelings are in the dance which drives the action."

'Praying Mantis' by Vision of the Dance will be performed tonight and tomorrow night at the Esplanade Theatre. For tickets, go to

site_title: S'pore economy seen expanding: Amex
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

S'pore economy seen expanding: Amex

Published

Thu, Oct 24, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Senior financial executives here believe that the local economy will continue to expand, and benefit their firms, even as challenges abound, according to the American Express Business Momentum Survey 2013.

While the impact of rising labour and property costs on businesses have been making headlines, it seems that more firms are wringing their hands over industry competition, currency volatility and the interest rate environment.

The American Express study was done with 101 senior financial executives from firms with annual sales turnover of US$20-151 million. They were interviewed over the phone in August this year.

Many believe that the general economic environment in Singapore over the next 12 months is positive, with over half saying that the Singapore economy would expand.

Three in 10 think that there would be no change from this year, while 15 per cent expect to see some contraction.

A large number of respondents also think that the economic expansion would trickle down to benefit their firms. Some 42 per cent have positive expectations for their firm's performance over the next 12 months, while another 42 per cent expect it to stay unchanged. About 15 per cent see a contraction.

The survey noted: "Echoing the positive economic outlook, Singapore companies are confident of and positive towards business expansion by riding on the growing business momentum and magnifying their scale through exploring new markets and opening outlets.

"However, the present stable performance and stagnant global economy projected for the next 12 months has caused the same weight of views foreseeing their business performance to stay steady."

As many as 84 per cent of respondents said that industry competition was a key challenge, and 76 per cent expressed worry over the interest rate environment and currency volatility. Ranking third in the list of concerns was labour cost, with about seven in 10 respondents fretting over it. Property cost was in tenth place, with about four in 10 saying that it was an issue.

Andrew Chan, managing director of homegrown food chain The Soup Spoon, said that competition in the food & beverage industry has definitely increased over the last few years.

"We have to be very careful now because the conditions are right for others to come and snatch a bit of the pie. The open economy, the supply of new spaces and the generally high levels of optimism in the industry all mean that almost anyone who wants to open a joint can do so."

The Soup Spoon has tried to set itself apart with store revamps and a healthy eating concept. He added that the competition had also contributed to a manpower crunch in the industry.

Ellen Teo, general manager at liquefied petroleum gas group Union Energy, said that one of the group's key challenge is retaining and hiring staff.

"Industry competition isn't exactly as pressing because ours is a mature industry. The more apparent problem is the manpower crunch."

According to the American Express survey, firms are trying to meet the manpower challenge through a variety of means. These include working to retain talent, such as raising benefits, providing more training to employees, improving and streamlining the work flow, and automating.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

SilverNeedle aiming for 100 properties by 2016

Franchising model introduced, tapping public market a possibility in future

Published

Thu, Oct 24, 2013 · 10:00 PM

TAPPING the capital or public markets would not be out of the question in the future for Singapore-based SilverNeedle Hospitality, which has a goal of having 100 properties in its stable by 2016.

CEO Iqbal Jumabhoy said this on the sidelines of the company's launch of a new franchising business model for one of its hotel brands yesterday.

"Our business is a capital-intensive business, so at a point in time we will obviously be looking for additional capital," he said.

Mr Jumabhoy is no stranger to listed companies, having been executive director at the former Scotts Holdings and having helmed the hospitality arm of Straits Trading Company.

But now, he said that "our focus is on doing the right things right" for the relatively new business, founded in 2010 by the Nadathur Group, an investment firm owned by the co-founder of NASDAQ-listed Infosys Technologies.

This means getting the right management team and building the right operating processes, management systems and infrastructure.

"So we've been working on all of those pieces, working on the right things and getting them right as well," Mr Jumabhoy said.

He said that each of SilverNeedle's six hotel brands, which runs the gamut from economy to luxury hotels, has its own strategy, and he did not think it "unreasonable" to add 40 to 50 more hotels over the next five years. SilverNeedle has around 60 properties under management or licence, with more than 4,000 rooms in the Asia-Pacific.

The introduction of a franchising model for its 23 Country Comfort brand of upper mid-scale hotels, is one such avenue for growth.

SilverNeedle operates on management contracts and brand licensing agreements, and adding a third business model gives hotel owners another option, said Mr Jumabhoy.

For example, they can now own more than one property. Potential suitors can also tap SilverNeedle's investments into areas, such as back-end systems and technology.

"But at the same time they can manage their own destiny through the business," he said.

All the hotels under the Country Comfort brand are in Australia and New Zealand (ANZ). The aim is to extend the brand's reach both within ANZ and out to South Asia, South-east Asia and North Asia.

The introduction of franchising for its Country Comfort hotels will coincide with a revamp of the brand over the next 12 months to focus more on the business traveller.

As part of this transition, Country Comfort hotels will offer more business-focused amenities, such as high-quality beds, free Wi-Fi and local calls, and simple check-in and check-out services.

Current licensees of the brand will continue existing arrangements with SilverNeedle, which will look at whether Country Comfort is still the right fit when the agreements expire.

Even if it is not, Mr Jumabhoy remains confident that there are other brands under SilverNeedle that can serve their needs."We would not want to lose them, so we have alternatives for them; there is no push factor," he said.

site_title: OCBC, UOB said to be courting Wing Hang Bank
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

OCBC, UOB said to be courting Wing Hang Bank

Published

Thu, Oct 24, 2013 · 10:00 PM

OVERSEA-CHINESE Banking Corporation (OCBC) is considering a bid for Wing Hang Bank, with United Overseas Bank (UOB) reportedly also eyeing the Hong Kong bank.

A Bloomberg report said that OCBC has been studying an offer for Wing Hang for more than two weeks.

OCBC declined to comment on the matter.

UOB spokeswoman Tan Ping Ping said: "We are not commenting on market rumours or speculation."

CIMB head of research Kenneth Ng said: "It's not totally surprising that the two Singapore banks are rumoured as potential interested parties in Wing Hang." He added that they would be keen to acquire a controlling stake.

"Although the profitability of Wing Hang is not the most attractive, it will allow them to expand into Hong Kong . . . to participate in the offshore yuan market, the growth of China and the rise of wealth management opportunities," Mr Ng said.

For the first half of this year, Wing Hang, one of Hong Kong's four remaining family-owned banks, posted a net profit of HK$1 billion (S$160.8 million), 1.8 per cent lower than a year ago. It has a market capitalisation of about HK$36 billion.

The bank, controlled by the Fung family, said last month that it was in discussions to sell a significant stake. The Bank of New York Mellon Corp is its second-biggest shareholder. Together, the Fung family and BNY Mellon control about 45 per cent of the bank.

OCBC, South-east Asia's second-biggest lender, has invested about $1.5 billion in China so far - one of the three areas of focus for the bank outside its core Singapore market - chief executive Samuel Tsien said at the opening of the bank's China headquarters in Shanghai last month. The other key markets are Malaysia and Indonesia.

The bank's presence in China dates back to 1925 with the opening of a branch in Xiamen. Following local incorporation in 2007, it now has 16 branches and sub-branches across nine cities, up from five branches and representative offices.

UOB, Singapore's third biggest bank by assets, opened a foreign direct investment advisory unit in Hong Kong last month. The bank said it plans to double its cross-border business between Hong Kong and South-east Asian companies within the next three years on rising intra-regional trade flows within emerging Asia.

Acquiring a stake in Wing Hang will allow the two banks to expand their operations in Greater China, which accounts for 5 per cent of OCBC's profits before tax and 9 per cent of UOB's in the first half of this year.

Rival DBS Group receives close to 30 per cent of its pre-tax profits from Greater China.

Wartsila's Q3 profit rises to 138m euros

Published

Thu, Oct 24, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[HELSINKI] Finnish ship and power plant engine maker Wartsila posted a stronger-than-expected rise in quarterly profit on higher spending by shipping clients and solid demand from power plants.

Though Wartsila said its order book has taken a hit from some customers delaying investment decisions, its escape from the sharp deterioration experienced by other Finnish industrials amid Europe's prolonged economic downturn lifted its shares 4 per cent by 0815 GMT.

Third-quarter operating profit, excluding one-off items, rose to 138 million euros (S$236 million) from 113 million euros a year earlier, beating the average forecast of 132 million euros in a Reuters poll of analysts. A 14 per cent drop in orders, however, prompted the company to trim its 2013 sales growth forecast to between zero per cent and 5 per cent from the previous estimate of up to 10 per cent.

"Uncertainties in the global economy and fluctuations in emerging market currencies have caused power plant customers to delay decision-making, which has impacted our overall order intake," chief executive Bjorn Rosengren said.

But Wartsila also noted an improving outlook among shipping and shipbuilding clients, forecasting strong orders for product tankers, large container ships and gas carriers to continue through the year.

It also said demand for services in the power plant segment remains good, though global economic uncertainty is weighing on the power generation market itself. - Reuters

site_title: US flood insurance sinks homes
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

US flood insurance sinks homes

Big jump in premium sparked by new federal rule has led to a fall in home prices in flood zones

Published

Thu, Oct 24, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[TALLAHASSEE, Florida] RANGEL Dockery and her husband bought a waterfront house in Florida four months ago, assuming their US$2,000-a-year flood insurance premium would remain about the same. After reading recently about a change in the federal flood programme, they checked on next year's rates and were stunned: Their bill will grow to US$14,000 annually.

Now the elementary school teacher and her husband Clint, an information technology specialist, are considering selling their two-bedroom St Pete Beach home, probably at a loss, because she said they can't afford the bill, and their mortgage requires flood coverage.

"It was very frustrating to finally have what we've worked hard for all of our life," Ms Dockery, 52, said. "I feel like the rules were changed in the middle of the game. And unfortunately, we can't play by the new rules."

Monthly premiums for more than one million homeowners are set to increase due to a rewrite by the US Congress last year of the federal flood insurance programme. As a result, home prices in flood zones around the country are declining as potential buyers baulk at the premiums, said Moe Veissi, a Miami real estate agent who led the Chicago-based National Association of Realtors last year.

Federal flood insurance covers US$1.3 trillion of property in all 50 states, with Florida, Texas, Louisiana, California and New Jersey making up two-thirds of all policies, according to Federal Emergency Management Agency, which runs the programme.

About 85 private insurance companies contract with Fema to administer the flood programme, including Northbrook, Illinois-based Allstate Corp and Columbus, Ohio-based Nationwide Mutual Insurance Co.

Consumer groups, governors and mortgage bankers are calling on Congress to reverse the law, which was designed to reduce the National Flood Insurance Programme's growing debt. The measure, called the Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform Act of 2012, phases in rate increases for the 20 per cent of policyholders who have been receiving federal subsidies on premiums.

Some of those subsidies began disappearing or shrinking on Oct 1, 15 months after the law passed with bipartisan support.

States are searching for ways to reduce homeowners' bills. In Florida, home to 37 per cent of the nation's 5.6 million flood policies, state lawmakers are trying to attract private companies to write flood policies and are considering starting a state-based flood insurance pool.

Mississippi sued the federal government to stop the rate increases, saying the US failed to study the economic impact. Louisiana is preparing to sue. Massachusetts attorney general Martha Coakley proposed legislation this month to cap the amount of insurance lenders can require.

Bills pending in the US House and Senate to delay rate increases have bipartisan support, mostly from lawmakers in coastal states. Research groups that advocate market-based policies, such as Heritage Action for America and the R Street Institute, have urged members of Congress to leave the measure in place.

The law is an an "appropriate" way to restore financial viability to the programme, and it makes sense to ask those with the greatest risk to pay more, said RJ Lehmann, senior fellow for the Washington-based R Street Institute, in a statement. Mr Lehmann helped write the law sponsored by Representatives Maxine Waters, a California Democrat, and Judy Biggert, an Illinois Republican, who lost the November election.

Ms Waters, who said she never expected the bill she sponsored to cause large rate increases, is now working to delay its implementation. "When I agreed to co-author this legislation, our goal was to create a bipartisan solution to repair our National Flood Insurance Programme," Ms Waters said in a Sept 30 statement. "Neither Democrats nor Republicans envisioned it would reap the kind of harm and heartache that may result from this law going into effect."

Louisiana property assessments on homes in flood zones have already dropped by as much as 30 per cent because of the new flood rules, said Michael Hecht, president of Greater New Orleans Inc, an economic development organisation. Mr Hecht's group has been using such stories to warn lawmakers to change the law. "Owners will lose everything, values of unsellable properties will plummet, bank mortgages will go into default, local tax bases will erode, and economies will be eviscerated," according to material distributed by Greater New Orleans.

Buyers flee

Homebuyers are walking away from contracts when they see the insurance costs, said Ross Miller, who owns a mortgage brokerage in Metairie. In parts of Plaquemines Parish, a coastal community on the Gulf of Mexico, neighbourhoods will have insurance premiums of US$10,000 to US$25,000 a year, Mr Miller said. "What do they think people are going to do?" he said.

Ms Dockery said she and her husband moved from a 2,200-square-foot home inland to a property half its size in June, drawn to the barrier island on Florida's west coast.

Their son had moved out of the old house for college and they expect to retire in the next five to 10 years, she said. "We absolutely love it, and it would be very difficult to have to sell," she said. "It's the lifestyle we were looking forward to."

Ms Dockery said they never would have bought the US$400,000 home if they knew insurance rates would increase so rapidly. The property is assessed by Pinellas County, which includes St Pete Beach, at about US$521,600.

Some house hunters in the area have already begun blacklisting neighbourhoods where rates are rising, said Wendy Lockhart, a St Petersburg, Florida, real estate agent. Ms Lockhart is struggling to sell her own home after quotes for the insurance premium went from about US$1,000 to US$8,105.

"We were getting five or six showings a week," she said. "Then when all this started hitting the front pages about three weeks ago, we've had no showings."

Realtors in the St Petersburg area, which has more than 50,000 subsidised policies, have taken up a marketing pitch for homes that don't lie in flood zones: "No flood insurance required!"

Karen Hoyt, a physical therapist who is preparing to move from Colorado to St Pete Beach, said the insurance rates she's seen have discouraged her from buying. "We're going to rent for a year and see what happens," Ms Hoyt said.

Under the law, those who bought homes after July 2012 became ineligible for subsidies after Oct 1. The flood insurance programme amassed more than US$20 billion in debt after Hurricane Katrina slammed into New Orleans in 2005 and it borrowed more after superstorm Sandy hit the East Coast in 2012.

Under the law, owners of vacation homes began to lose federal subsidies in January, with annual rate increases of 25 per cent until reaching full price. Beginning Oct 1, subsidies for businesses and primary homes began being phased out. Those who buy homes in flood zones or sign up for new policies won't be eligible for subsidies.

Subsidies have kept rates as low as 10 per cent of the actual cost. Fema is reassessing its risk calculations, drawing flood maps that will bring higher rates to some areas.

If the Florida legislature finds ways to give homeowners more options for flood insurance, that may pressure lawmakers in Washington to reduce rates, said Florida state Senator David Simmons, the Republican chairman of the banking and insurance committee. Florida policyholders have paid US$16 billion into the federal programme over the last 35 years, while taking out about US$4.5 billion in claims, he said.

"We're the ones who are subsidising the entire National Flood Insurance Programme," Mr Simmons said. - Bloomberg

JAL may sue govt over allocation of airport landing slots, says CEO

Airline seeks govt reply after rival ANA receives more slots

Published

Thu, Oct 24, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[TOKYO] Japan Airlines (JAL) reserves the right to sue the Japanese government for favouring rival ANA Holdings by allocating it more landing slots, JAL's president told Reuters yesterday, raising the prospect of an unprecedented battle that could batter the nation's airline industry.

Asking a court to force the government to review its recent allocation would be a rare step for a Japanese company, especially one that once enjoyed cozy ties with politicians and regulators but which has fallen out of favour of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's one-year-old administration.

"It's one of the steps we might take in the future," said Yoshiharu Ueki, when asked if legal action was one possibility.

Mr Ueki said that his company had asked the government to give a satisfactory explanation for the landing rights handout, which saw ANA receive more than twice as many of the prized international slots at Haneda airport than JAL.

The government, which had previously always divided slots equally between the two airlines, is expected to respond to JAL as soon as today, but Mr Ueki said that JAL was extremely dissatisfied with the process so far.

"There are times when you will take actions because you are trying to achieve a particular result, and sometimes you will take actions even knowing that you might not be able to get a particular result," Mr Ueki said. "Sometimes things have to be said, sometimes things have to be done," he said at JAL's Tokyo headquarters.

In what became a politically charged battle over the landing rights at the Tokyo hub, Japan's aviation regulators on Oct 2 awarded JAL five new Haneda slots compared with 11 for ANA.

Two days later, JAL filed its first ever formal request for the government to clarify its rationale for the allocation of the slots, which are worth around US$20 million a year in operating profit.

Aviation officials argued that they needed to level the playing field for the airlines after a US$3.5 billion state-led bailout waived most of JAL's debt and gave it a competitive advantage over ANA.

ANA lobbied hard for a bigger share of the landing rights, winning the sympathy of Mr Abe's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, which was in opposition when JAL was rescued.

Mr Ueki said that the government's decision was opaque and irrational, and left key points unexplained. The resulting uncertainty is preventing JAL from planning its flight schedule for next summer and hindering its mid to long-term business plan, he added.

In another historic move, JAL ordered 31 Airbus A350 jets, declining for the first time to buy from Boeing. JAL and ANA have traditionally bought from the US manufacturer in what was seen as essentially an extension of the close US-Japan security alliance.

JAL went with the European maker, Mr Ueki said, in part because it was worried about the risk of being a launch customer for new aircraft, a commitment it would have had to make had it opted to pick the Boeing 777X.

JAL's fleet planning, he said, would next turn to replacing its older Boeing 737 jets. The carrier, which owns 30 of the single-aisle aircraft, will consider proposals from both Boeing and Airbus, Mr Ueki said. - Reuters

site_title: Chef executive officers for a day
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Chef executive officers for a day

Dylan Tan

Published

Thu, Oct 24, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The occasion was the launch of a book profiling the best of Singapore street food stalls beloved by the captains of industry here.

Some among the 200 guests - including chief executive officers (CEOs) of private and public agencies - at the convivial event had to "work" for their dinner, so to speak.

Minister for the Environment and Water Resources Vivian Balakrishnan, for example, showed he could make teh tarik as guests around him broke into laughter at his effort. A few other CEOs flipped roti prata as cameras flashed.

The CEOs' Hawker Guide, the slim volume that was the reason for last night's event, is a collaboration of The Business Times and Knight Frank Pte Ltd. A follow-up to the first edition published in 2010, the book makes its debut against the backdrop of a rather more serious issue - that of the uncertain future of Singapore's hawker traditions as the culinary masters approach retirement with no clear succession plans.

As Alvin Tay, Editor of The Business Times, put it: "Together with Knight Frank, we hope to use this book as a springboard for discussion and action - to promote the hawker profession as not just a noble one, but comfortable and even fashionable as well."

The "action" he mentioned was a reference to the book's mission - to raise money for a fund to help young people pick up hawker skills through a Business Times and Knight Frank initiative called Project Hawkerpreneur.

The book is not for sale, but for a minimum donation of $20 donors will receive a complimentary copy. More than $100,000 has already been raised, and a target of $300,000 has been set.

The book features the hawker food series published in the weekend edition of The Business Times between September 2012 and April 2013, as well as new exclusive content. To put the book together, 10 top executives, including Singapore Press Holdings CEO Alan Chan, Ambassador-at-Large in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Professor Tommy Koh and Kwek Leng Peck, executive director of Hong Leong Asia, each came up with a list of their 10 preferred stalls in various hawker food categories. The list was then sent to The Business Times' database of Who's Who in Singapore business, for them to vote for their favourites.

Also at the book launch, hosted by UBS and held at the UBS Business University Asia-Pacific Command House last night, were hawkers such as Casuarina Curry, Haron Satay, 328 Laksa, Tian Tian Chicken Rice, 968 Popiah, No 18 Zion Road Char Kway Teow and Founder Bak Kut Teh serving up their signature dishes.

The guests included Ronnie Tay, CEO of the National Environment Agency (NEA); Chong Siak Ching, CEO of the National Art Gallery; Tan Kian Chew, group CEO of NTUC FairPrice; and Chong Kee Hiong, CEO of OUE Hospitality Reit Management.

Edmund Koh, Singapore country head and CEO of UBS Wealth Management South East Asia and the Asia-Pacific hub, said: "Food is an important part of life in Singapore. . . The launch of the CEOs' Hawker Guide 2013 is a wonderful celebration of the street food tradition we have here."

Under the Project Hawkerpreneur initiative, YMCA, the beneficiary, will put aspiring hawkerpreneurs through the Hawker Master Trainer Pilot Programme set up by the Singapore Workforce Development Agency and the NEA. Aimed at encouraging entrepreneurship and preserving a piece of Singapore's street food culture, the initiative has already enlisted veteran hawkers to pass on their culinary skills to the participants who sign up for the programme. The target: To develop hawkers for the 10 new hawker centres to be built by 2017.

Knight Frank's executive chairman Tan Tiong Cheng said: "There is now an urgency to promote and ensure this cultural heritage remains alive. . . I believe the funds raised from the guide book will, in a small way, bring the need to preserve our unique food culture into sharp focus and encourage more Singaporeans into the trade."

For information on the Hawker Master Trainer Pilot Programme, please visit www.wda.gov.sg. Own a copy of The 'CEOs' Hawker Guide' with a donation of at least S$20.

All cheques to be made out to 'Knight Frank/BT Charity A/C'

site_title: Singapore CIOs need to adapt to IT changes
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Singapore CIOs need to adapt to IT changes

Listen to this article

Published Thu, Oct 24, 2013 · 10:00 PM

IBM's CEO, Ginni Rometty, noted in Singapore recently that the world is witnessing a historic convergence of technology shifts with a combination of mobile, social, cloud and inter-connected devices. This is having a profound impact on enterprises, many of which are struggling with the issue of BYOD (bring your own device) and the extensive use of non-corporate apps such as Gmail and Evernote. The question is, are Singapore's chief information officers (CIOs) ready for this tectonic shift with the right set of policies? There used to be a saying that you can't get fired for choosing Microsoft. While this may still hold true, the new complexity that technology has brought in has made the task of CIOs that much harder and resistance to change is not an option. As Khoong Hock Yun, assistant CEO (Infrastructure and Services Development) of Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore, said last week at a roundtable organised by BT, a good organisation-wide mobile strategy needs to strike the right balance between usability, cost and security.

Microsoft has been the long-standing incumbent in the enterprise applications space. However, viable alternatives have emerged thanks to the same technology trends alluded to by Ms Rometty. Google offers its cloud-based Google Docs and email service as a low-cost alternative to Microsoft's cash cows, Office and Outlook. Google's Chromebook - a notebook running on its Chrome OS (operating system) which essentially puts everything in the cloud - has become quite popular and can be bought for as little as $300. A combination of low-cost hardware and excellent cloud services - available for a small fee - that run on any machine or OS makes Google a viable alternative for many small businesses at least. At its big event earlier this week, Apple officially put its hat into the ring by offering its Mac OS and iLife and iWork suit of apps for free to users who buy its hardware. While iLife is a suite of mainly creative apps for Mac OS and iOS devices, iWork is Apple's answer to Microsoft's Office. Combined with its push of the popular iPad into the enterprise through BYOD, Apple has now made a strong case for iWork for the enterprise.

To be sure, Microsoft Office is far more feature-rich than the Apple or Google counterparts. However, the two competitors are setting an example that software and OS should come for free and storage should be in the cloud and not on devices. Microsoft generates around 96 per cent of its operating margins from its OS and productivity software and so this move would certainly be a cause for concern for the Redmond, Washington-based company. It is responding to the challenge in its own way, by shifting most of its software into cloud-based services and producing new types of devices such as the Surface tablet.

site_title: Keep a wary eye on inflation
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Keep a wary eye on inflation

Published

Wed, Oct 23, 2013 · 10:00 PM

SINGAPORE's latest inflation figures - a markedly lower- than-expected headline rate of 1.6 per cent in September - would seem to assuage concerns about rising price pressures amid a soft growth outlook. But more likely than not, the dip last month will turn out to be a blip in an uptrend.

High and rising costs of healthcare, housing and (in particular) transport continued to drive the consumer price index (CPI) this year, raising it 2.8 per cent in the first six months. Domestic cost issues in a labour-tight economy, coupled with a bigger concern over imported inflationary pressures, in fact kept the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) hand in at its recent October monetary policy review, with the Singapore dollar maintained on an appreciating path with no change in the slope, width and centre of the policy band. And arguably, despite the encouraging September CPI report - the market had expected the inflation rate to be maintained at August's 2 per cent - the risks of rising price pressures haven't dissipated. Indeed, if anything, the signs point to a pick-up in the inflation measures in the months ahead.

What stands out in September's CPI numbers is the decline in transport costs - specifically, private road transport costs fell 2 per cent in the month, driven no doubt by fluctuations in vehicle certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums. Financing restrictions on motor vehicle loans introduced in February led to corrections in COE premiums in the ensuing months. But subsequent policy decisions since - particularly plans to regroup cars in the COE categories, taking into account engine power output as well - have resulted in swings in the vehicle premiums, mostly upwards, as buyers seek to pre-empt the changes. In fact, compared to August, car prices were actually higher in September. In any case, underlying the CPI transport figures over the past 12 months or so has been a high base effect that will soon run out, in fact from October.

The other key driver of domestic price pressures are manpower costs, given the tight labour market and restrictions on the hiring of foreigners across the lower and middle levels of the workforce. While employers and business owners brace themselves for rising labour costs, business rentals or pricier commercial vehicles, these higher costs will eventually pass on down to the consumer. For the year to September, Singapore's inflation rate stands at 2.5 per cent; some economists expect it to cross 3 per cent in the coming months and possibly touch 4 per cent by mid-2014. Even the official core inflation (excluding accommodation and private road transport) - 1.6 per cent for the first nine months of 2013 - is expected to rise to perhaps 3 per cent in 2014.

Singapore may have withstood higher inflation in the past, but with the economy looking at another year in the fairly subdued 2.5-3.5 per cent growth range, the need to keep a lid on rising cost pressures should be amply clear.

site_title: Apple freebies may cost Microsoft dearly
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Apple freebies may cost Microsoft dearly

Published

Wed, Oct 23, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Amid the hubbub over the improvements to its tablets unveiled on Tuesday, Apple slipped in an interesting announcement that could be quite a game changer over the medium to long term - one that could hit Microsoft.

This was that its Mac OSX software will be free for download to anyone who has bought an Apple computer since 2007. Its iMovie, Garageband and the productivity suite iWork - a rival to Microsoft's Office - will now be free with a new Apple Mac.

Commenting on this, Jan Dawson, chief telecoms analyst at Ovum, said: "Microsoft generates 96 per cent of its operating margins from its operating system and productivity software licensing. Apple is now teaching people to expect both of those things to be free. While this won't disrupt Microsoft's business overnight, it will create further pressure on Microsoft to bring down prices for its productivity software and especially for Windows."

He said that just as Google uses advertising revenue to fund its software and services, Apple is now using its hardware to subsidise its software across the board. "The big question is: What can Microsoft do to compete, when its cash cow is being eroded by these moves from its competitors?"

This has been a watershed year for the tablet market: For the first time, the Android operating system (OS) overtook Apple's iOS as the dominant tablet platform.

Information technology research and advisory company Gartner noted that Android's market share is 49.6 per cent, and that of iOS, 48.6 per cent; last year, Android was at 44.9 per cent and iOS, 53.9 per cent.

For Apple, therefore, the success of its two tablets - iPad and iPad Mini - is key, since it would not want a repetition of what happened in the smartphone market, where Android, once it overtook iOS, raced ahead to corner nearly 80 per cent marketshare, leaving Apple's share in the low to mid-teens.

Avinash K Sundaram, IDC Asia-Pacific's senior market analyst, told The Business Times that Apple's commitment to deliver the Retina-class iPad Mini as early as in the last quarter of this year "was a pleasant surprise" and signalled the Apple camp's urgency in regaining its grip on the tablet market.

He said: "While these new launches will help Apple regain some lost ground in the short term, longer-term though, Android will continue to chip away at Apple's share, especially as players in this eco-system continue to bring out similar products at much lower price points."

Gartner vice-president of research Carolina Milanesi pointed out, however, that Android's market share comes from lower-end devices. "We need to account for that when judging the success Android has had over iOS."

Thomas Husson, vice-president and principal analyst for marketing and strategy at global research and advisory firm Forrester, said that Apple is best placed to maintain its premium positioning, and Android to capture the mass-market, given that its OS is open to a wider range of original equipment maker partners.

"It is just the beginning for Microsoft, but it has stronger assets in the business space. That said, by offering free OS software (OS X Mavericks for Macs) and services (iWork and others), Apple can play a strong role in the business space, thanks to its Bring Your Own Devices (BYOD) developments."

Ms Milanesi added: "iOS will be more high-end than Android and it will also be about enterprise, but still, more a mix between BYOD and enterprise versus Microsoft, which will remain mainly enterprise-focused."

site_title: COE premiums fall across the board
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

COE premiums fall across the board

Published

Wed, Oct 23, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] COE premiums ran out of steam after the strong surge two weeks ago and fell across the board in yesterday's second bidding exercise for October.

A Category A certificate of entitlement - used to register cars below 1,600cc - sank $8,111 to $76,889, while Cat B - for cars above 1,600cc - slipped $5,590 to $87,910.

Cat E - the open category which currently tracks Cat B - dropped less, just $1,600 to $92,289.

Meanwhile, Cat C - for goods vehicles - was $8,308 lower at $68,002, and Cat D - for motorcycles - inched $157 down to $1,804.

"The correction was expected," said the managing director of a luxury dealership. "Premiums were pushed too high for customers' comfort after the last bidding cycle and the market has been quiet since."

He said most people in the motor industry had expected the adjustment in the Cat A premium.

"The Cat A luxury market is saturated," he explained. "Those who can afford to buy have already bought. As for those whose cars are still on order, stock only arrives next year, so there's no rush to bid for a COE."

The managing director's last remark was a reference to the Mercedes-Benz CLA-Class, whose 1.6-litre model is said to have sparked the recent surge in the Cat A premium.

As for the Cat B premium, he said there was some uncertainty initially about its direction because its spike in the previous tender had been attributed to a luxury brand's aggressive bidding. But as it turned out, he was pleasantly surprised by its almost $5,600 drop.

"I thought it would be plus or minus $2,000 to $3,000," he said.

But it was the Cat E premium that caught most off-guard. It jumped from about $70,000 to $90,000 with half an hour left to the end of the tender, when the other categories were still at $1.

"I understand one of the luxury brands is stocking up on Cat E COEs to make a final sales push at the end of the year and top the market rankings," he said.

Looking ahead, he believes the Cat A premium will rebound because mass market car buyers, who have been on the sidelines, will return to the showrooms.

"There are many Japanese and Korean car buyers who have been priced out of the market and are just waiting for the right time to come in," he said.

As for Cat B, he believes it will also rise again. His reason?

"Cat E has set the pace, so Cat B has no choice but to follow it."

content:

TDSR hit Singapore buyers harder than foreigners

Listen to this article

Kalpana Rashiwala

Published Thu, Oct 24, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) framework seems to have had a bigger impact on private home purchases by Singaporeans than on foreign buyers.

Private home purchases by all categories of buyers took a hit in the quarter following the introduction of the TDSR in late-June, but foreigners posted the smallest percentage drop of 39.1 per cent - compared with declines of 51 per cent for Singaporean buyers and 44 per cent for PRs. This was not unexpected, as the TDSR framework (under which financial institutions are required to take a borrower's total debt servicing obligations into account when granting property loans) was targeted at Singaporeans rather than at foreigners.

In contrast, the initial rollout of the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) back in December 2011 had a much bigger impact on foreign buyers. Then, the number of caveats they lodged for the purchase of private homes tanked 73.5 per cent quarter-on-quarter, according to a caveats analysis by DTZ.

site_title: Microsoft cash cow getting squeezed
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Microsoft cash cow getting squeezed

Listen to this article

Published Wed, Oct 23, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] Apple's giveaways are a jab at Microsoft. Mac users won't have to pay to upgrade to the latest operating system, the company said at its event on Tuesday. Those who buy a new product won't pay for work software like spreadsheets or creative photo and movie packages - on the device or in the cloud. In short, Apple, like Google, is training users to expect software to be free. For Microsoft, that's a problem.

The iPhone and iPad maker uses software to sell premium hardware, so its approach makes sense. Macs are pricier than entry-level PCs. And the company led by Tim Cook is forgoing only a small chunk of revenue. Even including the hugely popular iTunes with its paid-for content, software and services accounted for less than 10 per cent of the company's revenue in the first nine months of the year. Those already sold on the advantages of Apple's products will get a slightly cheaper meal. Having all the software thrown in may also attract new customers.

Google started this fire with its free Android operating system for mobile phones as well as its calendars, word processing capability and other online software. Google's method is slightly different - it uses advertising sales to subsidise the creation and distribution of these programs. But from their different angles, both the search giant and Apple are well on the way to making sure users get used to free software.
