site_title: Keppel thrives despite tough environment
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Keppel thrives despite tough environment

Published

Mon, Oct 21, 2013 · 10:00 PM

KEPPEL Corp's recent strong set of quarterly results should position the group to achieve projected FY2013 net profit of $1.5 billion, which falls within the mean full-year estimates of the top 10 equities research firms covering the stock. Not surprisingly, most analysts have maintained their "buy" rating on the stock.

After the results were announced last Thursday, the stock gained six cents on Friday to close at $10.87. Analysts are projecting Keppel's FY2014 and FY2015 earnings to push upwards to $1.63 billion and $1.66 billion, and have a median stock price target of $12.50, a 15-per cent upside from Friday's close.

This vote of confidence is hard-earned, as investors and key shareholders are well aware of the competitive environment within which the group operates. In the offshore and marine division, for instance, both South Korean and Chinese shipyards are bidding aggressively for offshore rig-building contracts to fill shipyards suffering from a dearth of commercial shipbuilding contracts.

Yet Keppel's offshore & marine margins (which analysts watch like hawks) remain robust with operating profit margins at 16.5 per cent in Q3 2013, up from 14 to 14.2 per cent in Q1 2013 and Q2 2013, and 12.9 per cent in Q4 2012 - an indication that the group had kept a lid on costs and is still able to price its rigs competitively.

On top of that, the group has secured an enviable $5 billion of new offshore rigbuilding contracts year to date, bringing its total orderbook to $13.7 billion with deliveries into 2019. A good part of these new orders have come from repeat, long-term customers such as Ensco, Diamond, Maersk, Pemex and Sete Brasil. This is a strong endorsement of the group's capabilities and track record. Its yards in Singapore, Brazil and Azerbaijan now have 21 jack-ups drilling rigs, six semi-submersibles, three accommodation semi and numerous FPSO newbuild and conversions to deliver over the next five years. To sustain earnings, the group needs to continue to replenish its orderbook with at least $4 billion-$5 billion of new contracts every year.

Keppel's key shareholders have been an equally loyal lot. Apart from Temasek which still holds 21 per cent of the stock, its top shareholders' list reads like the Who's Who of asset management firms with Aberdeen topping the list, followed by Blackrock, Fidelity, Invesco and Capital. Keppel's solid balance sheet, strong core earnings, attractive dividend yields and management track record have ensured its position as a key holding.

But these expectations would weigh heavily on any management team, let alone one where a new CEO is being groomed to take over in three months' time.

That is why Keppel's July announcement that the group's current CFO, Loh Chin Hua, had been picked as CEO-designate took many in the investment community by surprise.

Firstly, the group's previous CEOs or executive chairman (in the days of Sim Kee Boon and Lim Chee Onn) when recruited were already long-serving leaders, rising from the ranks and successful top managers in various operational divisions. For instance, Mr Lim had been Keppel Land's chairman and managing director since 1997, and a director of Keppel FELS and was Keppel's senior executive director since 1983, when he was appointed as Keppel Group's executive chairman in January 2000.

When current CEO Choo Chiau Beng was appointed as group CEO in January 2009, he had held the position of CEO of Keppel Offshore and Marine for almost 25 years.

It was under Mr Lim's stewardship that Keppel sold its stake in KeppelTatLee Bank to OCBC, and then merged and privatised Keppel FELS, Keppel Shipyard and Keppel Hitachi Zosen under the listed holding company, and establishing offshore marine, property and infrastructure as the three core group divisions.

Under Mr Choo's stewardship, the group divested its stake in Singapore Petroleum Company and established K-Green Trust. Meanwhile, a combination of new rig building orders, fuelled by rising oil prices and a booming property market, boosted the group's net profits from $1.2 billion in FY2009 to a record $2.2 billion last year.

Given the track record and calibre of the previous CEOs, it would be an understatement to say that Mr Loh will have big boots to fill. But he is no newbie either.

Mr Loh started his career at Keppel as head of Keppel Land's fund management business under Alpha Investment Partners in 2002, and grew its assets to $10.6 billion todate. Prior to that he was MD at Prudential Investment Management, and at GIC. He was appointed group CFO in January 2012, and will have held the position for just two years before he becomes group CEO.

When he takes over the helm in January, the Keppel group is expected to achieve near peak earnings (excluding exceptionals). The key earnings drivers would still be its offshore & marine and property divisions, with infrastructure a distant third.

There is a saying that the CEO's job is a lonely one. But at Keppel, a culture of teamwork and mentoring at the top has ensured continuity remains a strong tradition. It is perhaps telling that in its December 2008 announcement that Mr Lim would step down and Mr Choo would assume the CEO position, it was also announced that Tong Chong Heong would be promoted to CEO of Keppel Offshore and Marine. In the past five years, Mr Tong has been Mr Choo's right hand man in building up Keppel Offshore and Marine.

In keeping with tradition, Keppel revealed that 32-year offshore & marine veteran Chow Yew Yuen would succeed Mr Tong as CEO from Feb 1, 2014.

However, Mr Loh's upcoming promotion will leave an important vacancy which Keppel's board will need to fill. So far, no announcement has been made, but presumably the kingmakers at Keppel are lining up the candidates.

site_title: OSV supply overload feared as shipbuilders enter market
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

OSV supply overload feared as shipbuilders enter market

Published

Sun, Oct 20, 2013 · 10:00 PM

OVERSUPPLY is growing in the offshore marine sector as more traditional shipbuilders shift their focus towards building offshore support vessels (OSVs) to overcome the poor demand in their own market.

One industry player feels that this trend, particularly with Chinese yards jumping on the OSV bandwagon, could potentially send the offshore industry down the road of a supply overload, as was experienced by the traditional shipbuilding market.

Alex Yeo, chief executive of mainboard-listed Swissco Holdings, sounded out this caution even though he noted that the OSV market is more resilient than the traditional ship market, and therefore better prepared to weather such a setback.

"We should be very cautious about traditional shipbuilders entering the OSV market because it seems that it could potentially be a bubble building. Yes, OSV seems to be a bit more resilient in the shipbuilding environment but if everybody is to shift the focus, we would again have a supply overhang," he warned.

Mr Yeo added that the shipbuilding industry should have learnt its lesson post-2008, which marked a period when an excess supply of ships, particularly from state-backed yards in China, flooded the market and coincided with a drop in demand of cargo due to the global economic crisis.

He emphasised that the industry should exercise more caution in flooding the market with vessels but his concerns are also based on the view that traditional shipbuilding is still in choppy waters. "Even though the Baltic Dry Index has improved a little bit, a slight pick-up does not mean that we are out of the woods yet and the numbers show that conventional shipping has not recovered yet."

The situation is even more dire in China, suggested Mr Yeo as he believes that the shipbuilding industry there has a long road ahead to recovery, given that it is still dealing with the excess capacity that it created.

"The China shipbuilding industry is disastrous at the moment. The China state government has come out to say that at least one-third of the shipyards must close or consolidate and they need to cut that overhang," he said.

Still, he feels that vessel builders around the world, including in Singapore, could benefit from the situation the Chinese yards find themselves in, by leveraging on the cost advantage there and to gain a foothold in what he believes could be the most important offshore and marine player going forward.

Swissco itself has been building vessels in China for more than a decade, he said. "There is no doubt that the world's shipbuilding industry has to always shift to a lower-cost centre, in terms of lower labour costs. China has been one of the most cost-efficient places to build vessels in the last 20 years. The Europeans, and not only the Asians, are also moving there. It is definitely going to be the number one shipbuilder in the world."

He is certain that this will be the case and as a result, Mr Yeo said that Singapore yards will definitely find China an enormous challenge. "Singapore yards are doing well right now as they are more specialised and are building specialised rigs, but it is only a question of time before the Chinese yards start doing it. It is all a cycle."

But the China factor could also be a blessing, Mr Yeo concluded, as the lower prices the yards there offer also puts pressure on local industry players here and is a "wake up call for them to be more competitive".

site_title: OKH Global plans to divest IT business
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

OKH Global plans to divest IT business

Shareholders to get units in firm holding the business

Published

Tue, Oct 22, 2013 · 10:00 PM

INDUSTRIAL property developer OKH Global plans to dispose of its IT business, which is separated from its core business, following a $123 million reverse takeover of Chinese technology firm Sinobest.

The company will divest itself of two units: Guangzhou Sinobest Information Technology and Sinobest Technologies (HK).

"The proposed distribution allows the company to dispose of the IT business, which has low return on equity," OKH said in a statement yesterday.

To do so, OKH intends to set up an intermediate holding company in the British Virgin Islands and transfer the shares it holds in the subsidiaries to the new company. In return, OKH will receive new shares in the holding company under a restructuring exercise.

Subsequently, OKH will undertake a reduction of the issued and fully paid-up share capital of the company and distribute all the shares it owns in the holding company to its shareholders rather than distributing cash.

"The proposed distribution will enable the company to return value to shareholders free of payment," OKH said.

OKH's shareholders will then hold shares in two separate companies: OKH and the holding company. The distribution will be made on the basis of one holding company share for every share held in OKH. Shares in the holding company will not be listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX).

Shareholders who do not wish to own unlisted shares of the holding company can choose to sell their shares back to the holding company and receive cash instead.

As at end-June, the two units had a combined net tangible assets attributable to shareholders of 149.6 million yuan (S$30.3 million). Based on this - as well as the holding company's issued share capital of 628.7 million shares after the restructuring - shareholders will not receive more than 0.24 yuan for each holding company share, OKH said.

The holding company will fund the buyback by internal cash resources and/or external financing. "Shareholders should note that (OKH) will not be funding the buyback," the company said.

To ensure that the holding company has enough funds to effect the buyback from minority shareholders, OKH chairman Bon Ween Foong, former Sinobest chairman Zou Gefei, Jin Changren and Profit Saver International will not elect for the buyback. They will collectively own 426.5 million shares in the holding company.

site_title: Carriers seen adjusting plan for box rate hikes
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Carriers seen adjusting plan for box rate hikes

Published

Sun, Oct 20, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[COPENHAGEN] A further drop in freight rates last week could force Maersk and other shipping companies to renegotiate planned hikes in container rates on routes from Asia to northern Europe next month.

Maersk Line, the world's biggest container shipping company and part of oil and shipping group A P Moller-Maersk, has said it will attempt to hike rates on routes from Asia to Northern Europe by US$950 per TEU with effect from Nov 1, a 144 per cent increase if successful.

Such attempts are not uncommon in the industry, but are seen as a base for negotiation and the announced hikes rarely go through at planned levels.

With spot freights rates falling to a 17-month low last week, shippers may now have to adjust their rate hike plans. The Shanghai Containerised Freight Index showed rates on routes from Asia to Northern Europe had fallen to US$661 per 20-foot container (TEU), compared with an average level of US$1,378 in 2012, and to levels which are considered loss-making for most shipping companies.

"The main problem is overcapacity and I expect rates to continue to trickle until the beginning of November," said head of maritime analysis company SeaIntel, Lars Jensen.

Mr Jensen said he did not expect the announced rates would be fully accepted by customers, but that Maersk Line would likely succeed in raising rates enough to exceed the break-even level of around US$1,000-1,100 per 20-foot container on the Asia to Europe route.

"They will get a good portion of the announced price hike through, but I do not expect it will go 100 per cent," Mr Jensen said.

According to data from the Shanghai Shipping Exchange on Friday, spot rates for container shipping on the Asia to Northern Europe route have fallen 2.1 per cent last week.

Maersk Line is the biggest container shipping operator with nearly 600 container vessels, competing with lines such as Israel Corporation-controlled Zim Lines, Chinese Orient Overseas Container Line, Korean Hanjin Shipping and Hapag-Lloyd.

Maersk's competitors have announced they will attempt to raise rates by between US$950 and US$1,000 per TEU, also from November. - Reuters

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Lower finance expenses pull Rickmers' Q3 profit up 59%

Published

Tue, Oct 22, 2013 · 10:00 PM

RICKMERS Maritime, a Singapore-based business trust that owns and operates container ships, said third-quarter net profit jumped 59 per cent on lower finance expenses.

Net profit rose to US$13.1 million from US$8.2 million a year earlier, the company said in a statement yesterday. Revenue grew one per cent to US$36.6 million.

"Given hopes of an expected beginning of recovery in the container shipping industry next year, we will continue strengthening our balance sheet, positioning us to capitalise on growth opportunities as and when they arise," Thomas Preben Hansen, chief executive of Rickmers Trust Management, said.

Trade growth is projected to reach around 4.7 per cent this year and accelerate to 6.2 per cent in 2014, subject to global economic developments, according to Clarkson Research Services, a unit of the world's largest shipbroker. Continued uncertainty in the global economy and high oil prices pose downside risks.

Rickmers' vessel operating expenses during the quarter were 2 per cent higher at US$9 million due to a contractual increase in fixed operating expense and vessel management fees.

Finance expenses almost halved to US$5.8 million on reduced outstanding bank loans balances and expiry of interest rate swaps contracts, which resulted in lower interest expenses, the company said.

Rickmers had a 99.9 per cent utilisation rate in the third quarter. It has cash and cash equivalents of US$57.8 million, higher than the US$53.5 million a year ago.

As at end-September, the group's net asset value per unit fell to 63 US cents from US$1 dollar at the end of last year. Earnings per unit dropped to 1.54 US cents from the year-ago quarter's 1.62 US cents, which was restated to take into account effects of the rights issue, Rickmers said.

For the nine months to Sept 30, net profit increased 24 per cent to US$31.5 million while turnover dropped one per cent to US$107.1 million from the year-ago period.

The company has maintained distribution per unit at 0.6 US cent for the quarter. Rickmers finished at 29 cents yesterday, unchanged from the previous day.

content:

Frasers Centrepoint Trust DPU rises 10% in Q4

Full-year DPU hits new high of 10.93 cents

Published

Mon, Oct 21, 2013 · 10:00 PM

FRASERS Centrepoint Trust (FCT) posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.98 cents for the fourth quarter ended September, up 10 per cent from 2.71 cents a year ago.

This was on the back of a 10.1 per cent rise in distribution to shareholders to $24.6 million, from $22.3 million a year ago.

While gross revenue rose 3 per cent to $40.2 million, higher maintenance and other property expenses - including a 54.6 per cent jump in property tax to $3.9 million and a 22.1 per cent increase in maintenance expenses to $4.7 million - resulted in net property income (NPI) falling 5 per cent to $27.3 million.

For the full year ended September, DPU rose 9.2 per cent to 10.93 cents - a new high for the trust, and the seventh year of consecutive DPU growth since FCT's listing - while distribution to unitholders rose 9.5 per cent to $90.1 million.

Gross revenue grew 7.3 per cent to $158.0 million on higher contributions from Causeway Point and Northpoint from better rental rates achieved for new and renewed leases during the year. As a result, NPI rose 6.9 per cent to $111.6 million.

As at end-September, average portfolio occupancy was 98.4 per cent, up from 93.6 per cent a year ago. This was mainly a result of the recovery of Causeway Point's occupancy to 99.5 per cent upon completion of the addition and alteration works.

During Q4, 49 leases, accounting for 36,351 square feet (sq ft) or 4.1 per cent of FCT's total net lettable area, were renewed with a 10.8 per cent rental reversion. The average rental reversion for the financial year 2013 was 7.7 per cent.

Total asset size rose 10.9 per cent to $2.13 billion, as a result of the recognition of $195.7 million from net surplus on revaluation of FCT's properties. Correspondingly, net asset value per unit of FCT grew 15.7 per cent to $1.77 from $1.53 a year ago.

This led to a 2.5 percentage point improvement in gearing level to 27.6 per cent. The average cost of borrowing in Q4 remained stable at 2.73 per cent and the weighted average debt maturity stood at 2.85 years as at end-September.

The counter ended trading half a cent higher at $1.85 yesterday, before the results were released.

TTJ gets $41m deals for Downtown Line 2 jobs

Midas wins $34.2m parts contract for China bullet trains

Published

Mon, Oct 21, 2013 · 10:00 PM

TTJ Holdings has clinched new contracts worth $41 million.

The structural steel specialist said yesterday that it had re-secured the sub-contracts from McConnell Dowell SEA to supply, fabricate and install civil defence shelter doors for the Sixth Avenue and King Albert Park stations on the Downtown Line 2.

The company also received the contract from SK Engineering and Construction (Singapore) (SKEC) to work on the Tan Kah Kee station.

"With the sub-contracts for the three Downtown Line 2 stations in hand again, I am happy to report that TTJ has effectively mitigated any previous exposure we had to these projects," said TTJ chairman Teo Hock Chwee.

McConnell Dowell and SKEC took over from Austrian builder Alpine Bau, which was working on the line's King Albert Park, Sixth Avenue and Tan Kah Kee stations when it filed for insolvency and stopped work in mid-June.

TTJ also said it had clinched two other contracts to supply, fabricate and install steel structure works for Tanjong Pagar Centre, which is set to be the tallest building in Singapore at 290 metres, and for Mediapolis@one-north.

The new contract, which the group expects to complete substantially in FY2014 and 2015, will bring TTJ's order book to $151 million.

"With Singapore's robust population growth, infrastructure development and government-backed mega projects in the pipeline, we believe there will be many business opportunities going forward," Mr Teo said.

Separately, Midas Holdings said it had bagged contracts worth 167.5 million yuan (S$34.2 million).

The contracts, secured by Midas subsidiary Jilin Midas Aluminium Industries Co, are to supply aluminium alloy extrusion profiles and certain fabricated parts for the manufacture of high-speed trains to Chinese train manufacturers.

The contracts are expected to contribute positively to Midas's financial performance from 2013 to 2014, the company said.

site_title: Stordalen returns to scene of his biggest failure
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Stordalen returns to scene of his biggest failure

And now, having learned his lessons, the hotel billionaire is a roaring success

Published

Mon, Oct 21, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[OSLO] Billionaire Petter A Stordalen, Scandinavia's biggest hotel owner, says the one time in his career he did everything wrong ended up being a lesson in how to protect his fortune.

The Norwegian national - who won a reputation for building his hotel empire at breakneck speed last decade - learned his lesson after rushing into the Danish market. He lost 800 million kroner (S$168 million) from 2000 to 2011 following a property bust that forced him to sell all 12 hotels there. He has now returned to the scene, cherry- picking two hotels in Copenhagen.

"Last time we did business in Denmark, we did everything wrong," Mr Stordalen, 50, said in an interview over breakfast at The Thief, his newest six-star hotel in Oslo. "I expanded too fast. This time we do it differently with brands that are better defined, stronger management and a plan to stay only in Copenhagen."

The lessons are helping Mr Stordalen rebuild his empire, and his personal fortune, even as much bigger competitors including Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc and InterContinental Hotels Group Plc sell properties.

For the former triathlete, the trick is to make every hotel opening a lavish event that dazzles guests and steals newspaper headlines. In the past, that's included arriving on a hotel roof in a bright blue helicopter. He's even descended from a ceiling with a disco ball while playing drums for an opening in Gothenburg, Sweden. At a hotel opening outside Oslo, he set fire to a guitar for dramatic effect.

"He's untraditional in the way he communicates," said Torgeir Silseth, CEO of Nordic Choice Hotels AS, which has 171 hotels in the Nordic and Baltic regions. He has worked with Mr Stordalen since he entered the hotel business in 1996. "He talks about his kids, his worries when he wakes up at 4am and his worst fears. He's much more open and sharing, way beyond what is normal in business - a bit eccentric."

The approach has worked. Mr Stordalen is now Norway's ninth-richest man worth 10.2 billion kroner (S$2.1 billion), according to an annual ranking by Norway's Kapital magazine.

The native of Porsgrunn, a small town about 160 kilometres south of Oslo, runs his business through the Home Invest Group, a private company which includes Nordic Choice Hotels, a property business and an investment firm. His companies had sales of 6.2 billion kroner in 2012.

Mr Stordalen became manager of a shopping centre in Trondheim, northwest of Oslo, at the age of 24, before he finished college. Then in 1992, when a financial crisis in Norway pushed the shopping centre operator Steen & Stroem ASA into bankruptcy, he rallied investors to save the business.

By selling off the individual stores and inventory, he said it took him and his two business partners 48 hours to transform a company with 45 million kroner in annual losses into a profitable enterprise.

In 1996, Mr Stordalen was fired as CEO of Steen & Stroem after falling out with fellow billionaire Stein Erik Hagen, one of the company's largest shareholders.

He sold his shares in Steen & Stroem to buy what was then called Choice Hotels, which had 40 hotels. During the first three years, he bought one new hotel every other week, folding in on average 50 more employees with each purchase.

"It was a time of a lot of commotion," Mr Silseth said. "It was mostly frustrating because so much happened and there were so many changes but the system, structure and organisation was always behind. Speed is his strongest asset and is what built the company - but it's also what could be dangerous."

Mr Stordalen took Nordic Choice public in 2000, holding on to 40 per cent to finance an expansion. By 2005, he was fed up with investors who couldn't look beyond the next quarter's bottom line and bought out the company for 462 million kroner.

Today, he doesn't need help financing his business. "Cash flow is the most important thing," Mr Stordalen said.

Home Capital, the investment arm of Home Invest, has one billion kroner in bonds and shares. That, combined with returns in property business and his model of borrowing only up to 65 per cent of the value on his properties, gives Mr Stordalen the cash flow to expand his business.

Over the next five years, he wants to add 29 hotels to the Nordic Choice chain. Last year he returned to the shopping centre business, buying Sektor Gruppen AS and its 13 malls in Norway with a partner for 7 billion kroner.

Mr Stordalen's next big thing is turning his entire empire into an environment-friendly enterprise. He spent 20 million kroner on getting a green certificate on a recent hotel and his business is ranked the third most sustainable in Norway, according to the Sustainable Brand Index.

"I want to show that it's possible to do things differently - to be environmentally and socially responsible and still earn money," he said. "Tax is the cost of civilisation and there can be no business on a dead planet." - Bloomberg

Homes in big German cities overvalued by 20%

Published

Mon, Oct 21, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[BERLIN] Apartments in Germany's largest cities may be overvalued by as much as 20 per cent as home construction fails to keep up with demand, the Bundesbank said.

Apartment prices in parts of Berlin, Hamburg, Munich, Cologne, Frankfurt, Stuttgart and Dusseldorf have risen by more than 25 per cent on average since 2010, the Bundesbank said. Prices in areas around those cities may be climbing due in part to speculation.

"The price pressure on residential property markets will probably not ease up in the near term," the Bundesbank said in its October report. "However, it's not very likely that the current price dynamics on the property market are already leading to significant macroeconomic risks."

German home prices are rising as investors seek a safe place to put their money. Low interest rates are encouraging investors to seek returns outside of bond markets and making it easier for buyers to finance their purchases.

As a whole, the German housing market is appreciating in line with income and isn't overvalued, the central bank said.

Prices in Germany's cities beyond the biggest seven may be about 5 per cent to 10 per cent above where they should be, based on long-term demographic and economic indicators, the Bundesbank said. - Bloomberg

site_title: Looking forward to next year
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Looking forward to next year

As a business leader, what are your expectations for 2014, for the Singapore economy, the region and the world? How do you think 2014 will be different from 2013?

Published

Sun, Oct 20, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Michael Jenkins

Chief Executive

Roffey Park Asia-Pacific

THE rather bleak French expression Plus ça change, plus c'est la même chose - the more things change, the more they remain the same - might be one way of characterising the world at large as we look to 2014. Our challenge is to stay alert and not assume that the BRICs will continue to be ''the ones to watch'' - we need a greater level of awareness to ensure we are alive to what was yesterday's news, to guide our organisations with a fresh, discerning eye and to be able to grab opportunities as they present themselves. At one point in the recent past the BRICs looked set to be replaced by the CIVETs - Colombia, Indonesia, Vietnam, Egypt and Turkey. How things change! And yet our fondness for acronyms persists as we try to make sense of the complex and prioritise our efforts. The one constant is to ensure that our leadership is strategic and of the moment.

Hugues Delcourt

Country Executive

ABN AMRO Bank NV Singapore and Chief Executive Officer of ABN AMRO Private Banking Asia & Middle East

UNCERTAINTY and its twin brother, volatility, may continue to lead the way for the global economy in 2014. We are all - whether we like it or not - closely tied to US politics, and what we see there this (past) week is at best the fact that we have ''just kicked the can further down the road''. The debt ceiling overhang has not been solved, but delayed. It will be back. Who knows how this will affect the crucial decisions on quantitative easing to be made next year by Janet Yellen, the next governor of the US Federal Reserve?

Despite the uncertainty, I believe there is a silver lining in the progressive recovery of the global economy, with developed nations generating growth in 2014, albeit at lower levels, and crucially providing increased demand that will bolster the Asian growth story. And if Asia grows, Singapore grows.

At ABN AMRO, uncertainty is the basis for prudent risk management amid potential opportunities and consequently does not worry us unduly. If anything, it highlights the need for us to continue to stay close to our clients as their trusted adviser. Our approach continues to be to focus on truly understanding our clients' risk profiles and investment horizons and then craft the best possible portfolio options for them.

Leon Perera

Chief Executive Officer

Spire Research & Consulting Group

2014 will see more balanced growth between developed and emerging economies. Provided the US overcomes its current political gridlock, and with an experienced new leader at the Fed, their economy may perform decently as economic fundamentals continue their recovery. Japan should grow briskly, as Abenomics gathers momentum. Europe's performance will lag that of the US and Japan. Emerging market growth rates will be crimped by various domestic issues, some capital flight due to US Fed tapering and the uncertainties surrounding elections in India, Indonesia and Brazil. But given healthy domestic demand, emerging economies will still grow at a respectable rate. Singapore should see slightly better growth in 2014 amid these global and regional conditions. Uplift will come from the tourism, construction and regional services sectors, to compensate for some softness in manufacturing and financial services.

Jeremy Lee

Regional Manager, SE Asia & Taiwan

Moog

WITH every passing year, it is becoming increasingly challenging to predict what's round the corner. However, there does seem to be a strong silver lining after the past few years of roller coaster rides of the global economy. While the days of heady growth may be passé, governments across the world are realising that unrestricted credit growth is only a bubble. Singapore being one of the most open economies can do little to insulate itself from the global scenario.

The initiatives of the government to help local businesses to expand during these trying times will definitely ease the pain to some extent. Further, Singapore has the advantage of being at the epicentre of a region that will still register the most promising growth globally. There are some signs of manufacturing picking up as Japan looks to enhance its presence in South-east Asia and China gets serious in developing its services sector. All these should help change the prevailing uncertain and sombre mood in 2014.

Christophe Duchatellier

CEO

Adecco Asia

WE can look forward to a positive 2014. Clearly there are still challenges on the economic front, particularly with the ongoing crises in Europe. From a regional front, we can expect positive changes from Myanmar and the Philippines. From a talent resource perspective, human capital professionals here clearly have some challenges as companies continue their search for the best talent available. Talent mobility will still be a priority and core focus for many firms. As business leaders, we continue to look forward to stronger partnerships and sharing sessions with other business leaders as well as continued discussions with government.

Mark Micallef

Area Vice-President, Asean

Citrix Systems

THE resilience of South-east Asia in 2014 will hinge on fundamental structural reforms that harness medium-term growth potential. It is vital for South-east Asian businesses to implement policies that foster closer economic cooperation and strengthen integration in the region as a whole. To do so, the emerging economies that are trying to catch up with the developed ones in the region, should look to embrace growth based on productivity increases driven by enhancements in the quality of human capital and business innovation.

For example, organisations can look to enterprise mobility which leverages technology solutions, such as desktop virtualisation, network technologies and cloud computing, that empower employees to work and collaborate from anywhere, on any device and at any time. This not only enhances an organisation's overall productivity and capabilities, it can also help foster integration and boost intraregional agility, which is critical to ensure South-east Asia's ongoing economic prosperity.

Seah Kian Peng

CEO (Singapore)

NTUC FairPrice Co-operative Ltd

I AM quite cautious over the global outlook for the year ahead. There are many reasons to expect tepid growth, if not worse. The world's fiscal and economic uncertainties remain unresolved. And just as one cannot multiply wealth by dividing it, the debt situation in many countries cannot be solved by borrowing more. So, until this severe over-borrowing is resolved or a plan, painful as it may be, is put in place, global markets are likely to continue to be very turbulent. Singapore will have to ride through such periods. We have a few things on our side. We are financially strong, we are in a region which is growing, and we have sound fiscal and monetary policies. The challenge is for us to remain competitive and find a way to keep operating costs under control. Only then can we be pro-business and pro-worker at the same time.

Charlie Foo

Vice-President

Brocade

THE overall business outlook for 2014 will be mixed, with pockets of growth in some sectors while certain industries may experience contraction. Nevertheless, we are hopeful that Asia-Pacific will perform bullishly given its economic diversity and the growth potential of emerging markets such as Indonesia and Myanmar.

In the technology sector, we are seeing market momentum and strong demand for critical infrastructure development from South-east Asia, China and India, while mature economies such as Australia, Singapore and South Korea are investing in transformative technologies to improve productivity and competitiveness. We believe the adoption of new technologies and the resulting market growth will even surpass nominal GDP growth in some countries.

Subbaraju Alluri

CEO

Grey Group Singapore

MOST companies are still seeing growth opportunities in the region. In 2014, we predict an increase in the level of activity especially in the relatively untapped emerging markets.

We don't anticipate the pace of business to slow down for many of our clients. However, companies will now relook their budgets to ensure greater returns on investments. To this end, we expect to see clients becoming more digitally savvy, as they try to engage consumers on a more personal level. A strong brand equity will help keep their products and services top of mind among customers - an important strategy to bolster the effects of temporary economic cycles.

Ronald Lee

Managing Director

PrimeStaff Management Services Pte Ltd

SINGAPORE'S economic growth should continue to be moderate in 2014, with economic restructuring measures continuing to pose a challenge for many businesses. Human capital is a key component of any business and as PrimeStaff operates in the talent acquisition arena, we foresee that the tightening of foreign labour policies will exacerbate the manpower crunch that many companies are already facing. Further tightening measures may be introduced next year so the business community should brace themselves for this possibility.

Regionally, countries that have been on a strong growth trajectory in recent years, such as Indonesia and Vietnam, may continue to experience good growth prospects. However, it may not be as buoyant as in previous years. Of all the countries in South-east Asia, it is likely that Myanmar will experience the highest growth for obvious reasons. Overall, I believe the global economy will still be rather fragile and susceptible to policy missteps and political shake-ups in the US and Europe, as we have witnessed this past year.

Gerald Foo

President

Walton International Group (S) Pte Ltd

THE US fiscal health will be of concern and will have an impact globally. However, according to World Bank economist Olivier Blanchard, Core Europe is at last showing some signs of recovery, which will bode well for the global economy. With this scenario, the outlook for 2014 looks patchy although most countries in Asia will see growth in their economies with China leading the way.

As for the Singapore economy, businesses in general will be affected by the squeeze in manpower constraint as well as high labour costs. As a result, inflation will be higher. Singapore's growth may be marginally higher than this year. The way forward for Singapore businesses is to innovate and increase productivity without relying too much on manpower. In this regard, training our workforce to multi-task and also to use more technology to overcome the manpower issue is the way to go. At Walton, we constantly emphasise on training and we send our staff for courses regularly. Once the staff are well trained, they are more confident and able to undertake additional duties efficiently.

Phupinder Gill

Chief Executive Officer

CME Group

SINGAPORE has greatly benefited from stable government policies that has enabled its financial sector to expand and take advantage of the tremendous growth in Asia. The environment that has been cultivated by the government will continue to serve Singapore well for many years to come.

In the US, uncertainties about fiscal and monetary policies are seriously hindering growth prospects as we enter 2014. Slower growth in the US, along with continued stagnation in Europe, are likely to encourage Asian economies, especially China, to increase their emphasis on domestic or regionally-driven growth. For China, this might mean increasing the pace of financial reforms to give more flexibility to the consumer and business sectors as reliance on large-scale new infrastructure projects is decreased.

Allen Ang Swee Meng

Group Managing Director

Aldon Technologies Services Pte Ltd

I EXPECT the global outlook for 2014 to be less volatile, underpinned by slow but steady growth in major Western economies. However, there are potential risks, including the possibility that the scaling back of stimulus measures in the US may cause severe capital outflow and disruptions in emerging economies. In Asia, I foresee some headwinds as China gears itself for a controlled slowdown which will affect the economies of the rest of Asia.

In 2014, I expect Asia's growing middle class to continue to spend on housing and consumer products on the back of low interest rates, boosting domestic consumption. This will spur industrial activities, especially the semiconductor industry which provides chips for almost every consumer product. It will be a boon for Singapore's manufacturing industry and export-driven economy.

Against this positive backdrop, Aldon Technologies, a manufacturer in the semiconductor industry, is cautiously optimistic about prospects for 2014. Advance estimates show the economy grew 5.1 per cent in Q3 of 2013. We have felt the economic robustness and share the MAS' expectations that the economy will continue to expand for the rest of the year and into 2014. However, like other manufacturers, the foreign labour policy will increase our operating costs and crimp our manpower capacity. We have implemented some work redesign and productivity improvement measures and are hopeful we can grow 8 to 10 per cent this and next year.

Yeoh Oon Jin

Executive Chairman

PwC Singapore

DESPITE continuing global economic uncertainty, almost 70 per cent of chief executive officers surveyed in PwC's Asia-Pacific CEO Survey 2013 stated that they intend to increase investments in the region, with 42 per cent being very confident of revenue growth over the next 12 months.

CEOs are confident of growth in Asia-Pacific, especially South-east Asia. Of the top five 'dark horse' economies that CEOs identified as most likely to show more business opportunities - Indonesia, Myanmar, China, the Philippines and Vietnam - four are located in South-east Asia. Our CEO survey shows much confidence in the region as the apex of growth in the coming year.

We believe that Singapore's geographical proximity and our good political and economic standing in Asean puts us in a natural beneficial position.

Herbert Vongpusanachai

Managing Director

DHL Express (Singapore)

DESPITE lower global economic growth ahead, the logistics sector remains stable. It is expected to grow at a modest rate of 5.3 per cent in 2014, better than 2013's 3.5 per cent. Growth in the South-east Asian economies is set to remain buoyant on the back of robust consumption, rising investment and increased intra-regional trade, with GDP growth projected at 5.7 per cent in 2014. In 2013, DHL Express continues to see sustained growth across all countries in South-east Asia, with the strongest business expansion coming from the Philippines and Vietnam. We expect this momentum to continue in 2014.

Looking ahead, SMEs will remain our key focus. We will also grow our footprints and strengths in specialised sectors, including oil and gas, electronics, life sciences and aerospace, by providing comprehensive and innovative solutions to enhance our customers' overall competitiveness. The opening of Myanmar will also offer us an exciting market in 2014.

Saw Ken Wye

CEO

CrimsonLogic

CRIMSONLOGIC has achieved accelerated business growth in 2013, driven mainly by the expansion of our footprint in the emerging markets. We secured exciting projects, including the roll-out of trade facilitation systems in Oman and the building of Mauritius' national identity card system.

In 2014, we are confident that emerging economies, like the Middle East, Africa and Latin America, will remain the key growth drivers for CrimsonLogic, as these untapped markets continue to represent huge potential for eGovernment projects. We expect our overseas business to grow faster, but Singapore remains a strong showcase of our capabilities.

Although global business sentiment may be a little uncertain currently, the Singapore brand continues to be strong. This, coupled with a capable and knowledgeable workforce, will enable local businesses competing regionally and globally to have a competitive edge over others.

Toby Fowlston

Managing Director, Singapore

Robert Walters (Singapore) Ltd

WHILE sentiments for 2014 are generally cautious, we can look towards a positive start to 2014, given Singapore's economic growth this year. Singapore remains one of the top choices within Asia for multinationals to base their regional businesses. Hence, we anticipate the entry of even more global firms in 2014, which will contribute significantly to the economy.

In addition, while we have faced a talent crunch for local professionals over the past few years, the Singapore government's new initiatives to attract returning Singaporeans from overseas will create a more dynamic workforce. This will be another noteworthy upcoming development which is likely to channel a positive outcome.

Raed S Haddad

Managing Director, Asia-Pacific

ESI International

WE expect moderate growth in the global economy in 2014 with Asia-Pacific leading most of the expansion while the Euro area stabilises. The outlook for South-east Asia, China and India has remained optimistic so far and this will continue into 2014 and the medium term.

Singapore, with its strong economic fundamentals and advanced workforce, will enjoy quality growth as a regional business hub as it transforms its economy into a more sustainable and inclusive growth-led model. In that regard, enterprises in Singapore will need to innovate the way they conduct business, with the integration of technology and human capital training, so as to improve productivity and performance, and thrive under such an economic model.

Lim Soon Hock

Managing Director

PLAN-B ICAG Pte Ltd

2014 will remain uncertain. The hot spots in the world - the US economy, eurozone crisis - and the slowing economies of Asia, in particular China, India and Japan, have not fully recovered. If anything, they are in convalescence. The current gridlock on the US debt ceiling and spending, although it seems to have been resolved, has put a damper on the anticipated recovery. All the major economies of the world are affected by systemic risks and the responses of monetary policies, for example, quantitative easing from the US and Abenomics in Japan. It is the worst kind of economic concoction that will drive Singapore's vulnerability to a higher level. There is little room for us to manoeuvre out of this persistent economic predicament. Singapore would have done well if we can maintain the current economic growth in 2014.

Businesses should therefore be prudent with investments and keep as much cash as possible. Indeed, if need be, they should monetise assets such as inventories or redundant facilities to keep cashflow positive. Going forward, governments will have to be more aggressive with their fiscal policies and be relentless in creating employment and attracting investments, to exit from this economic malaise. Surgical actions will need to be taken as the medicine that has been prescribed is evidently not working.

Ranjit Khanna

Head of South-east Asia & Global NRI

Coutts & Co Ltd

THE world is healing, slowly. The fallout from the banking crises in 2008 is still with us in the form of quantitative easing (QE) programmes in developed nations. Soggy growth in most of the G-7 means that, even in the US, QE will be around for quite some time. Growth in developed nations is not breaching 2 per cent and will be a struggle again in 2014. Heavily indebted consumer sectors are a significant drag and developed nations are now reliant on companies investing again or on increased demand growth in emerging markets.

We think Asia will do better in 2014 as investment rates increase in cash-rich companies. Sentiment about the region's larger nations and Singapore's large export-oriented economy will improve, although some post-plenary doubts will continue about China's extended credit cycle. India's new central bank governor has been a great choice and the prospect of an SK Modi premiership should make 2014 a very dynamic year. We view the Philippines' renewed investment cycle very favourably and hope that 2014 is a better year for policymaking in general.

Wong Heng Chew

President

Fujitsu Singapore

IN recent years, we have seen tremendous upheaval in the business environment and society. Globalisation has transformed economic activity, leading to seismic shifts in the market landscape, along with increasing uncertainty. However, businesses are also becoming more adept at leveraging technology to fuel their expansion and resolve issues facing business and society. For Asian businesses, this means becoming more nimble, cost-effective and streamlined for business expansions.

Looking ahead, Fujitsu envisions a Human Centric Intelligent Society where people will play a central role and leverage information and communication technology to realise sustainable development globally. This creates potential to drive new business value and transform social infrastructure. People will be able to exploit the benefits of new insights and harness critical knowledge for innovation, business growth and an intelligent society.

V Hariharan

CEO

Singapore Mercantile Exchange

FROM the perspective of Asia's major exchange traded asset classes, 2014 is likely to be an improvement over 2013. In commodities, precious metals demand, especially silver, will be robust. We expect the steadying and strengthening of Asia's currencies, with the Singapore dollar consolidating its position as an Asian currency anchor. Since US government debt is not a major component of trading activity in Asia, a US default or downgrade would have negligible impact. Conditions are ideal for Singapore to further encourage the inflow of global capital and to comprehensively consolidate its position as a leading global financial centre into 2014.

Thirumalai Chandroo

Chairman/CEO

Modern Montessori International Group

AS we prepare for 2014, it's that time of the year to project and extend new outlines for our businesses. The economic outlook for Emerging Asia (China, South-east Asia and India) is looking bright, although America may once again be a subject of uncertainty in 2014, given the flux in the US economy.

Macroeconomic policies such as monetary reforms and policies to narrow income ceilings and promote inclusive growth around the world will play a critical role in driving sustainable development; this will influence how business owners plan for 2014. But Singapore is progressing steadily as our economy shifts towards a more broad-based growth led by rising productivity and innovation.

Gurpreet Dhillon

Chief Executive Officer

Religare Health Trust Trustee Manager Pte Ltd

SINGAPORE will continue to enjoy steady growth in 2014. The recovery in the Western economies is having a positive impact on Asia. We are encouraged by this outlook and hopeful that Asia will remain the world's economic growth engine through sound macroeconomic policies, expanding domestic consumption and continued investments. These will be key in driving sustainable growth in the Asian economies through improved living standards and bolstering the rise of the middle income class throughout Asia.

While we continue to monitor the volatile capital markets in the US and Europe, given the impact they have on the rest of the world, we are confident in the resilience of the global economy.

Joshua Yim

CEO

Achieve Group

BASED on the latest developments in major economies such as the United States, Europe, China and Japan, the sentiment of late appears to be more positive than in previous quarters. The only hiccup seems to be the US shutdown and debt ceiling issue, which has come under control for now. However, this is a factor to watch out for as it may create a blip in the global recovery. In the Asia-Pacific, news has come out that China is still experiencing healthy growth while Japan's economy is also growing, judging from its buoyant stock market and export market.

Generally speaking, compared to 2013, the Asia-Pacific region and South-east Asia will do better in 2014. Singapore's growth has always been dependent on the global economy. Singapore's economic growth has borne the brunt of the manpower crunch in the past 12 to 18 months. Growth for the year will probably come in around the mid-point of the forecast 1 to 3 per cent. I think this climate will persist into 2014 as the government has sent a clear signal in giving Singaporeans and permanent residents priority for jobs. It is not the case that Singapore does not welcome foreigners but it seems that the immigration tap will not be as open as before. The employment market will be even tighter and it is likely to continue to be an employee's market as the demand for Singaporean and PR workers heats up.

David Leong

Managing Director

PeopleWorldwide Consulting Pte Ltd

2014 will see the US and Europe shift to a higher gear of growth. Despite continuing transatlantic economic turbulence, they will remain each other's most important markets. China's slowing economy will see its investments flowing out to find better returns, particularly to America and Europe.

The world will also be watching how the US will handle its debt ceiling issue and how it can go on as the de facto world reserve currency without any loss of confidence in the US dollar. This will have a direct impact on interest rates. Any upward movement is likely to affect growth prospects.

Singapore will have sluggish growth. The strong Singapore dollar is unlikely to weaken over the long term and this will affect the republic's export competitiveness. Businesses will face higher business costs, higher wages and a contracting labour supply. 2014 will be a year of low expectations for Singapore as the macro environment will remain challenging.

Zaheer Merchant

Regional Director (Singapore & Europe)

QI Group of Companies

FOR 2014, I expect a mixed bag of fortunes overall. I am confident Singapore will maintain its economic growth into 2014 on the present 5.1 per cent growth in the third quarter 2013. Inflation and labour factors need to be reined in, but the finance and services sector seem strongly positioned for continued growth. This should help our business sectors.

Regionally, the ''opening-up'' of Myanmar, and dynamism of Indonesia and Philippines, are the bright spots. I believe Malaysia will also be fine if its currency issue is dealt with since there is political stability. Prospects over Europe are still slow, while the US uncertainty is unhelpful. I am hopeful of 2014 being different from 2013 because I am confident there will be clear economic certainty with the Fed's leadership settled.

Bryce Boland

APAC, Chief Technology Officer

FireEye

IN 2014 the Personal Data Protection Act and the Computer Misuse and Cybersecurity Act will come into force, increasing the cost and complexity for enterprises as the rapid uptake of smart phones and tablet computers continues unabated. We expect to see more attacks with malicious mobile applications, fake application stores and manipulation of the supply chain to deliver devices preinstalled with malware.

Globally, the cyber crime market will continue to grow. Terrorist groups, political activists, whistleblowers and criminal organisations will continue to leverage poorly protected IT systems.

Steve Melhuish

Co-Founder and Group Chief Executive Officer

PropertyGuru

''Volatility'' and ''uncertainty" are two words we have heard very often this year when we talk about the economy. The truth is, 2013 has indeed proven to be somewhat of a roller-coaster ride. Taking into consideration the key events that have transpired so far - the changes in political leadership and the lack of in some cases, and the 16-day shutdown of the United States government that cost the economy US$24 billion, for example - 2014 will feel the spillover effects one way or another, while it faces new challenges and its fair share of volatility and uncertainties ahead.

That said, it's not all gloom and doom. We will see global growth, and recovery from the crisis will continue, albeit slowly. That's important. Some have even predicted that the year will turn a corner. And if we focus on Asia, which remains a global growth leader, there's good reason to be optimistic. Barring any external surprises, the Singapore economy also looks poised to expand steadily. As usual, my advice to investors and business owners is this: Don't put all your eggs in one basket, always know what you're getting yourself into and have a back-up plan.

David Siah

Country Manager

Trend Micro Singapore

2013 saw an increase in the frequency and impact of cyber-attacks, as well as greater awareness among consumers, enterprises and governments. In Singapore alone, regulations and laws like the Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) and MAS Technology Risk Management Guidelines reinforce the need to maintain due diligence when dealing with confidential and personal information.

With the momentum on mobility push, it will be important to ensure that BYOD does not turn into Bring Your Own Disaster. It will be critical for organisations to follow smart data protection practices, ensure instantaneous data protection and build up a strong security system for effective detection and quick response to targeted attacks.

Lionel Lim, President

Asia Pacific & Japan

CA Technologies: In this ever volatile world, it is likely that the uncertainties in the US and European markets will continue to cast a shadow somewhat on this region in 2014. That said, I remain optimistic about the growth prospects of this region, and especially about the increasingly significant role that Singapore has as the governance, infrastructural and financial safe haven for the region. This is a region that is teeming with opportunities. All indicators point to the fact that this region is the world's largest growing cloud-connected consumer base. The largest-growing internet user base and smartphone user base, the soon-to-be largest ICT spending region are all within the Asia Pacific and Japan, complemented by growing intra-regional trade and strong forex reserves. Companies, organisations, and governments need to be agile and innovate to succeed and better connect with their constituents in this connected market. This underscores the increasingly important role that IT plays in business transformation to drive greater productivity, collaboration, efficiencies and sustained growth. This age of innovation in Asia Pacific and Japan will gather strength next year, centreing on Singapore as the innovation hub to drive further growth for the region beyond 2014.

Baltimore's port partially reopens

Listen to this article

Published Sun, Oct 20, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] Baltimore's port, a gateway for autos from Bayerische Motoren Werke AG and Mazda Motor Corp, partially reopened with car shipments still idled even as striking longshoremen resumed work on container vessels.

"The ILA (International Longshoremen's Association) is going back to work under master contract conditions," said John Leichling, president of Local 1429, one of Baltimore's four chapters, in an interview.

Baltimore's Local 333 chapter announced a work stoppage on Oct 15 after failed negotiations with the Steamship Trade Association of Baltimore Inc over its local contract, which covers the handling of items such as automobiles, said Jim McNamara, a spokesman for the ILA.

Avaya targets mid-sized firms with voice, video-conferencing solutions

PICTURE this - your sales force is out in the field but doesn't have all the answers on hand to respond to all of your customers' questions. Instead of doing a follow-up via another appointment, your sales agents can start a video on their tablets, laptops or smartphones on the spot and within minutes have a fully qualified expert on a video conversation with your customers.

Such a scenario is already playing out for a major insurance company in China. Relying on Avaya's call management and contact centre solutions, the insurer's agents quickly place a video call between the customer and an actuary or an expert.

The contact centre backing up the agent force in this manner not only improves the customer experience but also shortens the time it takes to get the customer on to a new policy, said Mike Muller, president for Avaya in Asia-Pacific.

site_title: Buying by directors surges
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Buying by directors surges

Listen to this article

Published Sun, Oct 20, 2013 · 10:00 PM

THE buying surged while the selling among directors remained high based on filings on Singapore Exchange (SGX) during the holiday-shortened week of Oct 14-18. A total of 11 companies recorded 27 purchases worth $6.8 million versus five firms with 17 disposals worth $12.64 million. The number of trades and value on the buying side were up from the previous week's five-day totals of 24 purchases and $3.69 million. On the selling side, the number of trades was down from the previous week's 24 disposals but the value was up from the previous week's sales worth $9.6 million.

While the buying by directors rose last week, the buyback activity among listed firms plunged with only seven firms that posted 16 repurchases worth $1.5 million. The figures were sharply down from the previous week's 11 companies, 26 trades, and $14.2 million.

There were several significant buyback and director trades last week. On the buybacks side, Global Invacom Group bought back for the first time after the stock rebounded by 25 per cent. On the flip side, Chasen Holdings, along with an executive director, bought shares after the stock plunged by 65 per cent. site_title: Getting the hang of dabbling in alternative investments
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Getting the hang of dabbling in alternative investments

The key advantage of such instruments is in the diversification they provide to a portfolio, says ANG BEN YOU

Published

Sun, Oct 20, 2013 · 10:00 PM

A few of my friends overseas buy and sell playing cards. The notion that such an endeavour would amount to any sort of business or investment seemed far-fetched - until the news came that someone in Norway had successfully funded his purchase of an Audi by selling rare out-of-print "Jerry's Nuggets" cards at 200 euros (S$339) per deck.

Right now, companies and even individuals are printing their own decks, keeping them limited to depress supply, holding them in their personal inventories and then selling them in the hope of making a killing. It is not uncommon to see a newly-released deck of cards selling out in a few hours, only to reappear later on eBay, sometimes costing 10 times more.

One can see how playing cards could be a viable - if unconventional - investment. They can be lumped under the category of alternative investments, which refer to any form of investment not considered part of the traditional portfolio of stocks, bonds and cash.

But the term evolves with investment trends.

In recent years, alternative assets such as wine and art have become the rage. Like the popular term for emerging markets BRIC - a grouping comprising Brazil, Russia, India and China - the popularity of alternative assets has given rise to a new acronym, SWAG - for Silver, Wine, Art and Gold.

Such unconventional asset classes are needed in an investment portfolio mainly because of their low correlation to traditional securities. Gold, the traditional safe haven during economic distress, is now joined by several other alternative asset classes.

Wine and art

The popularity of wine and fine art as investment instruments has been driven predominantly by the growth of high net worth individuals (HNWIs) in emerging markets such as China. If investing in such exotic assets is your cup of tea, it is useful to understand some of the forces behind art and wine prices.

The key winds behind market movements will also apply to art and wine, albeit sometimes in an opposite way, reflecting their low correlation to the market. Some of these forces involve general economic conditions and inflation. Logically, an increase in global wealth through economic prosperity will lead to an increase in demand for wine and art, leading to price appreciation.

Non-systematic and specific factors for art include interest in certain genres, trends and even culture. Thus even within art genres like Impressionism or Realism, returns can be different.

Other factors contributing towards the value of an art piece include the artist's critical acclaim, whether it is supported by leading art dealers and its previous ownership if owned by reputable collectors or art galleries.

Economic conditions determine the value of these items. With wines, for example, it is important to understand that not all wines are "investment grade", so going down to the neighbourhood NTUC FairPrice store to buy a bottle of red wine in anticipation of price appreciation is probably not a good idea.

As a general rule of thumb, red wines from key French estates are investable, but investors need to look for quality and scarcity. Intermediaries like brokers, consultants and private banks may be able to advise on such investments.

To gain exposure to such assets, one can possibly buy into funds. Funds that invest in art are still rare, but are rapidly growing with the increase in HNWIs. For the financially capable, hoarding art pieces from notable artists can be a possible portfolio strategy. A notable example of a foray into an art investment portfolio was made by the British Rail Pension fund after 1974. The portfolio comprised some 2,500 individual works of art, built as a response to the financial crises of the time in the UK.

The Economist's Guide to Investment Strategy said that from 1974 to 2003, when the last piece of art from the portfolio was sold, the portfolio appreciated from £41.1 million to £170.4 million; this worked out to a net gain of £129.3 million and an annual return of 3.7 per cent net of commission, fees and taxes, excluding storage and insurance costs. This is evidence that investments of passion can be used successfully in the context of a portfolio strategy.

But is there an opportunity for entering the art and wine market?

The size of the art market is now insignificant relative to disposable wealth. Reports suggest that it is the same for the wine market. What this means is that any move by a substantial investor to establish or extend a major collection of art or wine may provide considerable support to prices. Thus, entering the market for such investments now could be prudent in anticipation of future gains from this standpoint.

Other alternative investments

While wine, antiques, fine art and even playing cards may be considered alternative investments, let us also consider more passion-neutral and liquid classes of alternative financial assets.

In the context of an investment portfolio, alternative investments are also defined as investments that are not constrained by the limitations of long-only listed investments. These include real estate, private equity, hedge funds, managed futures and even distressed securities. With the exception of real estate, these assets are usually part of a larger investment portfolio of, say, a mutual fund.

Investors in alternative non-passion financial assets are usually institutional investors or HNWIs rather than regular retail clients. This is not unusual because such instruments are usually more complicated. While this is a limitation, retail clients can still participate through more accessible financial products such as real estate investment trusts (Reits) and exchange-traded funds (ETFs).

Features of such investments

Some important features of alternative investments are worth noting:

Alternative investments, being unconventional in nature, can sometimes have low levels of liquidity. This is sometimes not well understood by investors and is the reason why a liquidity premium is required.

Other features of certain alternative investments, specifically funds, that are deemed less attractive include a high due-diligence cost, difficulty in valuation and a lack of access to information.

The comparatively higher costs in due diligence come from the additional research and monitoring required stemming from limited information. Limited information is in turn a result of poor transparency and pricing difficulties, requiring more specialised professionals. For example, fees for alternative investments, specifically funds, can include an annual management fee of one to 2 per cent in addition to an incentive fee of 10 to 20 per cent. These fees may not be justified, considering their returns, when compared with the returns and costs of investing in traditional assets.

The role of alternative investments

The key advantage of alternative instruments is in the diversification they provide to a portfolio. This is because of possibly better risk-adjusted returns - which mean lower volatility, together with better gains or less painful losses. Alternatives can thus diversify a traditional long-only portfolio of stocks and bonds.

However, do take note that diversification does not insure against loss. A better risk-adjusted return is achieved by selecting instruments with returns that are not correlated with traditional assets. By reducing the correlation between individual assets in a portfolio, volatility will be reduced, lowering a portfolio's overall risk.

One can also use alternative investments as a hedge in a portfolio. Since the returns of such products are usually not correlated with the core instruments in a portfolio, we can use them to protect against certain downside risks.

Risks of alternative investments

As the saying goes, never invest in something you don't understand.

Alternative investments are usually more complex. That being the case, they are usually also less transparent. For example, hedge funds, a lightly-regulated alternative investment instrument, are not obliged to disclose much publicly. You can't be sure that the tools employed by managers within a hedge fund are well suited towards making investment decisions.

In addition to the issue of trust, alternative investments can also disappoint in bull markets. A bull market can usually be observed during periods of rapid economic growth, where assets appreciate strongly. The period between the dot-com bubble to the 2008 crisis is an example of such a market. While returns of instruments that are not correlated with traditional assets can protect a portfolio against losses, let's not forget that this also means that gains will be capped. For example, short-selling strategies used to generate an absolute return tend to lag long-only strategies in a strong bull market.

Alternative investments can also possibly disappoint in extreme down markets, where correlations converge due to herd mentality.

Invest in moderation

To conclude, when used in moderation, alternative investments can be a prudent way to invest. An appropriate allocation to alternatives within a portfolio would be 10 to 20 per cent. This is large enough to impact returns and to reduce risk, and also small enough to keep due-diligence fees from becoming exorbitant.

It is also prudent to opt for a conservative approach by going for strategies with a proven track record. This is of course based on the assumption that the investment team chosen is somehow more skilled and knowledgeable.

While we understand the irrationality of the markets and the limits of models in predictability, we can also potentially use such alternative investments to benefit from market uncertainty. Such an outlook will typically employ a further layer of allocation towards alternatives which are extremely high-risk, high-reward.

Psychologically, one should be prepared for loss, but a small bet could potentially reap unexpectedly huge gains - it all boils down to playing your cards right.

The writer is a fourth-year student at the Lee Kong Chian School of Business in the Singapore Management University (SMU) and a student trainer in the Citi-SMU Financial Literacy Programme for Young Adults. Jointly launched by Citi Singapore and SMU in April 2012, the programme is Singapore's first structured financial literacy programme for young adults. It aims to equip those aged 17 to 30 with essential personal finance knowledge and skills to give them a firm foundation in managing their money, and a financial headstart early in their working lives.

ValueMax plans to raise $70.4m in IPO

Published

Mon, Oct 21, 2013 · 10:00 PM

VALUEMAX Group, Singapore's biggest pawnbroking chain by revenue, is seeking about $70.4 million in an initial public offering to expand its business.

The company, set to be Singapore's first pawnbroking chain to list on the mainboard, plans to offer 138 million new shares, or 25.9 per cent of the company, at 51 cents each, its CEO, Yeah Hiang Nam, said at a briefing yesterday.

ValueMax will be the third pawnbroker to go public, after Maxi-Cash Financial Services and MoneyMax Financial Services made their debuts on the Catalist board in the past 18 months.

About 133 million shares will be offered under the placement tranche, with the remaining five million shares offered to the public. The invitation is priced at a price-earnings ratio of 12.4 times based on the group's pro forma net earnings per share for the year ended Dec 31, 2012.

Established in 1988, ValueMax has 17 outlets in Singapore, as well as three other pawnshops with pre-owned jewellery retail outlets operated by its associated and investee companies. It also operates five outlets in Malaysia through its associates.

Last year, ValueMax's profit attributable to shareholders was $14.3 million, slightly lower than the $14.5 million in FY2011. Sales fell 4.3 per cent to $509 million on lower revenues from its jewellery and gold trading business.

That business segment contributed $486.7 million to sales in the last fiscal year, 5 per cent lower than the previous year. "This is because of the declining gold prices in the last quarter last year," chief financial officer Carol Liew said.

ValueMax gets its pre-owned jewellery from walk-in individuals and unredeemed pledged articles from its pawnbroking business and suppliers. It purchases gold bars for trading from refiners and gold traders.

Over the same period, the company's pawnbroking business grew 17 per cent to $22.3 million.

ValueMax intends to use 60 per cent of the $66.3 million in net proceeds to finance the expansion of its business, such as opening or acquiring pawnshops in Singapore and other countries, Mr Yeah said.

It will use the remaining 40 per cent to fund working capital.

The group said it planned to open a flagship store in central Singapore to target wealthy individuals in the second half of next year.
