Published

Tue, Oct 15, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[LOS ANGELES] THE pitch was enticing. At a time when the Standard & Poor's 500 Index had suffered a decline of 41 per cent in the previous three years, Morgan Stanley was offering its clients the possibility of some relief. In a prospectus, the New York securities firm invited its customers to put their money into a little-known area of alternative investing called managed futures. "If you've never diversified your portfolio beyond stocks and bonds, you should know about the powerful argument for managed futures," the bank wrote. "Managed futures may potentially profit at times when traditional markets are experiencing losses." Morgan Stanley presented a chart telling investors that over 23 years, people who put 10 per cent of their assets in managed futures outperformed those whose investments were limited to a combination of stocks and bonds, reports Bloomberg Markets magazine in its November issue.

Clients jumped in. During the decade ended in 2012, more than 30,000 investors entrusted Morgan Stanley with US$797 million in a managed-futures fund called Morgan Stanley Smith Barney Spectrum Technical. The fund already had US$341.6 million invested during the previous eight years. Top fund managers speculated with that cash in a wide range of asset classes. In that period, the fund made US$490.3 million in trading gains and money-market interest income.

Investors who kept their money in Spectrum Technical for that decade, however, reaped none of those returns - not one cent. Every bit of those profits - and more - was consumed by US$498.7 million in commissions, expenses and fees paid to fund managers and Morgan Stanley.

After all of that was deducted, investors ended up losing US$8.3 million over 10 years. Had those Morgan Stanley investors placed their money instead in a low-fee index mutual fund, such as Vanguard Group's 500 Index Fund, they would have reaped a net cumulative return of 96 per cent in the same period.

In the US$337 billion managed-futures market, return-robbing fees like those are common. According to data filed with the US Securities and Exchange Commission and compiled by Bloomberg, 89 per cent of the US$11.51 billion of gains in 63 managed-futures funds went to fees, commissions and expenses during the 2003-2012 decade.

The funds held US$13.65 billion of investor money at the end of last year, according to SEC filings. Twenty-nine of those funds left investors with losses.

The US$8.3 million loss in Morgan Stanley's Spectrum Technical fund over a decade pales in comparison with an aggregate deficit of US$1 billion in 29 Morgan Stanley and Citigroup Inc managed-futures funds in the four years ended Dec 31, the filings show. Those funds charged investors a total of US$1.5 billion in fees.

Morgan Stanley and Citigroup merged their funds' management in 2009; Morgan Stanley bought out Citi's share in June.

"The big news here is, the fees are so outlandish, they can actually wipe out all the profits," says Bart Chilton, one of five members of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC). Even though the CFTC oversees managed futures, Mr Chilton says he hadn't been aware of the effects of the high costs for investors.

"We absolutely need to do a better job of letting consumers know in plain English what's going on," he says. "Those numbers tell a story. It's astounding."

The impact of high fees on investors has escaped the notice not only of regulators, but also industry executives.

The Morgan Stanley Spectrum Technical fund was opened in 1994 under the leadership of then-chief executive officer Philip Purcell. He was succeeded in 2005 by John Mack, who had spent most of his career at Morgan Stanley. James Gorman, who replaced Mr Mack in 2009, joined Morgan Stanley from Merrill Lynch & Co in 2006.

The prospectus pitching the Spectrum fund, issued in March 2003, said the firm would accept investments as low as US$2,000 for individual retirement accounts.

Brokers have an incentive to keep clients in managed- futures funds because they receive commissions annually of up to 4 per cent of assets invested, prospectuses show. Investors pay up to 9 per cent in total fees each year, including charges by general partners and fund managers.

People put money into managed futures because their brokers recommend them, says Thomas Schneeweis, a finance professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst who was a futures-fund manager from 2004 to 2010. "Everything is marketing," he says.

Broker pitches that don't clearly tell investors about the drastic effect of fees should be considered fraudulent, says James Cox, a securities law professor at Duke University in Durham, North Carolina.

Because the managed-futures market is opaque and poorly understood, otherwise sophisticated investors often don't realise how pervasive the profit-eating fees are. The firms marketing the funds are at times also left in the dark. The industry refers to the computers programmed with trading algorithms as black boxes. Some banks say they can't see into the boxes of the traders they hired.

Strategy changes

"Particularly given the black box character of many managed-futures strategies, it is virtually impossible for the manager to detect strategy changes," Bank of America Corp's Merrill Lynch says in an August 2010 SEC registration for its Systematic Momentum FuturesAccess LLC.

The 7,752 investors in that fund faced losses of US$135.3 million, after fees, from 2009 to 2012, according to data from Merrill's SEC filings. Merrill spokesman Bill Haldin declined to comment.

High fees and black boxes are just part of the story. Some funds also allow their managers to make undisclosed side bets by trading ahead of or opposite to the fund's trades. Chicago-based Grant Park Futures Fund LP, which is marketed by Zurich-based UBS AG, says on page 90 of a 180-page, April 2013 prospectus that David Kavanagh, president of the US$660.9 million fund's general partner, may place such personal trades. "Mr Kavanagh may even be the other party to a trade entered into by Grant Park," it says.

The Grant Park Futures Fund reported a net investor loss of US$68.6 million during the decade ended Dec 31, after fees and commissions of US$427.7 million.

When financial advisers promote managed-futures funds, they often rely on charts produced by a small company in Fairfield, Iowa, called BarclayHedge Ltd. The firm, which has no connection to London-based Barclays plc, reports a 29-fold gain through 2012 for managed futures overall since 1980. Those numbers can mislead investors.

BarclayHedge does not deduct billions of dollars of fees charged by funds. It uses only information volunteered by managed-futures traders. Traders can stop providing data if their system starts to lose money or collapses, says BarclayHedge president Sol Waksman. The BarclayHedge data, even with its flaws, Mr Waksman says, is the industry benchmark. Investors need to look at more than just his index, he says. "They've got to accept some of the blame for going into something without any knowledge," he says.

Managed-futures funds are a subset of hedge funds. They're run by so-called commodity-trading advisers, or CTAs, who these days invest largely in financial futures. While hedge funds typically charge a 2 per cent management fee and 20 per cent of investor profits each year, a managed-futures fund often takes 7 to 9 per cent of assets invested annually and 20 per cent of any profits.

Ask questions before investing

The National Futures Association, a self-regulatory group, doesn't require managers to disclose the effects of fees on investor profits over time, says Mary McHenry, an associate director in the NFA's compliance department. "We can't just give investors all the answers," she says. "It's important that they ask questions before they invest."

Ms McHenry says she knows that brokers pitch managed futures as protection from stock market declines - and that fund risk disclosures say there's no correlation. Like hedge funds, managed-futures funds haven't been required to file with the SEC as a matter of course. However, an SEC rule has mandated that any partnership with more than 500 investors and US$10 million in assets - even a hedge fund - must file quarterly and annual reports.

The SEC has no category listing managed-futures funds, as it does for mutual funds or corporate filings. Bloomberg Markets culled through thousands of filings in several categories, including one called "SIC 6221 Unknown," to identify 63 managed- futures funds that reported to the SEC.

Even the managed-futures funds that file with the SEC don't have any obligation to disclose how fees in recent years ate up all trading gains.

The Grant Park Futures Fund filed a prospectus in April to raise US$927 million from investors. Although it included the boilerplate language saying substantial fees could offset trading profits, the document doesn't say that the US$25.6 million the fund had gained since 2009 was obliterated by fees. Investors suffered a US$223.6 million loss over that period.

Ken Steben, who runs a fund, says managed futures can be confusing to both investors and advisers.

Keith Stafford, an accountant who specialises in auditing hedge-fund and managed-futures data, says he and his colleagues are constantly amazed by the poor performance of managed futures for individual investors.

"We look at each other all the time and say, 'Why would anyone invest in this?'" says Mr Stafford, the member in charge of performance analysis at Arthur Bell, Certified Public Accountants, based in Hunt Valley, Maryland. "It's a racket." - Bloomberg

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Some car brands may change hands soon

Downturns seen as a good time to grab a new vehicle franchise

Published

Tue, Oct 15, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Despite Singapore's tough car market conditions, there is speculation that at least one European brand is set to change distributors here soon.

"Car buyers can expect some changes in the European car market here in the coming months," said a source.

But he declined to give more details or say whether the dealers taking over are existing players or new to the industry.

However, the source did say that the make or makes in question are not among the top-tier brands - which rules out market leaders like luxury marques BMW, Mercedes-Benz and Audi. Another popular European brand, Volkswagen, is run by the manufacturer itself as a direct dealership.

But why would anyone here want to take on a new brand during such tough times?

Singapore's car market has been languishing since 2009 when the government began cutting the certificate of entitlement (COE) quota sharply.

Last year, 27,899 new cars were registered, and this year's total market is set to be even smaller - up to 15 per cent smaller. The last time annual new car sales have been this low was in the mid-1990s.

As car sales plummet, so have car dealers' profits, and many have downsized their operations while some have even closed shop.

The source explained: "The brands in question have a lot of potential growth, and if those who take over can hang on long enough, they should be able to see the rewards."

He added that many people who run dealerships are "driven by passion and commitment because of the brand heritage".

"Of course, it is wonderful to make money, but some of these brands are really special, and representing them is a privilege," he said. "And who knows? Maybe Singapore's transport policy will change for the better."

He said that with a larger number of COEs expected to come onstream in a few years' time, things should brighten up for the motor industry.

The managing director of a luxury dealership agreed.

"It is hard to predict government policy but I believe it will change, although not so soon," he said. "Anyway, many dealers and consumers expect the COE supply to increase in the latter half of 2015 and 2016, based on the likely increase in vehicle deregistrations."

As for brands changing hands, he said that it is only during "bad times" that there is "an opportunity" to grab a new franchise.

"A downturn causes the industry to go through significant changes because some companies won't be able to ride it out," said the managing director.

"It is especially tough for those companies that sell only one brand, especially if it is a second- or third- tier brand."

He explained that multi- brand franchises are bigger, with economies of scale in terms of staff and showroom space.

"And it's not even necessary to have particularly deep pockets because during bad times, you don't have to do much or invest a lot. No one really expects you to sell that many cars during this period."

3 American winners

Listen to this article

Published Tue, Oct 15, 2013 · 10:00 PM

AMERICANS Eugene Fama, Lars Peter Hansen and Robert Shiller won the 2013 Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel (commonly known as the Nobel Prize for Economics) on Monday "for their empirical analysis of asset prices".

The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, which awards the eight million crown (S$1.5 million) prize, said their research has improved the forecasting of asset prices in the long term and helped the emergence of index funds in stock markets.

The award citation said Eugene Fama and several collaborators demonstrated that stock prices are extremely difficult to predict in the short run, and that new information is very quickly incorporated into prices; Robert Shiller found that stock prices fluctuate much more than corporate dividends, and that the ratio of prices to dividends tends to fall when it is high, and to increase when it is low; and Lars Peter Hansen developed a statistical method, the Generalised Method of Moments, that is particularly well suited to testing rational theories of asset pricing.

UK, China venture to build Manchester business hub

Published

Mon, Oct 14, 2013 · 10:00 PM

London

BEIJING Construction Engineering Group Co formed a venture with Manchester Airports Group and other partners to build an international business district in the UK's second-biggest city.

The buildings on the 61-hectare site in the north of England will be worth about £800 million (S$1.59 billion) when they're completed and fully leased, the partners said in a statement on Sunday. Carillion plc and the Greater Manchester Pension Fund are also part of the project, known as Airport City. It will create as many as 16,000 jobs and the development will be managed by Argent LLP, the group said.

Chinese developers including ABP Chinese (Holding) and Greenland Holding Group Co are expanding overseas as the government maintains curbs on residential housing to cool price increases. ABP is involved in the development of a third financial district in London focused on Asian businesses after the UK and China set a target three years ago of doubling trade to US$100 billion by 2015.

"Our aspiration as part of this international joint venture is to create a worldclass business destination that will open up new connections on a global level," said David Partridge, managing partner at Argent (Property Development) Services LLP.

Manchester Airport, Britain's busiest hub outside London, is used by more than 20 million passengers a year. The airport plans to open a direct airline service to China, according to the statement.

"We see our involvement in Airport City as an extension of the memorandum of understanding between China and the UK, where we have been looking to further explore joint infrastructure opportunities for some time," said Xing Yan, managing director of Beijing Construction Engineering. Bloomberg

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

World Bank debars record number of firms for fraud

Most from North America; Indonesia the only Asian nation among countries with the highest number

Published

Tue, Oct 15, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The World Bank is on the warpath against corruption and fraud, which are crippling its extensive development aid projects around the globe.

It debarred four times as many companies in the first seven months of this year as it did for the whole of last year; the number of debarments in that period has exceeded the total number from the past seven years combined.

From January through July, the international financial institution blacklisted more than 250 entities for fraud and corruption, making them ineligible for World Bank-financed contracts for specific periods.

Most of the debarred entities are from North America, with Indonesia being the only Asian nation among countries with the highest number of debarred entities.

Entities blackmarked in this way range from major multinationals to smaller firms and individual consultants. They were found to have engaged in bribery, bid-rigging, fraud and other wrongdoing related to World Bank-funded projects.

Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer's publication, The War On Corruption, a compilation and analysis of this year's debarments, said: "The World Bank is fighting back."

The international law firm noted that as much as US$40 billion worth of aid is estimated to have been stolen from some of the poorest nations in the world in the last seven years.

The World Bank has invested over US$200 billion to finance projects in developing countries around the world over the past five years. In that time, it concluded more than 600 investigations into suspected fraud, corruption and other misconduct.

Tim Coleman, Freshfields' Global Investigations partner in Washington, said: "The World Bank means business. Its ramping up of activity levels in 2013 is a clear signal that it will not tolerate corruption or fraud affecting its programmes."

Freshfields' report named North America as the region with the highest number of blacklisted entities, followed by Latin America and the Caribbean, then Europe and Central Asia.

By country, Canada topped the list with 119 debarments. The United States was next with 46.

Indonesia - the only Asian nation in the list of top offenders - came third with 43 entities debarred, followed by the United Kingdom with 40.

Data from the World Bank website noted that within Asia-Pacific, China had 18 debarments, India and Vietnam had nine each, while Malaysia, Singapore, Sri Lanka and Thailand had four each. Australia had three entities debarred, and Japan and Korea, two each.

Jane Jenkins, Freshfields' Global Investigations partner in London, noted the impact of such debarments: "Major contractors implicated in such activities can suffer severe reputational damage and stand to lose large contracts as well as the ability to bid for future ones for years to come."

However, the Bank introduced a mechanism for negotiated resolutions in 2010, and since then, has announced settlements with several major corporate groups. These settlements are similar to deferred prosecution agreements employed by regulators in the US and elsewhere.

Typically, they include a term of debarment, cooperation obligations and monitoring of compliance.

Canada's biggest engineering group, SNC Lavalin, is party to one of the largest corporate settlements.

The World Bank had debarred the multinational company and more than 100 of its affiliates for a span of 10 years from April, for misconduct in relation to Padma Bridge, a US$3 billion road-rail bridge project in Bangladesh; the project had been mired in corruption allegations.

The World Bank Sanctions Board began publishing some of its decisions in mid-2012, which Freshfields said could give an idea of the outcome of future cases.

For example, in most cases, entities are debarred for three years, and settlements tend to be in the range of 2-3 years.

Looking ahead, the Freshfields report said it expected the Bank's activity in the use of debarments and other sanctions to increase "as it seeks to put a stop to the misappropriation of its resources and the resulting weakening of its programmes".

Notorious Somali pirate 'Big Mouth' arrested

Published

Mon, Oct 14, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Brussels

ONE of Somalia's most notorious pirate leaders, known as "Big Mouth", has been arrested in Brussels and placed in custody pending charges, judicial sources said yesterday.

Mohamed Abdi Hassan, known as "Afweyne" or "Big Mouth", was being held in Bruges after being detained at Brussels airport on Saturday on disembarking from a flight from Nairobi, Belga news agency said.

Judicial sources told AFP that the federal prosecutor was due to hold a news conference yesterday. Afweyne announced in Mogadishu in January that he was quitting piracy after a highly profitable eight-year career. He said that he was working to persuade other pirates to do the same. Described last year by the UN as "one of the most notorious and influential leaders" in Somalia's pirate hub, he notably was involved in the 2008 capture of the Saudi-owned Sirius Star oil supertanker, released for a ransom of several million dollars.

He also reportedly took part in the 2008 capture of the MV Faina, a Ukrainian transport ship carrying 33 refurbished Soviet-era battle tanks, which was released after a 134-day hijack for a reported US$3 million.

Belgian media said that he was suspected also of the 2009 capture of a Belgian ship, the Pompei, held for over 70 days. AFP

site_title: Economics Nobel goes both ways
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Economics Nobel goes both ways

Listen to this article

Published Tue, Oct 15, 2013 · 10:00 PM

ECONOMICS is the only field in which two people can share a Nobel prize for saying opposing things. This old joke, provoked by the 1974 prize that went to ideological antagonists Friedrich August von Hayek and Gunnar Myrdal, is proving relevant again. Eugene Fama, Lars Peter Hansen and Robert Shiller all worked on financial markets efficiency and drew separate, if not opposing, conclusions. This is a welcome reminder that the dismal science has few absolute truths to offer - mostly questions to explore.

Hansen's merits are methodological. His key innovation, the Generalised Method of Moments (GMM), is a popular econometric technique with applications in micro and macro-economics, used to uncover relationships between variables in uncertain, complex economic environments - such as asset markets.

Unlike Hansen, Fama and Shiller are mostly known for the conclusions they - or often, others - draw from their academic work. Fama is one of the founding fathers of the "efficient market hypothesis", which roughly holds that financial markets always send the right price signals. Shiller, on the other hand, seems to have spent decades debunking the EMH, collecting empirical evidence that markets are prone to bubbles and irrational exuberance.

Three-Minute Digest

site_title: Shippers raise concerns over P3 alliance
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Shippers raise concerns over P3 alliance

P3 seen as changing structure and competitive state of the global container shipping market

Published

Tue, Oct 15, 2013 · 10:00 PM

CONTAINER shipping is back in the spotlight. Last week the Global Shippers' Forum (GSF) officially raised its concerns over the proposed P3 Global Alliance among Maersk Line, CMA-CGM and Mediterranean Shipping Company (MSC) by submitting detailed questions to the European Commission Competition Directorate in Brussels.

At the same time Drewry Maritime's latest Container Market Annual Review and Forecast 2013/14 highlights the fact that while there is a good deal of excessive market behaviour resulting in weak freight rates, ocean carriers are "getting half of it right". The half Drewry believes the lines are getting right is cutting costs.

The shippers believe, rightly, that consolidation of services will tend to restrict capacity and that will consequently put upward pressure on freight rates. Drewry's review is the latest in a long succession of industry reports that essentially point out that it is almost impossible to make long-term profits that reflect the level of investment required.

All this is depressingly familiar. What is happening now is quite simple. We are paying for the abolition of the tried and tested conference system.

More or less at the same time as container ships replaced general cargo vessels the liner shipping conference system started a gradual slide to oblivion.

The conference system is largely remembered for its complex tariffs which were primarily based on the value of cargo and its strict imposition of freight rates, including the loyalty discounts which kept shippers from using non-conference lines.

Despite the elaborate pricing structures of the many conferences, the system was not primarily about price but supply. From an early stage following the introduction of steamships it became clear that regular liner services and unregulated competition were incompatible concepts. Unrestricted competition would always lead to oversupply which would keep prices low and prevent companies from making sustained profits at levels sufficient to justify continued investment. The key element in conferences was the agreement of member lines to limit the number of vessels each put on a particular trade.

Better option

The conference system had its flaws but it served global trade well for over a hundred years. Can the same be said of the current free-for-all? Clearly the answer is "no".

"Sustainable" is today's politically correct buzzword. The current situation in the liner trades is not sustainable. In the long term there will be much more consolidation or alliances will be operated in a way that puts a sufficient brake on over-ordering of tonnage.

So either container shipping will increasingly be dominated by monopolies or the alliances will become the liner conferences of the 21st century, ensuring a "sustainable" balance between demand and supply.

An effective system of alliances would be the better option. Shippers, though, will bristle at this.

Last week GSF secretary-general Chris Welsh said: "We have raised these questions with the European competition authorities on behalf of shippers from all over the world because they are rightly concerned about the market impact of the P3. The question on every shipper's mind is: 'What will be the impact on my rates and the quality of services'."

GSF describes the proposed P3 Global Alliance as a recognised industry "game-changer" that will fundamentally change the structure and competitive state of the global container shipping market.

Mr Welsh continued: "Shippers are rightly worried about the potential of the P3 to eliminate effective competition in the world's main liner trades. We therefore need an in-depth assessment of the P3. That's why we are asking the European Commission to provide us with the essential details of the P3 and to confirm whether they have started a formal investigation or intend to do so. We need information and answers so that the GSF is in the position to protect the commercial interests of shippers internationally."

He added that GSF members will be bringing P3 to the attention of national competition authorities worldwide, and especially in Asia and in the US where the Federal Maritime Commission "is uniquely positioned to assess the potential competitive impacts of this never-before-seen aggregation of market share".

It remains to be seen whether P3 can overcome shipper hostility. I wouldn't put my money on it.

The half of the Drewry report that is bad news for container shipping lines is that over-tonnaging is still the big problem. The introduction of the new ultra large ships on the main East-West routes has actually eased oversupply there but made the situation worse on North-South trades as tonnage has been redeployed.

In the red

Drewry predicts global fleet growth next year of 7.4 per cent , "which will continue to challenge carriers' stability".

Significantly, Drewry believes that the formation of the P3 alliance is "one way of stabilising operational supply, but much more work is needed".

Neil Dekker, Drewry's head of container research, stated: "Pouring too much capacity into the system means that at some stage it will overflow and we would argue that this has already happened to some extent. Although 2013 will turn out to be an OK year for the industry and the main stakeholders should make a small profit, many carriers will still be in the red."

An industry with some players just keeping their heads above water and many others slowly drowning is an industry ripe for consolidation.

site_title: Pure Beauty Investments plans $16.67m takeover of Singapore Medical Group
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Pure Beauty Investments plans $16.67m takeover of Singapore Medical Group

Published

Mon, Oct 14, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

PURE Beauty Investments plans to acquire Catalist-listed Singapore Medical Group (SMG) for $16.67 million.

The former announced yesterday, through CIMB Bank Berhad, Singapore Branch, that it intends to make a voluntary conditional cash offer for all of SMG's 145.74 million issued and paid-up ordinary shares.

The takeover offer price stands at about 11.44 cents per share, which represents a 4 per cent premium above the last transacted price on Oct 8, and a 12 per cent discount to the volume weighted average price for the 12-month period prior.

SMG provides multi-disciplinary specialist healthcare services across ophthalmology, aesthetic medicine, sports medicine and oncology, and was listed on July 23, 2009.

Pure Beauty was incorporated in the British Virgin Islands on April 22 this year, and was set up for the purpose of making the offer. It has not carried on any other business since its incorporation, and has no subsidiaries.

Pure Beauty said that as it is planning to enter the specialist healthcare services sector, its acquisition of SMG will enhance the latter's growth prospects. It added that it has "no firm intentions to introduce any major changes" to SMG's business.

It intends to preserve the listing status of SMG on the Catalist board.

Pure Beauty's current shareholders are Tony Tan Choon Keat and Silver Mines Global Ltd - a company incorporated in the British Virgin Islands on May 28 this year, with its sole director and sole shareholder being Red Ancient Global Ltd. The latter, in turn, is owned solely by Ho Choon Hou, the other director of Pure Beauty.

As at yesterday, Pure Beauty is authorised to issue a maximum number of 50,000 ordinary shares of par value of US$1 for each ordinary share. It currently has an issued and paid-up share capital of US$7, and share premium of $7.03 million, divided into seven ordinary shares held by Tony Tan and Silver Mines in the proportion of 4:3, respectively.

As at yesterday, Beng Teck Liang, who is a person acting in concert with Pure Beauty, holds 29.77 million SMG shares.

Pure Beauty has received irrevocable undertakings from SMG's executive chairman and chief executive officer on a variety of conditions.

The offer document will be despatched to shareholders within the next three weeks.

site_title: S'pore gaining popularity as investment arbitration seat
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

S'pore gaining popularity as investment arbitration seat

Philip Morris Asia dispute shows why the Republic is seen as an ideal venue

Published

Tue, Oct 15, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Singapore is starting to give established investment arbitration seats such as London a run for their money - if the closely watched multi-billion-dollar Philip Morris Asia dispute with Australia is anything to go by.

The case involves Australia's Tobacco Plain Packaging Act 2011 which, the company alleges, "bars the use of intellectual property on tobacco products and packaging . . . with the consequential effect of substantially diminishing the value of (its) investments in Australia".

In arguing for Singapore to be the place for investment arbitration over London, Philip Morris Asia said in court papers that Singapore's judiciary is highly regarded, and has "demonstrated minimal intervention and a supportive attitude towards arbitration."

While the number of investment arbitrations held in Singapore is still small, that number has been growing as more countries are striking bilateral and multilateral treaties that usually include investment protection provisions and provide for dispute resolution through arbitration.

And Singapore is now on the radar - as an alternative to London, Paris and The Hague, among others - because more of such treaty cases involve Asia, said senior counsel Cavinder Bull of Drew & Napier LLC and deputy chairman of the Singapore International Arbitration Centre (SIAC) Board.

Mr Bull, a vice-president of the SIAC Court, also cited confidence in Singapore as an arbitration venue.

Singapore has been the venue of hearings in a number of Washington-based International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) investment arbitrations.

Case in point - Singapore's Maxwell Chambers is party to a memorandum of understanding with ICSID for the conduct of hearings here in investor-state disputes. A number of ad hoc investor-state disputes seated in Singapore have also taken place.

As at June 30, four cases involving South and East Asian governments have been registered with ICSID, Chong Yee Leong, a partner with Allen & Gledhill LLP noted. That compares with five cases each in 2011 and 2012, and just one or two cases annually from 2000 through 2010, he said, citing data from ICSID, which was established under the auspices of the World Bank.

"As more of the ICSID cases involved South and East Asian governments, it is only natural and appropriate that the seat of the investment arbitration should be in South and East Asia," Mr Chong explained.

He added that Singapore was considered a natural seat, given its reputation as a preferred choice for international commercial arbitration in Asia in the past decade. The SIAC handled 235 new cases last year, up from 188 in 2011. The total sum in dispute for new cases also hit a new high of $3.61 billion in 2012 - almost three times the previous year's $1.32 billion.

The SIAC, which is handling more than 600 active cases, has been involved in arbitrations involving state parties, but to date hasn't been called upon to act as the administering institution in an investment arbitration. But the SIAC is able to administer any investment arbitration arising under the 2009 Asean Comprehensive Investment Agreement.

The very factors that made Singapore a pre-eminent commercial arbitration hub also make it an ideal choice as a seat for ad hoc investment arbitrations or a venue for such disputes administered by ICSID.

In the Philip Morris Asia case, the company pointed out that since 2004, arbitration judges have been "specifically designated in the Singapore High Court to deal with any applications under the International Arbitration Act (IAA) and that the quality of jurisprudence which emanates from those three judges (from the Court of Appeal) is of the highest order."

It described Singapore as a "modern and cost-efficient arbitration centre, with the costs of hotel accommodation and other facilities lower than in London". Furthermore, Singapore is more convenient for the parties to travel to since Philip Morris Asia is based in Hong Kong, its executives are in Australia, and most of its counsel are based in either Australia or New Zealand (with some lawyers here at Maxwell Chambers). A number of its witnesses are also based in the Asia-Pacific region, it said.

The case, which is still ongoing, will set a landmark precedent on whether a state can demand plain packaging for cigarettes, said Michael Pryles, a former SIAC chairman and who has sat on several investor-state disputes as arbitrator.

Recent Singapore court decisions on applications by parties for relief under the IAA also illustrate the judiciary's strong support for international arbitration, party autonomy and the finality of arbitral awards.

Recently, an Ernst & Young partner in Singapore was compelled by the High Court to produce documents for investment arbitration proceedings between the Lao government and two casino investors over US$23.8 million in taxes they were forced to pay allegedly because of an improperly conducted audit.

"This decision is illustrative of the judicial support of arbitration, and further endorses Singapore as an ideal forum for international investment arbitrations," said Koh Swee Yen, partner of WongPartnership, who represents the two casino investors.

As for the economic impact, Mr Bull said that arbitration cases tend to involve a significant number of lawyers and many days of hearing. "This translates into more expenditure in Singapore, as lawyers, arbitrators and witnesses spend time here, using legal and other services based here. Singapore law firms will also benefit in that they will have more opportunities to do complex and interesting work."

site_title: Fire-fallout freebies for SingTel's home customers
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Fire-fallout freebies for SingTel's home customers

StarHub to unveil details of its own 'gesture of goodwill and appreciation'

Published

Mon, Oct 14, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

SINGTEL is going the whole hog, offering months of freebies to customers affected by service disruptions after last Wednesday's fire at its Bukit Panjang exchange. Even so, the question of compensation for the telco's corporate customers, which include banks and other large businesses, remains an open one.

On the residential end, all 60,000 of SingTel's affected broadband customers will get three months' worth of free speed boost, the telco said yesterday. At the same time, the 44,000 affected mio TV customers will have a whole month of free channel surfing across all of the pay-TV service's channels. The affected customers on the telco's fixed copper line network, who may also be SingTel's fibre customers, will have a month of free local calls for their troubles.

All the affected residential customers will be contacted within the next two weeks. The other shoe - what the telco will do about its corporate customers who experienced service outages last week - has yet to drop.

"For business customers, we will be contacting them individually to better appreciate how they were affected and address their needs separately," said Yuen Kuan Moon, SingTel's CEO Consumer Singapore. Asked about the possibility of compensation for its corporate customers, Mr Yuen said: "We will have to go back and look at our service agreement."

In response to SingTel, a StarHub spokeswoman said yesterday: "As a corporate customer of SingTel, we look forward to such a discussion with them. . . The service disruption caused by the fire at SingTel's exchange has inconvenienced our customers." StarHub itself is due to make it up to its own customers with a "gesture of goodwill and appreciation", and will provide details soon.

Last Wednesday, the fire that started inside one of the fibre chambers in SingTel's exchange burnt 149 fibre cables which then disrupted services for homes and key businesses. About two-thirds of the burnt fibre cables had belonged to OpenNet, which also meant disruptions for customers of StarHub and M1.

Already, DBS Bank, which was affected by service disruptions last Wednesday, is working with the telco to find out why the network contingency plan had not worked for some of its branches. As SingTel convenes an internal inquiry panel that will report to the group's board, additional costs are bound to follow, from the implementation of more measures to avoid a similar event, to the possibility of a fine by the regulator. Already, the telco is considering adding more fire-suppression systems and installing more spare fibre.

Even as the costs mount, the telco's sheer size will help it shrug off the financial fallout. SingTel said that the fire and service disruptions will not have a material impact on its earnings. "A tsunami could wash over Singapore, and SingTel wouldn't feel a thing," an analyst told The Business Times yesterday. Another analyst said that the impact of giving affected customers free services will be negligible. "A free month here, a free month there, that's not going to change anything financially," he said.

On Monday, complaints from pockets of customers persisted, even though the fibre strands had been reconnected last week. Yesterday evening, M1 estimated that about 300 of its fibre customers were still affected. "While OpenNet informed us on last Friday morning that all affected fibres have been re-connected, some of the connections are still not working as intended," said an M1 spokeswoman. On StarHub's end yesterday afternoon, about 500 of its fibre broadband customers continued to have problems with their service. While the fibre cables might have been fixed, the resumption of service might be held up by hardware on the customers' end, according to SingTel's Mr Yuen.

Compounding matters, while SingTel has "visibility" on its own customers, it says it does not have the same access to other service providers' customers. "I do not have the visibility of their network. It's their customers. They have their own electronics...(If) they...tell us that this is not working, we can troubleshoot with them," Mr Yuen said. According to him, while the core network had been robust, it was the last-mile connection - the infrastructure coming out of the fibre chamber - that had been impacted by the fire. Replicating this last-mile connection entirely, Mr Yuen said, is not feasible. "It's tantamount to having two stacks of water pipes from your home from two different sources," he said.

Yesterday, the Infocomm Devlopment Authority of Singapore urged operators to cooperate and step up efforts for service restoration.

site_title: Plane sales stall as US shutdown continues
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Plane sales stall as US shutdown continues

Published

Tue, Oct 15, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[DALLAS] Eni, Italy's biggest energy company, has a group of 10 Houston business people waiting to buy its Dassault Aviation Falcon 2000 jet. What it doesn't have is the US paperwork needed to sell the plane.

The partial government shutdown entering its 11th day last Friday is keeping the purchasers from closing a deal with Rome-based Eni valued at about US$5 million, said Bob Nygren, a founder of aircraft broker AeroSmith Penny in Houston. Eni has stashed the twin-engine Falcon at a suburban Dallas airport.

Executive jets aren't the only ones being sidelined. Hundreds of sales from vendors as varied as Airbus SAS and individuals are stalled as the Federal Aviation Administration's aircraft-registration office remains shuttered. Titles for US$2.5 billion of jetliners, small planes and helicopters may be in limbo if the shutdown continues.

"This is a mess," said William King, a vice-president at Cirrus Aircraft, which installs parachutes on its planes so they float to the ground in an engine failure. "Even if they settle this out quickly in the next 10 days, we could still be in a position of not meeting our delivery numbers by Jan 1."

The snags are part of the economic ripple effects from the first government shutdown in 17 years. Five US senators urged FAA administrator Michael Huerta in a letter last week to reopen the Oklahoma City-based registry because it's "inflicting unnecessary hardship on aviation industries".

None of the about 800 officials now being recalled to ensure air safety will be assigned to the registry, according to the FAA. During the shutdown, US law prohibits the FAA from running the registry and other operations that aren't protecting "life and property", the agency said in a statement last week.

Title work for planes of all sizes flows through the office, which is tucked within a sprawling FAA campus and usually operates "locked down like Fort Knox", said Clay Healey, owner of AIC Title Service in Oklahoma City, referring to the US gold reserves stored in Kentucky.

Seated at rows of desks in a documents room, title-company workers download aircraft information unavailable outside the registry's walls, Mr Healey said in an interview. A bank-teller-type window allows users to slide in paperwork for time-stamping by an FAA official, he said.

Without the FAA's permission, US$514 million of Europe-built jets from Airbus can't be brought into the US for carriers including US Airways Group Inc and AMR's American Airlines.

"This is a very unfortunate situation," Maryanne Greczyn, a US spokeswoman for Toulouse, France-based Airbus, said by email. "We are hopeful for a rapid-as-possible solution."

More than 30 companies, including Airbus, Boeing and units of General Electric and Bank of America, sent a letter last Friday to Secretary of Transportation Anthony Foxx, requesting the registry be reopened on security concerns. The FAA, among other things, provides the Transportation Security Administration and law enforcement agencies with aircraft-related information, they said in the letter.

The companies also said they're concerned that the increase in an already large backlog for new registration applications, combined with the expiry of temporary authorisations, will cause "enormous delivery delays".

At least two planes from Canada's Bombardier with a list value of about US$75 million, one of them for Delta Air Lines, are also in limbo, and Brazil's Embraer said this week that its US regional-jet deliveries may be affected "in the coming weeks" if FAA offices stay shuttered.

Boeing has been making deliveries to US customers that submitted registry paperwork before the shutdown and to international airlines that list planes with regulators in their home markets, said Doug Alder, a spokesman for the Chicago-based planemaker. US carriers also can take planes using temporary registration forms, he said.

Cirrus had to put delivery on hold last week for one of its single-engine planes because of the shutdown, Mr King said in an interview.

Eni is selling its used Falcon to upgrade to a G550 from General Dynamics' Gulfstream, according to Mr Nygren, the Houston-based aircraft broker. He declined to identify his buyer group, and Eni didn't respond to telephone and e-mailed requests for comment about the sale. - WP

site_title: China's property bonds offer good returns
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

China's property bonds offer good returns

US$ securities advance in line with housing market demand

Published

Mon, Oct 14, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Hong Kong

US DOLLAR bonds issued by China's developers are delivering five times the global average for debt denominated in the US currency as housing demand strengthens in the world's most populous nation.

Property securities, which account for 32 per cent of the Bank of America Merrill Lynch index of China's dollar bonds, have advanced 5.7 per cent since the end of June, after handing investors a 1.6 per cent loss in the first six months of this year. That compares with a 3.5 per cent average gain in overall Chinese notes in the greenback and 1.2 per cent for debt in the currency globally, according to BofA indexes.

Home sales in China have increased as the economy shows signs of a rebound and the government refrains from adding to market cooling measures. Country Garden Holdings, controlled by Yang Huiyan, the nation's richest woman, said last week it had already exceeded its 2013 property sales target by the end of September. Premier Li Keqiang plans to build homes as an estimated 260 million migrant workers need to move into cities to meet demand for labour.

"With almost half of China's population still living in rural areas, housing demand will rise as the nation continues its urbanisation," said Ken Hu at BOCHK Asset Management in Hong Kong, a unit of China's fourth-largest lender. "Developers are getting lower profit margins but turnover has increased, which is positive for bondholders. We prefer those with strong cash flows and continue to buy property bonds on a selective basis."

New home sales in Beijing almost doubled in the first six days of the National Day holidays from a year earlier, while business in Shanghai increased as well, China Securities Journal reported on Oct 8. Average daily transaction volumes in the Oct 1-7 period surged 50 per cent in 12 of 32 major cities monitored by Soufun Holdings, owner of the country's biggest real estate website.

"On average, companies in the sector have achieved 70 to 80 per cent of their full-year targets," said Manjesh Verma at Mitsubishi UFJ Securities in Hong Kong. "Over the next month or so, the bonds will hold up well, given sales have been pretty strong for a majority of developers in the year to date."

BOCHK's RMB High Yield Bond Fund, all of whose top 10 holdings were Chinese property developers as of the end of September, has put 5.7 per cent of its money in Shanghai-based developer CIFI Holdings Group's 12.25 per cent five-year dollar notes. The fund has invested another 5.5 per cent in Kaisa Group's 12.875 per cent US currency-denominated debt maturing in 2017.

The yield on Kaisa securities due 2017 has fallen 383 basis points to 8.92 per cent on Oct 11 since reaching a record 12.75 per cent in November 2012, data compiled by Bloomberg show. The rate on CIFI's debt was 9.94 per cent, compared with an all-time high of 12.25 per cent.

The rally may halt in the short term as the government is likely to roll out measures to cool the property market when Communist Party leaders meet in November to set economic policy for the coming years, according to Eric Liu at Aberdeen Asset Management in Singapore. "There could be measures to cut speculative demand, for example mortgage and housing price restrictions, particularly in cities with high property price appreciation," said Mr Liu. "I see property taxes being implemented in cities beyond Chongqing and Shanghai."

Increased supply of property bonds will also limit gains, Mr Liu said. Franshion Properties (China) sold US$300 million of five-year dollar bonds at 5.375 per cent on Oct 9, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. Greenland Hong Kong Holdings raised US$700 million from a three-year bond sale priced at 4.75 per cent on Oct 10, while China Taiping Insurance Group (HK) Co and Wynn Macau sold a combined US$1 billion of debt.

"Issuers would rather lock in a relatively lower rate now instead of waiting for later," said Mr Verma at Mitsubishi UFJ. "Demand is still strong for sector names due to robust sales reported by a majority of developers, and their adequate liquidity levels."

The average yield on Chinese dollar debt has dropped 55 basis points to 5.78 per cent on Oct 11 from the end of June, BofA Merrill Lynch indexes showed. The yield on China's 10-year government bonds climbed 51 basis points to 4.03 per cent in the same period, according to Chinabond data. Bloomberg

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

STI drops 14 pts in quiet, cautious session

Published

Mon, Oct 14, 2013 · 10:00 PM

A THOROUGHLY bo-ring and featureless session yesterday saw the Straits Times Index drift in low volume to a 14.46-point loss at 3,165.25, a situation not helped by the closure of Hong Kong and China for the Chung Yeung festival.

The US government's inability to agree on a budget and the possibility that it might default on its debt payments if its borrowing ceiling isn't raised by Thursday were said to be the main factors behind the index's weakness, though it was likely that short-term players were reluctant to keep positions open over a public holiday and so opted to sell first.

Similarly, broad swathes of the penny segment came under pressure, partly because of the reason given above but also because of exchange-imposed curbs on three speculative counters last week that brought the three crashing down.

Because of elevated caution surrounding many pennies, the outcome was an advance-decline score of 121-305 excluding warrants.

The story was the same for the rest of the low-priced segment - of the 20 most actively traded stocks, all were priced below 50 cents and 15 ended with a loss on the day.

The best indicator of just how lacklustre the session was came in the form of business done - 1.9 billion units worth $558 million, which in dollar terms was about half of last week's daily average.

Among blue chips, media and property group Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) saw its shares end one cent higher at $4.13 after the company reported a 25 per cent drop in profit to $431 million.

In a "sell", OSK DMG noted that although SPH gave an all-time high total FY13 dividend of 40 cents, FY13 recurring payout excluding the 18-cent special dividend from the listing of the SPH real estate investment trust was 22 cents, lower than the 24 cents paid out in the last two years.

"Management has maintained that dividend payout will be a high percentage of its recurring earnings. Thus, given our weaker earnings outlook on the counter, we think the cut in payouts could remain," said OSK DMG, which lowered its target price from $4 to $3.60.

OCBC Investment Research, however, in its report on SPH, said it sees SPH management's twin initiatives for growth and cost savings to be key positives and would look for execution and preliminary results over the first half of the new financial year. It set a fair value of $4.14 for the stock.

On the external front, the main issue confronting markets is that US lawmakers have not been able to reach a compromise on a federal budget and the raising of the government's borrowing ceiling to enable the Treasury to pay its bills.

In its Global Daily Insight yesterday, ABN Amro said it believes a deal will be struck between the GOP and Democrats at the eleventh hour but added that any Senate deal would need to be approved in the House of Representatives, where it will most likely arrive not far before the Oct 17 deadline.

"Although the dynamics of the debt ceiling debate have changed considerably over the weekend, it is clearly positive that both parties are still trying to find a way out off the fiscal impasse," said the bank.

"As such, we think that markets will hold their nerves (on Monday). That said, the Oct 17 deadline is nearing and we increasingly would expect to see more financial market unrest if no deal is in place just before or after that date."

site_title: Food prices push China's September inflation to 7-month high
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Food prices push China's September inflation to 7-month high

Policy response unlikely as analysts cite typhoon and holiday for the rise

Published

Mon, Oct 14, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Beijing

INFLATION rose to a seven-month high in September mainly driven by a busy holiday season and bad weather but should not lead to tightening as China's economy is just beginning to rebound and still has room to grow.

CPI rose 3.1 per cent last month against 2.6 per cent in August, the National Bureau of Statistics said. Though a seasonal pickup was expected, analysts had expected inflation to remain under 3 per cent.

The NBS said a sharp rise in food prices was mostly responsible for the unexpected spike due to a major typhoon which hit the eastern and southern coasts last month. China was also on holiday in late September and for one week in October, generally a time when price pressures increase.

Food prices in September jumped 6.1 per cent year on year, accelerating from the 4.7 per cent rise in August. Fresh vegetable prices rose 18.9 per cent in the month.

"The higher consumer price data may have been due to a (temporary) food supply shock," said Tim Condon, economist at ING. "But there is nothing from this data that suggests a policy response is needed."

Analysts don't expect any policy action unless inflationary pressures continue. China's economy has just bottomed out after growth fell to 7.5 per cent last quarter. Though it is showing some signs of recovery after the government implemented a small stimulus over the summer, the rebound remains uncertain.

August economic data was mostly positive but the HSBC PMI in October was substantially lower than expected and exports published over the weekend fell, questioning the strength of the recovery in China and overseas.

Analysts say a high inflation rate could limit more measures to support future growth as September's CPI is just above the 3 per cent guideline rate set by the central bank for deposits meaning that lowering interest rates further would harm savings.

"Even though CPI inflation could trend up further for the remainder of this year, overall inflation pressures will likely remain modest. Relatively accommodative monetary conditions are expected to stay in place," Qu Hongbin, economist with HSBC, said.

Looking forward, analysts say CPI should stay below the government target of 3.5 per cent as factories continue to destock and PPI remains weak, limiting upstream price pressures.

Producer price deflation, prices at factory gates, continued to decrease: -1.6 per cent in August to -1.3 per cent in September, as domestic demand shows signs of strengthening, albeit slowly.

The PPI figure "shows that market demand is becoming more active and the macro economy is stabilising and rebounding", National Bureau of Statistics analyst Yu Qiumei said in a statement. But analysts estimate PPI to remain in negative territory through the rest of the year as domestic demand has yet to pick up substantially. The government is scheduled to release GDP growth for the third quarter on Friday.

site_title: US MNCs up investments in Singapore
content:
US MNCs up investments in Singapore

Published

Tue, Oct 15, 2013 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Despite tough economic conditions, multinational corporations (MNCs) from the United States have upped their investments in Singapore, giving the city-state the honour of hosting the single largest US investment in the Asia-Pacific region.

Cumulative direct investments here jumped from US$118.57 billion in 2011 to US$138.60 billion in book value last year, according to the US Department of Commerce's latest figures.

The increase was in tandem with still-strong investment returns locally for US MNCs; their profits in Singapore climbed from US$21.07 billion (without current cost adjustment) to US$21.17 billion, at a time when global economic uncertainties were clipping American investments elsewhere in the world.

In contrast, Singapore companies' investments in the US were less impressive - but still notable. Their investments crept up from US$24.21 billion in 2011 to US$26.24 billion in 2012, behind those of Japan (US$308.25 billion) and Australia (US$42.69 billion), among the Asia-Pacific countries.

And Singapore's investments in the US stayed profitable, yielding returns of US$1.16 billion in 2011 and US$0.74 billion in 2012.

Globally, US direct investments increased from US$4,084.66 billion in 2011 to US$4,453.31 billion last year - with Europe (US$2,477.04 billion) accounting for over half of the investments. The single largest US investment was in the Netherlands (US$645.09 billion).

Latin America and other countries in the Western Hemisphere (US$869.27 billion), such as Barbados and the Dominican Republic, have the second biggest chunk of the US investments by region. The Asia-Pacific region (US$651.31 billion) accounted for the third biggest share.

Until two years ago, the US MNCs' biggest investment in the Asia-Pacific region was in Australia (US$137.26 billion), followed by Japan (US$126.03 billion) and then, Singapore. US investment in Australia fell to US$132.83 billion in 2012, bringing it below Japan with US$133.97 billion.

A big chunk (US$79.18 billion) of the US investments here, however, were in holding companies, compared with US$39.16 billion for Australia. The bulk of US investments (US$78.66 billion) in Japan were sunk in the finance and insurance industries, excluding banks.

US direct investments in China rose from US$54.07 billion in 2009 to US$58.99 billion in 2010. But they then fell to US$55.30 billion in 2011 and US$51.36 billion last year.

US MNCs' global income slipped from US$456.52 billion in 2011 to US$448.88 billion in 2011. It dropped from US$79.37 billion to US$76.93 billion in the Asia-Pacific region, including Japan, China and Hong Kong.

Global foreign direct investments in the US also increased last year, up from US$2,502.63 billion in 2011 to US$2,650.83 billion. Asia-Pacific companies raised their investments from US$409.51 billion to US$427.68 billion.

Returns for these global investments also rose - from US$161.78 billion to US$170.91 billion, with those from the Asia-Pacific rising from US$23.75 billion to $25.88 billion.

The acquisition will be funded through internal resources, and is not expected to have any material impact on the consolidated net tangible assets and earnings per share of the company for the current financial year ending Dec 31.

Shares in Nam Cheong closed 1.8 per cent higher yesterday at 28.5 cents.

site_title: Airbus expects A380 demand to mend
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Airbus expects A380 demand to mend

Issues with wing and the global financial crisis had hurt sales of the superjumbo

Published

Mon, Oct 14, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Sydney

EUROPEAN Aeronautic, Defence & Space expects demand for the Airbus SAS A380 superjumbo, the world's biggest passenger plane, to recover after issues with the wing and the global financial crisis hurt sales.

"While we cannot be happy with the sales level that we have today, I strongly believe that the 380 will recover," EADS CEO Tom Enders said in Sydney yesterday.

The Toulouse, France-based planemaker "was a bit impacted by the financial and economic crisis, but also by the wing-rib problems," he said.

Airbus, targeting to sell 25 of the superjumbos this year, won an order for 20 A380s in June from Doric Asset Finance even as Deutsche Lufthansa AG scrapped contracts for three. Newer models from Boeing and others that Airbus itself is building mean the economics of the A380 need further improvement, Tom Williams, Airbus executive vice-president for programmes, said in June.

Sales will pick up because there is a strong trend for ever larger aircraft, particularly in Asian countries and markets in the Middle East, Mr Enders later said in an interview with Bloomberg Television. "There's quite a lot of potential," he said.

The size of the aircraft, which carries up to 525 passengers, means carriers have to push harder to make flights profitable, Mr Williams had said. The A380, with an average list price of US$403.9 million, is powered either by Rolls-Royce Holdings turbines or ones built by a joint venture between General Electric and United Technologies' Pratt & Whitney.

Airbus, the world's second-largest planemaker, surpassed its 1,000-order annual sales target with three months to spare. The company won 1,112 orders in the first nine months before cancellations after securing deals for 170 planes in September alone. Boeing said on Oct 3 that it had booked 1,023 gross orders.

The European planemaker has exceeded 1,000 orders only four times in its history, setting a record total in 2011, when it secured 1,608 gross sales.

EADS booked 820 million euros (S$1.39 billion) in charges last year, with the wing-rib fixes on the A380 consuming 522 million euros. The planemaker struggled for orders for its flagship model last year after cracks appeared in wing components.

The A380, which entered service in October 2007 through Singapore Airlines, also suffered a blow in 2010 following an engine explosion on a Qantas Airways superjumbo. The Sydney-based carrier grounded its fleet of A380s for more than three weeks following the accident. Bloomberg

site_title: Country homes back in vogue in UK
content:
Country homes back in vogue in UK

Recovery spreads beyond London thanks to government mortgage guarantee

Published

Mon, Oct 14, 2013 · 10:00 PM

London

IT took more than a year for Mark Hudson to find his six-bedroom home in the English countryside. Within weeks of moving in, he got a bid that topped the £1.75 million (S$3.5 million) the property cost.

"Somebody called offering a significantly higher sum," said Mr Hudson, a 55-year-old manager at a publishing company, who in August swapped his home in Clapham, a London district favoured by young bankers and lawyers, for Dorset, the farm-dotted county 202 kilometres south-west of London that was the setting for Thomas Hardy's Tess of the D'Urbervilles. "It looks like we caught it just at the right time," he said.

Country homes are coming back into fashion, after lagging behind urban locations such as London's West End since the 2007 financial crisis when banks cut off mortgages. Prices for manor houses, farmhouses and cottages valued at more than £750,000 climbed at the fastest rate in more than three years in the third quarter, Knight Frank said in a report yesterday, as Prime Minister David Cameron makes reviving the housing market central to his efforts to pull the economy out of recession.

"It's UK economic growth and broader housing market confidence," said Liam Bailey, global head of residential research at the London-based property broker.

The government last week introduced the second phase of its Help to Buy programme, which offers mortgage guarantees that allow purchases with down payments as low as 5 per cent. The first phase, which began in April, provided interest-free loans for buyers of newly built homes. The programme has contributed to the strongest housing market since the financial crisis, even as two thirds of 31 economists surveyed by Bloomberg described it as "bad" policy.

"Help to Buy has obviously been a catalyst that has encouraged people," Mr Bailey said. "It's stimulated appetite to get into the market and that's not only the lower-end first-time buyers - it's right through into the prime sector."

In July, homebuyers took out 3,900 loans of £500,000 or more, the most since September 2007, according to the Council of Mortgage Lenders. There's also more willingness to lend at higher loan-to-value ratios, according to Henry Knight, managing director at mortgage broker Springtide Capital.

Two years ago, Barclays unit Woolwich, Nationwide Building Society and Lloyds Banking Group's Halifax "stopped agreeing mortgages for more than about £1 million, but now they've moved up to £2 million and some have gone to £3 million," Mr Knight said. "There are just more lenders playing in that market now."

Knight Frank's prime country-house index, based on data from the firm's UK branches, shows that prices rose 0.8 per cent in the third quarter from the previous three months. Gains were led by Virginia Water, Berkhamsted and Cobham, just outside London. Prices climbed 0.4 per cent on an annual basis.

The measure includes manor houses, defined by Knight Frank as a large property standing in extensive grounds; farmhouses, which typically have six bedrooms and several acres of land including garden, paddock and barns; and cottages, which normally have four bedrooms and about an acre of land.

While demand for properties within commuting distance of London was strongest, prime country homes in every region of England climbed for the first time in two-and-a-half years during the quarter, according to a reported published by Savills plc last week.

"This is your last chance to buy before stock goes down and prices really start to rise," Yolande Barnes, director of residential research at the London-based broker, said.

Current offerings from Savills include Park Place, an eight-bedroom period house on the edge of Windsor Great Park with cottages and stables on about 15 acres. The property, about an hour's walk from Queen Elizabeth II's Windsor Castle and close to English private school Eton College, is priced at £20 million.

Savills, along with Hamptons International, is also selling Bayfields Farm, a country house in Hampshire, about 48 km from Highclere Castle, where TV show Downton Abbey is filmed, for £2 million.

The value of UK luxury homes had plunged in the wake of the 2008 collapse of Lehman Brothers Holdings and the ensuing credit freeze and recession. Average prices of homes in London's most expensive neighbourhoods fell 25 per cent in 2008, while those in the countryside fell 20 per cent, Knight Frank's Mr Bailey said.

Mortgages of more than £500,000 to home buyers dropped by almost 50 per cent between 2007 and 2008, according to the Council of Mortgage Lenders.

London's property market began to recover in 2009, in part because of affluent foreigners seeking a haven from turmoil in the Middle East and the wider European debt crisis.

These buyers, attracted by mansions a short walk from Harrods and Buckingham Palace, helped push the price of luxury homes in central London up 23 per cent since their last peak in Autumn 2007. Prices of prime country homes remain down 20 per cent, according to Knight Frank.

Now the recovery is spreading beyond London. The number of homes sold in the UK reached the most in nearly four years in July, according to the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors. That helped push the value of prime country homes up for the third consecutive quarter, Knight Frank said.

House prices in affluent areas about an hour from London climbed 1.6 per cent during the three months, while those in the remainder of the south of England climbed 1.2 per cent, according to Savills.

UK's homebuilders have been among the biggest beneficiaries of revived housing demand, with an index of the companies gaining 47 per cent this year, compared with the 10 per cent advance for the FTSE 100 Index. Persimmon plc, the largest UK builder by market value, rose the most in almost two months on Oct 9 after Goldman Sachs Group said the stock may increase by 70 per cent within six months.

Homebuilders are increasing productivity to satisfy new demand, which may be a mixed blessing for country estates.

"Prices are moving up against a background of four years of low supply in the country house market," Mr Bailey said. "If this positive sentiment pulls in more supply, that will hang a question mark over the sustainability of this growth."

For Mr Hudson, waiting to sell his London home proved fortunate as prices rose in the capital, while he said they fell last year where he was looking.

"You'd see a house listed and a few months later it would still be on the market and the price had dropped," Mr Hudson said. "When we finally bought it was more of a lifestyle choice, we were never sure it was going to be a good investment."

After selling the home in Clapham for £1.3 million, with an extra £475,000 he could afford the six-bedroom country house with a cottage, swimming pool and eight acres of land.

"I had a feeling the time was right and London's housing market was coming to a peak," he said. "Maybe I was wrong on that point, because in fact that peak seems to go on getting higher and higher." Bloomberg

site_title: More control over BYOD needed: IDC
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

More control over BYOD needed: IDC

Companies need to work on security and simplifying IT, writes KEVIN KWANG

Published

Sun, Oct 13, 2013 · 10:00 PM

BYOD - bring-your-own-device - is an ongoing trend sweeping through enterprises as employees opt to bring their mobile computing devices to work. However, companies will need to evolve their mobility strategies to a "choose-your-own-device" (CYOD) one in order to have a more controllable, secure network environment.

According to Charles Reed Anderson, Asia-Pacific head of telecom practice and mobility lead at research agency IDC, BYOD is fast spreading as workers eschew company-issued notebooks and laptops, for personal devices that tend to be lighter and have better battery life.

However, this then brings challenges to the corporate backend because these systems are not configured to cope with secured access by myriad devices and users, he noted during a briefing session held by the research firm last week.

Avneesh Saxena, group vice-president of domain research at IDC Asia-Pacific, added that, based on the company's latest C-Suite Barometer 2013 study, the top priorities among business leaders are to build a more secure IT environment - which garnered 15 per cent of the total response - and to simplify existing IT.

Mobility-based

This is corroborated by projected IT spending, with mobility-based investments topping the list among the executives polled, while security, business continuity and disaster recovery came in at second spot, Mr Saxena pointed out.

Against this backdrop of increased demand by business users to have simpler IT and a concurrent focus on securing corporate networks and data, enterprises need to consider moving away from the end-user-driven BYOD model to a more corporate-led CYOD strategy, suggested Mr Anderson.

Explaining, the analyst said the CYOD strategy means companies get to decide on what operating systems (OSes) and devices they want to support on the backend. "So if an employee goes to IT and asks for a device with a specific OS, IT can point to a range and let them pick from there," he noted.

This then helps move the company from simply opening up the network to all its employees - a move that is nothing but a cost to the organisation since employees will just make use of the access to stream videos or other such non-work-related activities that offer no benefits, he added.

For many organisations in Asia-Pacific, however, they remain rooted in the first three stages of IDC's Mobile Maturity Model, Mr Anderson revealed.

Stage one, for instance, is when companies adopt ad hoc mobile device management (MDM) solutions from smaller vendors, and this was the stage where 57.3 per cent of polled companies were at when the study was released this July.

The other two stages - described as "opportunistic" and "repeatable" - account for 11.4 per cent and 3.8 per cent of companies, respectively.

Notably, 21 per cent of the companies polled scored too low to even make it on the chart, said the analyst, who pointed out this is an opportunity for enterprise mobility vendors to capitalise on.

Strategy

"Vendors should tailor their offerings to assist these companies who have yet developed an enterprise mobility strategy, and provide them solutions that are aligned to their needs and not piecemeal deployments," he said.

In terms of markets that are savvier in deploying enterprise mobility initiatives, Mr Anderson said Australia, New Zealand and Singapore are leading the way.

By comparison, markets such as Hong Kong, Taiwan, China and Taiwan remain in the first stage of the model, he pointed out.

From a verticals perspective, the financial services sector in markets such as Australia, Singapore and Hong Kong are being forward-looking in their mobility strategies, while healthcare is also driving more mature, well-developed initiatives, he said.

That said, the analyst pointed out some of the challenges hindering organisations' efforts to implement sound mobile strategies.

These include having to account for the different stakeholders and their varied needs, the confusing number of vendors and partners in the market right now, and having the capability of putting all the pieces together and making the backend work, he said.

K-Green Trust Q3 earnings up 7.4% at $3.8m

Published

Mon, Oct 14, 2013 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

K-GREEN Trust's net profit rose 7.4 per cent to $3.8 million in the third quarter, from $3.5 million a year ago, while revenue for the three months ended September was $17.1 million, up 0.3 per cent from a year ago.

For the nine months ended September, net profit slipped 4.8 per cent to $10.9 million from $11.4 million while revenue fell 13.8 per cent to $50.8 million.

Specifically, revenue from operation and maintenance (O&M) was $12.8 million for Q3 and $38.0 million for the nine-month period, representing an increase of 1.9 per cent and 1.4 per cent respectively.

This was mainly attributable to the higher output from the Tuas plant, as well as annual adjustments of O&M and power tariffs to account for changes in the consumer price index and fuel price.

Correspondingly, O&M costs rose 2.4 per cent in Q3 and 1.8 per cent in the first nine months of the year to $9.0 million and $26.7 million respectively.

Excluding construction revenue arising from the flue gas treatment upgrade last year, group revenue for the nine months remained stable, at $50.8 million while net profit would have been $0.2 million, or 2.0 per cent lower compared with a year ago, said Keppel Infrastructure Fund Management, trustee-manager of K-Green Trust.

Separately, group unitholders' funds decreased from $662.7 million as at end-December to $624.3 million as at end-September, mainly attributable to the distribution of $49.2 million to shareholders for 9M2013, partially offset by an increase in comprehensive income of $10.9 million during the period.

Correspondingly, total assets of the group decreased by $41.6 million to $639.9 million.

Going ahead, the underlying performance of the three assets in the business trust's portfolio is expected to remain stable, given that all three assets have long-term concession agreements with Singapore statutory boards.

The trustee-manager will continue to evaluate asset enhancement opportunities in all three assets and will continue to identify and evaluate suitable acquisitions. Key geographies for potential acquisitions remain Europe and Asia Pacific.

K-Green Trust's counter closed unchanged at $1.015.
